node.title: Astro 140: Life In the Universe (Instructor: Eric Ford)
Course Overview
node.body:
The possible existence of life beyond Earth is one of the most fundamental questions relating the human race to the physical Universe around us. While considerations of extraterrestrial life were in the domains of philosophy and science fiction in the past, today we have considerable scientific knowledge that can be applied to the question. Advances in modern astronomy have dramatically improved our understanding of our cosmic surroundings: tracing the cosmic origins of biological molecules, direct evidence for planets around most stars (exoplanets), and a deeper understanding of planet formation have all emerged in the past generation.  Several fields -- geology, biochemistry, paleontology (fossils), evolutionary biology --  give insight (though not a complete understanding) on how life arose on Earth, and spacecraft travel provides constraints on life elsewhere in our Solar System. 

The results from studies on Earth, the Solar System, and exoplanets across the Galaxy together indicate that the conditions for life are widespread in the Universe; extraterrestrial life has not been found yet, but does not seem implausible. Interstellar space travel between habitable planets, by humans or other beings, is exceedingly difficult but not physically impossible.   The course is thus rooted in modern science, but is connected to the long-standing philosophical question: Are we alone in the Universe? Today, this question is often embedded in science fiction (such as movies about aliens) and discussion about whether aliens have visited Earth.  Today, astronomical studies are leading the way in answering part of the question:  Earth-like planets seem to be extremely common.  But there is no evidence yet for life beyond Earth.  The course satisfies the General Natural Sciences (GN) component of the General Education requirements for a Bachelors degree from Penn State.  It requires the student has prior experience with an introductory astronomy course, but a background with another science course (e.g. biology, geology, chemistry) at the university level may suffice.  Students in this situation should contact the instructor during Drop/Add period to discuss whether the class is appropriate.  

What You Will Learn

The course naturally will give the student opportunity to learn lots of exciting new scientific discoveries in astronomy with strong elements of chemistry, geology and biology.  These findings are integrated around the basic question "Is there life in the Universe outside Earth?".   In addition to acquisition of knowledge, the course will return several times to discuss how science progresses, what science can tell us, and how it relates to other forms of thinking.  Finally, the course seeks to teach an important skill called `science writing'.  Here the student gathers information from diverse scientific sources and writes informative, well-organized, and well-phrased essays in a formal style that deemphasizes personal opinion and includes citations to scientific literature.  

Course Objectives

The course objectives for students to achieve during the semester are:

  • Knowledge & Comprehension: Define vocabulary. List facts and observational data that enable you to participate in scientific discussions regarding the potential for life beyond Earth.  

  • Application & Analysis: Describe the purpose and implications of scientific experiments and observations. Explain how the results have led to the current state of scientific understanding. Apply scientific reasoning to deduce the implications of hypothetical experiments and observations.

  • Synthesis: Explain how future experiments or observations could address open questions about the origins of life and potential for life beyond Earth.

  • Evaluation: Critically evaluate claims and identify the extent to which data is inconclusive.

Reading the textbook and online lessons will enable students meet the objectives of Knowledge & Comprehension.  Posting and reading discussion board posts will help students meet objectives of Application & Analysis and give the opportunties to begin synthesizing and evaluating scientific claims.  The Synthesis & Evaluation objectives will be further developed through writing two papers.  Participating in a citizen science project will provide students experience analyzing real scientific data and positioningn them to synthesize their understanding of the scientific process.  

Students will be assessed via a combination of online quizzes (Knowledge & Comprehension and Application & Analysis), discusssion board posts (some Knowledge & Comprehension, but primarily Application & Analysis), a class project (Application & Analysis), and two papers (Synthesis & Evaluation).

node.title: Course Navigation (CCW, Canvas, VoiceThreads)
node.body:
This course uses three interfaces.  

1. For quizzes, exams, discussions, submission of the project and papers, as well as e-mail communication and Course Announcements, the course will use the Canvas Course Management System.

2.  The interface that you are currently using will help to organize and deliver much of the course content, through a combination of web pages and videos. We will refer to this interface as the Course Content Website (CCW).  You can bookmark it at https://courses.ed.science.psu.edu/astro140/ or access each lesson from the corresponding module inside Canvas.

3.  Roughly once a week, the instructor will provide brief videos discussing the upcoming course content, discussing results of recent quizzes or other material, or some particular issue about the class.  These videos will be provided through the Voicethread system at Penn State; see here for an introduction.  The videos will appear in your Web browser within the lecture pages. In some cases, you may need to reload a page in order for the video to update. While you shouldn't need to enter the Voicethread system directly each week, you can via https://psu.voicethread.com/myvoice/group/1159117. Note that at the beginning of the semester, you must join the Voicethread `group' for our class  at the following URL: https://psu.voicethread.com/groups/subscribe/1159117/84507bce3/ .

It is important that you make sure that you are able to access this course via all three interfaces.  


At the top of all of the course pages in the CCW, you will notice a icon with a picture of a book and the word outline, which you can click to access a menu for the course content that lives within the CCW.  As you progress through the content, the menu expands to the right, creating breadcrumbs for you to navigate back through the content. You may also use the buttons at the bottom of your screen.

You will navigate to Canvas (canvas.psu.edu) anytime you are required to complete a quiz, participate in a Discussion Forum, or submit your paper or project.  The content is arranged by Modules/Lessons.

There may be times (e.g., near assignment deadlines) when it is important that you notice messages sent to your Canvas account promptly.  Therefore, many students choose to configure their Canvas email account to forward messages to an email or SMS account.   See 'Account' in the left menu and then 'Settings.'  In the far right menu, you can add emails or SMS contacts. (If you go back to the 'Account' link in the left menu, then you can adjust your 'Notifications' to send a copy of all of your course emails to your active personal email address, be it your PSU email or other personal account.   Note that messages sent via Canvas may include discussion of your course grades.  If you choose to forward these messages to accounts outside of Canvas, then you may be compromising the privacy of such information.)  

Remember to logout of the Astro 140 course content site and Canvas when you are done. The correct logout is important if you use a computer shared by many users (such as in computer labs) to prevent unauthorized access to your account and personal information such as grades.  Closing the browser tab or the browser window DOES NOT terminate the connection - “logging out” is important to preserve your privacy and work.

node.title: Instructions for Papers
node.body:
Papers for ASTRO 140 Life in the Universe

GOALS

  • Provide students with the opportunity to investigate a narrow scientific issue in some detail;
  • Challenge the student to assimilate diverse information into a coherent narrative;
  • Provide training in the art of scientific writing.

TOPICS   Paper topics should be chosen from the list of recommended topics (with recommended research materials) provided by the instructor later in the semester.  A student with a strond desire for a special topic should present it, with ideas for research materials, for prior approval by the instructor.  Our textbook and Wikipedia provide useful starting points for your research on most topics, but are not enough by themselves for a strong paper.  If you have difficulty identifying resources (or obtaining full-text versions), please freely contact the instructor. 

LENGTH AND FORMAT   The typical length is 3-4 pages text followed by pages for references and useful figures (perhaps .jpg taken from the Web). A cover page can be added.  The paper should be submitted prepared with a word processing system like Microsoft Word or Google Docs. The text is single-spaced with Arial or Times Roman font, 12pt font size, with 1" margins for 8.5x11 inch or A4 paper.  Papers may be submitted in either .docx or .pdf fomat with file names like "Lastname_Paper1.pdf".    

RESEARCH MATERIAL AND REFERENCING Each paper should make significant use of at least three sources beyond the text and Wikipedia.  Sources can include both general background sources and specialized sources;  it is great to have one or more peer-review research journal articles.   All sources(except the text and Wikipedia) should be included in the list of references and cited in the text.  Avoid many similar citations to the same source.  The example here in red illustrates referencing of book, article and Web material:

Cyanobacteria, also called blue-green algae, is not commonly seen today but dominated all lifeforms before the Cambrian Explosion 0.5 billion years ago.  Through photosynthesis, it had a dramatic effect on the composition of the Earth's atmosphere around 2 billion years ago (Kasting 2005, Chpt. 4; Lane 2010).  American and Australian geobiologists recently traced the genetic family tree of cyanobacteria found that only one of dozens of species evolved to produce oxygen (Perkins 2017).

Kasting, J. 2010, How to Find a Habitable Earth, Princeton Univ Press

Lane, Nick 2010, "First breath: Earth's billion-year struggle for oxygen", New Scientist, February pp36–9

Perkins, R. 2017, "How do plants make oxygen? Ask cyanobacteria", press release,  http://www.caltech.edu/news/how-do-plants-make-oxygen-ask-cyanobacteria-54559

GRADING  The grade will be based foughly equally on (a) the knowledge and understanding of the issue under study, and (b) the clarity and quality of the communication (Science Writing below).  For Paper 1, students will submit a draft to the instructor for suggestions on how to improve the organization and writing.  It need not be complete but should have at least: a detailed outline of the paper structure, two or more fully written paragraphs, and research references for the full paper.   The instructor will then return it with comments and suggestions for improvement to help the student write a strong paper.  Paper II will be written by the student independently based on a different set of topics provided by the instructor.  Paper I draft is worth 2%, Paper I completed 10%, and Paper II 15% of the course grade. 

SCIENCE WRITING  Quality science writing is a skill well worth developing and exercising. The paper's overall organization looks like a U: it begins with a short statement of motivation or scientific issue; most of the text presents the evidence or argument (some combination of empirical findings and scientific modelling); and the paper ends with a discussion of how the results relate to the original motivation. Within this framework, the paragraphs should follow a logical trail. Each paragraph should communicate one thought clearly.  Within a paragraph, sentences should be well-constructed.  Nouns and verbs should be informative (e.g. "The Martian photographs show ..." rather than "It was found ...").  First person pronouns should be avoided (e.g. not "I" or "my").  Colloquialisms and cliches should be avoided (e.g. "The experiment failed" rather than "It was a dismal failure").  Please read the following background materia: 

  • Eric Feigelson's general advice for astronomy writing (download)
  • Caty Pilachowski's tips for astronomy writing
  • William Safire's rules for writers (humorous)
  • Writing in the sciences
  • Astro writing problems (Feigelson)

ACADEMIC INTEGRITY Plagiarism is strictly prohibited. See the University document https://psu.box.com/v/PlagiarismAndYou for more details.  The presence of plagiarized text will be checked using specialized University-provided software. For example, you are not permitted to cut and paste text from the Web.   Extensive quotations from any source are also inappropriate.  Rather, the student should seek to understand and restate the issues in a new voice, summarizing and synthesizing diverse material (with appropriate reference).   

SUBMISSION A draft of Paper 1 is due Friday February 9, final version of Paper 1 is due Friday March 2, and Paper 2 is due by Monday April 30 (first day of Exam Week).  Each of these writing assignments is to be submitted via Canvas.  

Students are strongly encouraged to informally consult with the instructor as they progress with the papers.

node.title: Paper 2 Topics
node.body:
The recommended topics for Paper 2 concern exoplanet discoveries, properties, and implications.  While you can rely on information designed for the public (news releases, Wikipedia), I hope that most of you will delve into the research literature, at least for part of your paper. You can find the research papers on the `arXiv e-print' button of the ADS Web site.   Building on your experience with Paper I, your essay should be well-organized with an introduction / motivation, substantive scientific content, and brief conclusion.  Length is 2-3 pages of text (single spaced) with added figures and references.  The `science writing' style should be enforced: after you draft the text, revise it to remove `I/We' opinions, weak sentence structures (`This is ...'), colloquialisms (`once in a while...'), exaggerations (`amazing'), and excessive quotes.  Emphasize clear presentation of scientific findings and interpretations.   

If you have a different topic from Themes IV (Planetary systems in the Galaxy) or V (Life around other stars) that you strongly prefer to write about, send the instructor an email with title, scope/outline, and initial references.  You can proceed only if the instructor approves the topic.

node.title: Rubrics for Scientific Papers
node.body:
_____ Big Picture Items (38%)

_____ Choice of Topic (6%)

6:  The topic is appropriate to the course focused narrowly enough for the scope of this assignment.

4   The topic is appropriate to the course and focused, but lacks direction.

2:  The topic is appropriate to the course, but too broad or too narrow for the scope of this assignment.

0:  The topic is appropriate to the course and/or not clearly defined.

_____ Organization (8%)

8: Writer demonstrates logical sequencing of ideas with a specific point for each paragraph.

6: Paragraph/section development present but not perfected.

4: Logical organization; organization of ideas not fully developed.

2: Limited evidence of structure or organization.

0: No evidence of structure or organization.

_____ Integration of Knowledge (8%)

8:  The paper demonstrates that the author fully understands the references being reviewed and has applied concepts learned in the course. Concepts are integrated into the writer’s own insights. The writer provides concluding remarks that show analysis and synthesis of ideas, with conclusions supported in both the body of the paper and cited sources. 

6:  The paper demonstrates that the author, for the most part, understands the references being reviewed and has applied concepts learned in the course. Some of the conclusions, however, are not supported in the body of the paper and cited sources. 

4:  The paper demonstrates that the author, to a certain extent, understands the references being reviewed and has applied concepts learned in the course.

2:  The paper does not demonstrate that the author has fully understood the references being reviewed or that the author has not applied concepts learned in the course.

0:  The paper does not demonstrate that the author has fully understood the references being reviewed and that the author has not applied concepts learned in the course.

_____ Depth of Discussion (8%)

8:  In-depth discussion & elaboration in all sections of the paper.

6:  In-depth discussion & elaboration in most sections of the paper.

4:  In-depth discussion & elaboration in some sections of the paper.

2:  The writer has omitted pertinent content or content runs-on excessively. Quotations from others outweigh the writer’s own ideas excessively.

0:  Cursory discussion in all the sections of the paper or brief discussion in only a few sections.

_____ Cohesiveness (8%)

8:  Ties together information from all sources. Paper flows from one issue to the next without the need for headings. Author's writing demonstrates an understanding of the relationship among material obtained from all sources.

6:  For the most part, ties together information from all sources. Paper flows with only some disjointedness. Author's writing demonstrates an understanding of the relationship among material obtained from all sources.

4:  Sometimes ties together information from all sources. Paper does not flow - disjointedness is apparent. Author's writing does not demonstrate an understanding of all the relationship among material obtained from all sources.

2:  Does not tie together information. Paper does not flow and appears to be created from disparate issues. Writing does not demonstrate understanding of multiple relationships among material obtained from all sources.

0:  Absent, no cohesiveness

_____ Specific Elements of Paper (30%)

_____ Thesis Statement (6%)

6:  Clearly and concisely states the paper’s purpose in a single sentence, which is engaging, and thought provoking.  The thesis statement provides direction for the paper and with an interpretation based on evidence presented in the sources.

4:  Clearly states the paper’s purpose in a single sentence.

2:  States the paper’s purpose in a single sentence.

1:  Incomplete and/or unfocused.

0:  Absent, no evidence

_____ Introduction (6%)

6:  The introduction establishes the importance of the research topic, previews the structure of the paper, and states the main topic in an engaging way.

4:  The introduction addresses the importance of the research topic, but leaves room for improvement, and states the main topic and previews the structure of the paper. 

2:  The introduction does not establish the importance of the research topic, or states the main topic but does not adequately preview the structure of the paper.

1:  There is no clear introduction or main topic and the structure of the paper is missing.

0:  Absent, no evidence

_____ Body (6%)

6: Each paragraph has thoughtful supporting detail sentences that develop the main idea.

4: Each paragraph has sufficient supporting detail sentences that develop the main idea.

2: Some paragraphs lacks supporting detail sentences.

1: Multiple paragraph fails to develop the main idea.

0: Not applicable

_____ Conclusion (6%)

6. The conclusion is engaging and restates the thesis.

4.  The conclusion restates the thesis.

2.  The conclusion does not adequately restate the thesis.

1.  Incomplete and/or unfocused.

0.  Absent

_____ Quality of References (6)

6: More than 3 current and appropriate sources, of which at least 1 is a peer-review journal article. Sources include both general background sources and specialized sources. Special-interest sources and popular literature are acknowledged as such if they are cited. All web sites utilized are authoritative.

4: At least 3 current and appropriate sources, of which at least 1 is a peer-review journal article, scientific manuscript submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal or conference proceedings or scholarly book. Special-interest sources and popular literature are acknowledged as such if they are cited. All web sites utilized are authoritative.

2: At least 2 appropriate sources. Special-interest sources and popular literature are acknowledged as such if they are cited. All web sites utilized are authoritative.

1: At least 1 appropriate source. All web sites utilized are credible. 0: Not all web sites utilized are credible, and/or some sources are not appropriate.

_____ Writing Mechanics & Style (32%)

_____ Mechanics (8%)

8:  No errors in punctuation, capitalization and spelling.  Professional style throughout

6:  Almost no errors in punctuation, capitalization, spelling or professionalism.

4:  Several errors in punctuation, capitalization,  spelling and/or professionalism.

2:  Numerous and/or distracting errors in punctuation, capitalization, spelling, and/or professionalism.

0:  Not applicable

_____ Usage (8%)

8:  No errors in sentence structure or word usage.

6:  Almost no errors in sentence structure or word usage.

4:  Several errors in sentence structure and/or word usage.

2:  Numerous and/or particularly distracting errors in sentence structure and/or word usage.

0:  Not applicable

_____ Citation Style (8%)

8:  All cited works are done in the correct format with no errors.

6:  Some cited works are done in the correct format.

4:  Inconsistencies evident.

2:  Few cited works are done in the correct format.

0:  Absent/Not applicable

_____ Reference Style (8%)

8:  Done in the correct format with no errors.

6:  Done in the correct format with few errors. 

4:  Done in the correct format with some errors.

2:  Done in the correct format with several errors.

0:  Absent

Rubric for Draft or Detailed Outline of Scientific Paper

_____ Organization (40%)

40: Writer demonstrates logical sequencing of ideas with a specific point for each paragraph.

30: Paragraph/section development present but not perfected.

20: Logical organization; organization of ideas not fully developed.

10: Limited evidence of structure or organization.

0:  No evidence of structure or organization.

_____ Level of Detail (20%)

20: A specific purpose for each paragraph and at least two appropriate supporting details.

10: Room for improvement in purpose or level of supporting details of some paragrams.

0:  Room for improvement in purpose and level of supporting details of multiple paragrams

_____ Quality of References (40%)

40: More than 3 current and appropriate sources, of which at least 1 is a peer-review journal article. Sources include both general background sources and specialized sources. Special-interest sources and popular literature are acknowledged as such if they are cited. All web sites utilized are authoritative.

30: At least 3 current and appropriate sources, of which at least 1 is a peer-review journal article, scientific manuscript submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal or conference proceedings or scholarly book. Special-interest sources and popular literature are acknowledged as such if they are cited. All web sites utilized are authoritative.

20: At least 2 appropriate sources. Special-interest sources and popular literature are acknowledged as such if they are cited. All web sites utilized are authoritative.

10: At least 1 appropriate source. All web sites utilized are credible.

0:  Not all web sites utilized are credible, and/or some sources are not appropriate.

This rubric was adapted from http://www.cornellcollege.edu/library/faculty/focusing-on-assignments/tools-for-assessment/research-paper-rubric.shtml and https://www.cte.cornell.edu/documents/Science%20Rubrics.pdf accessed 8/7/2016.

node.title: Instructions for PlanetHunters project (not yet available)
node.body:
In this project, you will contribute to an actual citizen science research effort to analyze real astronomical data from NASA's Kepler spacecraft. Your contribution will help astronomers learn about how many stars in our galaxy might have planets orbiting them. This is a serious project that will take several hours to complete, so please plan ahead and budget your time accordingly.   You may choose to read about the project now, and perhaps even to start on this project the very first week.  That said, I fully expect that students will proceed to lessons for Theme 1, and come back to this page later as they make progress on the project.  

Your mission: Look for planet transits and classify light curves from NASA’s Kepler spacecraft based on the star’s temporal variability.

I. Getting Started

First, make sure you have watched my PlanetHunters video tutorial that provides an overview of how to use the PlanetHunters website to hunt for planets and to recognize other causes of stellar variability.

Second, go to the PlanetHunters website (http://PlanetHunters.org), sign up for an account (or log in again if you already created an account), and complete the introductory tutorial.  Go ahead and quickly inspect at least few light curves looking for any possible transits, just to get the hang of it.  Then, explore the other features of the website, as described in the video tutorial.  In particular, review the different types of light curves you may see in the “Spotter’s Guide”.  Once you are ready to start the main part of the project, continue to section 2. 

II.  Inspect & Classify Light Curves (30%)

In this step, you will inspect and classify at least 50 light curves.  You’ll record your results into a data tables, using one row for each light curve you examine.  First, make sure you are logged into Planethunters.org, click the “Start Classifying Planets” button or “Classify” tab to get started.

Inspect your first light curve and draw a box around any potential transits, as described in the tutorial.  Before you move on, classify each light curve according to the type of stellar activity using the following three categories:

a) Quiet: This is for light curves that do not show systematic variation. Any vertical scatter in the points is attributed to "noise". The spread of the scatter should be no more than about 0.05%.

b) Spotty: These light curves show clear and generally smooth variation.  There will not necessarily be a systematic repeating pattern, but there are often quaesi-periodic variations with a timescale of days to weeks.

c) Pulsating: These light curves also show clear variation, and with a quaesi-periodic pattern that repeats. The timescale of the pulsations are typically minutes to hours, significantly more rapid than spotty stars.

Record your interpretation into a data table using one row per light curve (see next page).  For each light curve, record your classification it into one of the three categories by placing a 1 in that column. Place zeros in the boxes for the other categories of stellar activity in the same row.  There are two additional columns to indicate if you identify a potential transit and for any notes you wish to record.  If you think you see one or more transits, enter the number of potential transits in the Transits column.  Note that you might not see any real planet transits during your entire project.  (If you mark a light curve as containing a transit, it should also be marked as belonging to one of the previous three categories.) Once you’re ready to move on, click the button at the bottom right (either “No Transits” or “Finished”). 

The next screen will have some additional information.  Record the “Zooniverse id” (at the bottom left in small font) for the star you just classified into your data table.  If you found something interesting, consider marking the light curve as a “Favorite” and/or leaving a comment about what interested you.  This will make it easier for you to come back to review your most interesting light curves near the end of the project.  Now, click next subject, and repeat for the next light curve.

Repeat the above process for at least 50 stars.  I encourage you to take breaks, so you stay fresh.  You can return as many time as you like over multiple days (remember your username) to classify dozens of light curves.  If you choose to use a printed copy of the data table, then you will need to print out several pages.  If you are using a spreadsheet with your data table, then add new rows as necessary to contain all your results. When you are finished, every box should have a number in it. Do not leave any boxes blank when you submit.

Suggestion:  You will report your results of Sections III, IV & V in the Canvas via the assignment named "PlanetHunter Project Results".  I suggest that you print out a copy of the questions you'll be asked to answer from Canvas, and perform the analysis and calculations in sections III & IV, writing down your responses as you go (either on paper or a text file).  Then you go back into the Canvas assignment, upload your data table from section II, enter your results from Section III & IV, and respond to the final questions in Section V.

III.  Analyze your Data  (30%)

1.  Review your data table. 

You’ll report a summary of your results in Count the total number of light curves you classified (and recorded in your data table). 

  1. Count the number of light curves that you categorized as “quiet”.
  2. Count the number of light curves that you classified as “spotty”. 
  3. Count the number of light curves that you classified as “pulsating”. 
  4. Count the number of light curves that you identified as having a potential transit.
  5. Compute the percentage of light curves that you classified into each category.  You can use the formula:  
    Percentage in given category = 100% * (Number in category) / (Total Number Inspected). 
  6. What is the percentage of light curves that you identified as having a potential transit? 

2.  Review your most interesting light curves.   

Now, that you’ve reviewed many light curves, you are likely to be able to recognize common patterns more easily.  Go back to review the light curves that you marked as potentially containing a transit.  (If you didn’t mark at least three as likely to contain a transiting planet, then use the light curves that you found most interesting, so that you review at least three stars.  You can access a light curve again by clicking “Talk” at the top of the PlanetHunters classification page, and then click “Search” at the top of the TalkPlanetHunters page, enter the “Zooniverse ID” of the light curve you want to review in the textbox below “Search For”, and click “Search”.  Then your object should appear on the right.  Click on your object’s Zooniverse ID, and you will have access to the entire Kepler light curve for that star.*  Note that typically you will now be presented with much more data than when you first reviewed the same star’s light curve.  Below the lightcurve, there is a label “Quarters” and a list of light curves segments (e.g., “1-1”, “1-2”, “1-3”, “2-1”, … “17-3”).  When you first reviewed the light curve, you were presented with just one of these segments. Now, you can review all the available data for the star.  Click on each of the quarters to review each segment of the light curve. 

* = You can also review a list of the light curves that you analyzed by choosing “Profile” at the top of the planethunters classification page.  If you marked some light curves as a “favorite” in planethunters, then you can find those by clicking “Favorites”.  If you entered a comment about some light curves, then you can find those by clicking “Talk” at the top of the planethunters classification page and then “Profile” on the TalkPlanetHunters page.

After reevaluating the interesting light curves you found, answer the following questions:

  1. Which light curves do you still consider likely to contain a good transiting planet candidate?  (List their ZooinvereIDs.)
  2. What is the percentage of light curves with a good transiting planet candidate relative to the total number of light curves in your data table?
  3. The Kepler mission monitored the brightness of ~192,000 stars in search of transits and identified approximately 4,696 planet candidates. What is the rate of planet candidates per star (expressed as a percentage) based on the Kepler mission? 
  4. How does the percentage of transiting planet candidates based on your analysis compare to the frequency of planet candidates identified by the Kepler Mission?
  5. If your % is similar, explain whether this is surprising or not, and why. If your number is different, explain why you think this is so.  In either case, list at least three possible reasons, and sort them by which are think is more significant (from most significant to least significant).
  6. Which of the light curves above do you consider to be your “best” transiting planet candidate?

IV.  Quantitative Analysis of One Planet Candidate  (30%)

Next, you will estimate a putative planet’s orbital period and size, based on the light curve with your best planet candidate.  If you have no good planet candidates, then you may use the star APH000067z.  You may wish to review the PlanetHunters video tutorial for tips to help you measure the transit depth and duration.

  1. What is the Zooniverse ID of the star that you are analyzing for this section?
  2. Find two to five putative transits.  (You may need to look in multiple quarters.)  Zoom in around each and report the approximate mid-times of each transit.  Use the times on the scale at the top of the light curves.  (The times along the bottom axis reset each segment, so can’t be compared across multiple segments.)
  3. Are the times of the putative transits consistent with a single orbital period?  If so, what is the approximate orbital period?
  4. What is the typical brightness level of the points outside of a transit?  (No units needed; brightness is in arbitrary / relative units.)
  5. What is the typical brightness level of the points inside of the transit? (again, no units needed)
  6. What is the transit depth? The formula for depth is (transit depth) equals (out-of-transit brightness minus in-transit brightness) divided by (out-of-transit brightness).
  7. Measure the starting time of a transit.  Measure the ending time of a transit.  Compute the transit duration.  (transit duration) = (transit end time) minus (transit start time).
  8. If there are many transits in the same light curve, then measure the transit depth and duration for at least five transits. 
  9. Are your measurements of the depths and durations of different transits are consistent with each other?  Does this result favor or disfavor the planet hypothesis?
  10. What is the average of your measured transit depths?
    (Use this average in the calculations below.)
  11. What is the radius of the putative planet relative to the radius of the star?
    The formula is (planet radius)/(star radius) = square root(transit depth).
  12. What is the radius of the putative planet relative to the radius of the Sun?
    (planet radius)/(radius of sun) = (planet radius)/(star radius) * (star radius)/(radius of sun)
    For most stars, the radius of the star (divided by the radius of the sun) will be reported below the light curve, after “Radius” and above “Kepler ID”.
  13. What is the radius of the putative planet relative to the radius of Jupiter? 
    The radius of the sun is approximately 10 times the radius of Jupiter.
  14. Given your measurement of the planet’s radius, is the putative transiting object more likely to be a planet or eclipsing binary star?
  15. What is the radius of the putative planet relative to the radius of Earth? 
    The radius of the sun is approximately 100 times the radius of Earth.
  16. If this star were to have another transiting planet whose radius was equal to that of the Earth, how likely would you be have noticed the Earth-size planet’s transits? 

V.  Reflecting on the PlanetHunters Experience (10%)

  1. What did you like most about this project? 
  2. Did you encounter any specific difficulties or frustration that you can pinpoint?   If so, please state which specific questions or logistical aspect of the project.  
  3. Do you have any suggestions for how the project could be improved for students in a future semester?
  4. Has this project affected your understanding of the scientific process?  If so, please explain how your perspective has changed through this project. 
  5. PlanetHunters is just one of several citizen science projects enabled by the larger Zooniverse project that involves hundreds of thousands of individuals worldwide in meaningful scientific investigations.  This new effort is known as Citizens Science, and Zooniverse won a major Global Impact Award from the Google corporation.  You may be interested in exploring some of their other projects.  Based on your experience with this project, how likely are you to participate in a citizen science project outside of a formal class?

node.title: Theme I: The Astronomical Context for Life
node.body:
Welcome to the first theme of the course. There are three topics for this unit:

  • How do we study life in the Universe?
  • Cosmology: The History of the Universe
  • Stars: Energy for Life

The unit will be completed over two weeks of the course.  Except for some historical background, this is intended primarily to review material you covered in a previous introductory astronomy class, with some particular focus on ideas most relevant to the emergence of life in the Universe.  If this material is new to you, then please devote extra time to this theme.  

You can navigate with the arrows at the bottom right of the page or using the links above.

node.title: How do we study life in the Universe?
node.body: (Use links on the left or the left-right buttons below)

node.title: The Scientific Method
node.body:
We are adopting here an empirical approach based on the scientific method. A good scientific theory should be consistent with previous observations or experiments, make clear and detailed (and often quantitative) predictions that are observable or testable, and the results must be reproducible by other scientists under controlled conditions. In astronomy, we often rely on the assumption (validated many many times) that the laws of physics and properties of matter are the same throughout the observable Universe. Science rests on the philosophical assumptions that there is a real world, that our senses inform us about this external reality, and that the physical world behaves in a consistent and often comprehensible manner.  This philosophical approach is called Positivism; it dates back to Plato in ancient Greece and grew to prominence in the 18th century as Newton's mathethematical laws of physics became widely accepted.  

Examples of strong arguments relating to Life in the Universe

  • We infer the existence of habitable planets orbiting ordinary nearby stars from periodic variations in the stars' radial velocity and from the transits of the planets across the star's disk. A few of these planets are in the star's Habitable Zone where life could develop. These results are convincing because they are quantitatively interpreted using Newton's laws of gravity & motion.
  •  We infer the existence of dozens of species of molecules in astronomical environments (molecular clouds, protoplanetary disks, comet tails, Jovian moons) which are essential to terrestrial life. This is convincing because quantum mechanics gives precise predictions regarding the emission lines of molecules.
  • We infer that all living organisms on Earth (bacteria, grass, bee, humans, etc) are descended from a single line of primitive organisms 3-4 Gyr (giga-year or billion years) ago. This is convincing because biochemical/cellular studies show tremendous similarity in the chemistry (DNA, proteins, metabolism) and genetic codes of organisms today, and because of interpretations of the fossil record combined with radioactive dating of rock layers.

Example of a weak argument relating to Life in the Universe

The presence or absence of UFOs is very difficult to interpret in a convincing fashion:

  • Pro: Unidentified Flying Objects demonstrate that technologically advanced extraterrestrial living organisms are now visiting Earth.  This is unconvincing because the explanation involving alien spacecraft is only one of several possibilities (e.g. witness mistakes or hoaxes). It would be convincing if we had some physical object from these visits that could be studied in scientific laboratories to show that the object is not from Earth. 
  • Con: The absence of clear visits from extraterrestrial civilizations demonstrates that no extraterrestrial civilizations exist in the Galaxy. This is known as Fermi's (or Tipler's) argument.  But  a general argument is made from a narrow finding.  It is possible that extraterrestrial civilizations exist in the Galaxy today with technology that could travel to Earth, but they have not done so.  Maybe they haven't found Earth (lots of other nice habitable planets for vacations!) or have chosen not to visit for some unknown reason.

So, while the astronomical evidence for habitable exoplanets orbiting other stars is quite convincing from a scientific viewpoint (even though the findings are quite recent), the various arguments cooncerning Unidentified Flying Objects are not very convincing in one direction or the other.  This is the kind of judgments we will seek during the course, particular in the Papers and Discussion.  Note that scientific arguments are not black-and-white. (In contrast, mathematical arguments can be absolutely right or wrong; for example, 2+2=5 is wrong). Science progresses by preponderance of evidence, confirmation and contradiction of predictions -- not logical proof. Thus, scientific conclusions at any given time can be wrong, particularly at the frontiers of knowledge. Scientific conclusions are not comprehensive and complete; there are many important questions which have not been successfully approached using the scientific method. On the examples above, we have not disproved the hypothesis "UFOs are from outer space" just because the evidence to date is unconvincing.

But collectively and over time, the powerful growth of mutually supporting scientific evidence and theories convinces large communities of scholars that we are on the right track of understanding the universe around us. We thus see progress from scientific knowledge to scientific understanding. As we gain understanding of different aspects of the universe, we also gain the ability to manipulate the physical world to our advantage. This leads to modern technologies: automobiles and jet airplanes, electricity and the Internet, medicines to treat diseases, and so forth.

During this course, we will be discussing issues where scientific knowledge and understanding is relevant to the question of Life in the Universe:

  • cosmology and structures in the universe
  • production of chemical elements and molecules in the Galaxy
  • formation and evolution of planets orbiting stars
  • concepts of habitability on planets
  • origin of life on planets
  • interrelationships between life and planetary atmospheres
  • possibilities of intelligent life on other planets

Some of this understanding is well-established (e.g. cosmology, synthesis of elements in stars), some is at the forefront of current research (e.g. formation of planets, life-atmosphere interrelationships), and some still have very little evidence and knowledge (e.g. origin of life, intelligent extraterrestrial life).

You can find some related discussions of the scientific method in the following material:

  • Earth Sciences 10, Lecture 1: Scientific Method

  • An Introduction to Science: Scientific Thinking and the Scientific Method by Steven D. Schafersman 

  • APPENDIX E: Introduction to the Scientific Method

Part of the method is amusingly presented in the 1-minute video "The Key to Science" by distinguished physicist Richard Feynman (Caltech) decades ago.  A more modern and nuanced view of the scientific method, taking into account sociological aspects of the scientific community, is given in a 19-minute TED talk by historian Naomi Oreskes (Harvard). Please see both of these videos.

node.title: The Rise of Modern Science
node.body:
Modern science began roughly 400 years ago in Europe with study of phenomena around us: study of the forces regulating the interaction of objects (physics), study of the composition of objects (chemistry), and study of living organisms (biology). Modern scientific theories, observations and experiments build upon themselves, creating an amazing edifice of knowledge and understanding. In many cases, we use our knowledge and understanding to build advanced devices that allow further discovery of phenomena and testing of theory. For example, we use our knowledge of light, optics, electronics, materials and spacecraft to construct superb telescopes that can see billions of times fainter than the human eye, and at wavelengths we can't see at all. We use our understanding of thermodynamics, gases, materials, and the chemistry of combustion to design jet airplanes that fly us around the world.  

Physical processes for many situations were found to have an underpinning in advanced mathematics (calculus, differential equations, group theory, differential geometry). We (or at least, I) really don't know why the Universe is regulated by mathematical laws of physics.  Here are a few of the major advances in the the emergence of modern science:

  • In the late-1600s, Isaac Newton derived differential equations that explain the motions and mechanics of interacting bodies (for instance, the motion of a kicked football or the motion of the Moon around the Earth)
  • In the late-1800s, Ludwig Boltzmann and others generalized these equations to explain the behaviors of fluids, gasses and stars. This includes thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, stellar systems, and so forth.
  • During the 1700-1900s, chemists found that matter is composed of combinations of ~100 elements: hydrogen, helium, carbon, iron, and so forth. Their properties could be organized in the Periodic Table of the Elements.  Browse the interactive Periodic Table of the Elements. The most important elements for living organisms on Earth are hydrogen (H), carbon (C], oxygen (O), and nitrogen (N). Our bodies also have phosphorus (P] in our DNA, calcium (Ca) in our bones, iron (Fe) in our blood, and small amounts of other elements.
  • In the early-1900s, many physicists found that behaviors within atoms are quantized; that is, only specific energies are permitted. Quantum mechanics provided a profound explanation for the periodic table of the elements, atomic and molecular spectra, and much more.
  • In the late-1900s, biochemists and cell biologists recognized that a complicated polymer known as DNA carries the genetic information in living organisms that provides a code for the production of proteins and for passing that information on to offspring.
  • In the late-1900s and early 2000s, particle physicists established the foundations of matter in the form of quarks and other elementary particles, including the Higgs boson discovered in 2013. These are understood within a theory based on quantum mechanics.
  • From the early-1990s to the present, astronomers have established that the universe is expanding from a `Big Bang' event ~14 Gyr ago.  The theory is well-established and agrees well with diverse datasets, but implies that the Universe is filled with Dark Matter and Dark Energy which we have not detected in the laboratory.

node.title: Historical Views on Life in the Universe
node.body:
Since the beginning of western culture, scholars have discussed the possibility that we are not alone in the Universe. For centuries, this was the domain of natural philosophers and theologians who discussed the issues based on abstract philosophical and religious ideas. Even astronomers who addressed the matter (e.g. Christiaan Huygens and William Herschel in the 18th century) engaged in fantastical thinking not supported by their observations. In modern times, the popularity of `science fiction' involving aliens from outer space reveals that the issue still has high cultural interest.

But, starting around the 1970s (e.g., Carl Sagan, Frank Drake, Lynn Margulis), these discussions began to be rooted in empirical findings of astronomy, planetary science, chemistry, and biology. It is not longer fantastic to discuss the possibility of extraterrestrial life. Our course will take this modern approach to the subject, but it is valuable to recognize the historical background. The information below is in outline form, but you are encouraged to learn more about these historical figures and ideas through the Web links.

Greek/Roman Era (500BC - 400AD) Arguments Both Against and in Favor of Extraterrestrial Life

  • Plato & Aristotle's geocentric universe: the celestial bodies are totally different from our earthly world
    • Terrestrial material: Earth, Water, Air, Fire
    • Heavenly material: quintessence or ether, crystalline spheres for Sun/planets/stars
    • In contrast, Democritus, Epicurus & Lucretius' s atomic universe: many Suns/Earths possible
  • Sun not Earth at center of solar system (Earth not special)
  • Myriad stars/Suns each with planets (Sun not special) 

See the excellent interactive historical timeline at Jet Propulsion Laboratory's PlanetQuest site.  

Christian Era (500-1500) Strong Prohibition against Extraterrestrial Life

  • Aristotlean science incorporated into Christian theology (angels/seraphim ~ heavenly spheres). E.g. in Dante's Divine Comedy.
  • God created Heaven, Earth and & Man (Book of Genesis, ancient Hebrew creation story). Man lies between beasts and angels (Chain of Being). Life on Earth has unique relationship to God and cannot exist elsewhere.

Age of Enlightment (1500-1900) Great Popularity of Extraterrestrial Life

  • Galileo's telescope (new moons/planets/stars), Newton's laws imply that the mechanics of the celestial bodies (e.g. Moon (celestial mechanics) are not different from the mechanics of our terrestrial world.
  • Chemical elements, discovery of "atoms" on Earth and in stellar spectra
  • Plurality of worlds very popular. Scholars write about Venusians, Lunar Cities, Martian canals. Examples include: Bernard de Fontenelle's Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds (1686, popular book among the nobles of France under Louis XIV) and Christiaan Huygens' Cosmotheoros (1698, book on human-like beings on Moon and the planets by a famous astronomer)

Three Illustrative Quotes

"The Marchioness was very impatient to know what the fixed stars were. Are the inhabited, like the planets [in our Solar System]? said she, or are they not peopled. … The neighboring worlds sometimes send us visitors, who come, in a very magnificent style. These visitors are comets, ornamented with brilliant flowing hard, a venerable beard, or a majestic train" (de Fontenelle 1686, p.110 & 121)

"What a wonderful and amazing Scheme have we here of the magnificent Vastness of the Universe! So many Suns, so many Earths, and every one of them stockd with so many Herbs, Trees and Animals, and adornd with so many Seas and Mountains!" (Huygens 1698)

"... the knowledge of the construction of the Moon leads us insensibly to several consequences... such as the great probability, not to say almost absolute certainty, of her being inhabited." (William Herschel 1780, famous astronomer, discoverer of Uranus using Newton's laws)

Modern Era (1900--) Arguments Both Against and in Favor of Extraterrestrial Life

Skepticism about life outside Earth (review Rare Earth hypothesis):

  • Temperatures, atmospheres in most planets are inhospitable
  • Failure to make 'life in the test tube' or find life on Moon/Mars
  • Simple life (e.g. bacteria) may be common but complex life (e.g. humans) may be rare
  • No evidence for extraterrestrial life yet

Illustrative Quote

"... how totally unfitted are all the other planets [in our Solar System] either to develop or to preserve the higher forms of life, and in most cases, any above the lowest and most rudimentary. ... Mars receives less than half the amount of sun-heat per unit surface that we do. And as it is almost certain that it contains no water ... man's place in the solar system is altogether unique, and that no other planet either has developed or can develop such a full and complete life." (evolutionist A. R. Wallace, 1903)

vs. scientific optimism about extraterrestrial life:

  • biochemistry is an extension of astrochemistry: emergence of life a natural phenomenon.
  • development of rocketry: travel to the planets achieved, travel to stars conceivable
  • Mars does have water, frozen today in polar caps but flowing as a liquid in the past
  • scientific search for extraterrestrial life in the Solar System begins (1970s--)
  • search for extraterrestrial radio signals (SETI) proceeds but unsuccessful (1960s--)
  • Carl Sagan, astronomer and popular proponent of searching for extraterrestrial life (1970-80s)
  • discovery of extrasolar planets successful (1990s--)
  • NASA promotes astrobiology & related initiatives (1990s--)
  • Example: This course and our textbook on astrobiology

Popular Culture (1900--)  Very Enthusiastic about Possibilities of Alien Life

  • Science fiction: H.G. Wells (c1900), Superman comics (1930s--), Isaac Asimov & Arthur C. Clarke (1950s-80s), dozens of other more recent authors
  • Television shows: Star Trek (1960s), My Favorite Martian (1960s), The X Files (1990s) and thousands more TV shows about aliens
  • Hollywood movies: 2001 (1968), Star Wars (1970s--), Alien (1979--), E.T.: The Extraterrestrial (1982), Contact (1997), Men in Black (1997--), & many others

Experience Carl Sagan, the most famous astronomer in the public eye during the 1970-90s.  view this 3-minute You Tube Excerpt,  "Contemplations of Life" from his Cosmos television series.  Though his language is poetic, Sagan was an excellent scientist and we are following his path in our Astro 140 course.  He made this in 1980, long before the discovery that exoplanets are very common in the Galaxy ... so his life-long optimism about extraterrestrial life was entirely speculative at that time.

node.title: Cosmology: The History of the Universe
node.body:
We first lay the foundations of Life in the Universe by discussing the Universe as a whole, its origins in a Big Bang ~14 billion years ago, and its history until the present day. Big Bang cosmology began in the early-20th century, was largely confirmed by the late-20th century, and is now in an era of detailed investigation, establishing the parameters of the model to ~1% precision.  Modern cosmology is full of unexpected and unintuitive features: a universal expansion (similar to blowing up a balloon); its contents dominated by mysterious Dark Matter and Dark Energy; a clear explanation for the formation of the simplest elements (hydrogen and helium), and the formation of stars and galaxies.

We then proceed to discuss galaxies that form from the matter in the expanding Universe, and our Milky Way Galaxy in particular.  It has billions of stars, but also an `interstellar medium' of gas and solid particles from which later stars and planets form.  So this lays the astronomical foundations for the existence of planets and chemical ingredients needed for life.  

All societies have a cosmology … an explanation for the origin and development of the world around us. In many traditional cultures, the world is created by deities, gods and goddesses. The previous lecture outlined the rise of modern science, starting with Isaac Newton's mathematical relationships defining the motions and gravitational interactions of physical objects.  So our cosmology is based on modern scientific theories (gravity, atomic & molecular physics, etc) that has been completely validated in the laboratory and in technologies.  This is the first cosmology that is `true' in an empirical sense, not based on beliefs or speculations.

node.title: The Big Bang Universe
node.body:
The expanding Universe

In the 1920s, the astronomer Edwin Hubble (shown below left) and others  obtained spectra of these galaxies to measure their motions towards or away from us based on the Doppler shift. To everyone's amazement, nearly all galaxies showed a redshift indicating they are all moving away from us. Furthermore, the redshift is greater for more distant galaxies, following a linear relationship v = Ho d (Hubble's law). Hubble's original data is shown below right; today we have millions of galaxy redshifts measured, extending the diagram to fainter magnitudes (rightward) and faster velocities (upward).   The only reasonable interpretation for all galaxies moving away from us in a linear fashion is that space itself is expanding, much like the rubber surface on a balloon expands as it is inflated.  By the middle of the 20th century, nearly all astronomers acknowledged that we reside in an expanding universe.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1828|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

A powerful explanation of the expanding universe actually preceded the observations.  A brilliant young scientist named Albert Einstein had made profound changes to Newtonian physics. First, in 1905, he showed that Newton's laws of motion do not hold when speeds approach the speed of light. He then struggled for a decade to understand gravity in this new context, emerging with the theory of General Relativity in 1915. Based on the view that massive bodies alter the geometry of 3-dimensional space-time, Einstein's General Relativity gives a full and accurate explanation of the gravitational attraction between bodies. The mathematics was quickly applied to the universe by others who found that the theory predicts that the Universe should not be static: it should either expand or contract following specific mathematical formulae. Remember that this is not a vague idea, but a rigorous mathematical derivation based on Einstein's General Relativity.

Below are predictions of the theory of General Relativity for different model parameter values.  The orange curve represents a `closed' Universe where the expansion stops and reverses to a contraction due to a high density of matter (Omega_m).  Curves above the green line represent an `open' Universe that expand forever.  Observations of the masses of galaxies (including the mysterious Dark Matter) indicate that our Universe has Omega_m around 0.3 ... so our Universe will expand forever.  But since 1999, very convincing evidence has been acquired that the universal expansion is actually accelerating, as in the red curve.  The cause is another mysterious component of the Universe (denoted Omega_V here) called Dark Energy, a repulsive force in space-time itself.  The nature of Dark Matter (which gives an attractive force) and Dark Energy (which gives a repulsive force) are not understood today, but we are convinced they exist.   

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1829|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

The cosmic microwave background

If the universe is expanding, then the galaxies were closer together and the average density of matter was higher in the past. Extrapolating to earlier times, there must be some instant when the expansion began, after which the density of the universe was extremely high. High densities imply high temperatures for normal matter. When dense matter is hot it radiates light with a `blackbody' spectrum. So the expanding universe model predicts:

  • the universe was formed in a `Big Bang' at a single instant. With the latest measurement of Hubble's constant, H_o=70 km/s/Mpc and other parameters, we have measured that the Big Bang occurred about 13.8 billion years ago.

  • the early universe just after the Big Bang was filled with light and particles at extremely high temperatures

  • the Universe should be suffused with light from the Big Bang following a blackbody spectrum

In the 1950s, physicist George Gamow calculated that the light from the Big Bang should cool as the universe expands, and should be a few degrees above absolute zero today. In the mid-1960s, this cosmic light was discovered, by accident, by Arno Pensias and Robert Wilson. They were working for Bell Laboratories (the U.S. telephone company) to investigate why static was present on long-distance telephone calls that used microwave signals. They found that the entire sky was the source of the radiation.  The discovery of the CMB was a powerful confirmation of the Big Bang model for the expanding universe.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1838|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

The CMB has been extensively studied since then, most recently with the Planck satellite telescope built by the European Space Agency.  Their image of the CMB, released in March 2013, across the entire sky (after removal of extraneous emission) is shown above.  It was found to have exactly a blackbody spectrum with T=2.735 K, about 3 degrees above absolute zero. Note the ripples (called `fluctuations') in the brightness, all at levels around a few parts in a million of the overall brightness.  These provide strong constraints on the model values for the Big Bang model. Below is a diagram of the composition of the Universe obtained from the best-fit Planck model.  Only 4% of the `stuff' in the universe is regular matter: molecules made up of atoms, themselves made up of protons, neutrons and electrons. 72% is the mysterious `Dark Energy' that is accelerating the universe's expansion, and 23% is comprised of the different mysterious Dark Matter that slows the expansion. Note that in our course on Life in the Universe, we are  concerned only with 4% of regular matter from which stars, planets and biospheres are made.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1839|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1840|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

The birth of galaxies

Even though the Universe has been expanding since the Big Bang, dispersing the atoms and cooling the light, gravity is still present. On local scales, atoms attracted each other, forming early stars and then galaxies. We have little observational knowledge about this phase of the Universe's history, hence its nickname `the Dark Ages'. It lasted roughly from 1 million to 1 billion years after the Big Bang, or the first few percent of the Universe's current age. Astrophysicists argue that an early generation of stars formed during this time, quickly going supernova and polluting the gas with small amounts of elements heavier than helium. Detailed models show that gravitational attraction (involving both Dark Matter and regular matter) produced dense sheets and filaments that then collapsed to form galaxies and galaxy clusters. Big galaxies cannibalize smaller ones, and mergers of big galaxies are common. Massive black holes formed at the center of most galaxies at the same time. 

Astrophysicists have taking the known laws of physics (gravitational attraction, gas dynamics) with the conditions emerging from the Big Bang to produce computer simulations of the formation of galaxies as the Universe expands and cools. These simulations are among the largest scientific calculations ever made. See this excellent 4-minute YouTube video for a tour of the 2013 Illustris simulation, one of the most recent and comprehensive efforts.

node.title: Galaxies and the Milky Way Galaxy
node.body:
Galaxies: The home of stars and planets

In the early 20th century, astronomers knew only about stars relatively near the Sun in the Milky Way. But there were some blurry objects in the sky known as `nebulae'. Around 1920, the talented American astronomer Edwin Hubble used a large new telescope in California to obtain improved photographs of the nebulae. Some appeared to be huge, but very distant, structures similar to the Milky Way. With repeated observations of the nebula Messier 31 in the Andromeda constellation, Hubble demonstrated it was a distinct "island universe," or galaxy. He and others photographed many other galaxies.  

The first two galaxy images shown below are seen nearly face-on, showing the spiral arm structure where stars are forming today.  The third image shows a spiral galaxy seen edge-on. Note the dark clouds of interstellar medium that obscure the flat disk.  While galaxy collisions still occur today, ~14 billion years after the violent Dark Ages, most galaxies are quiet and stable, serenely spinning through space.
