The Milky Way Galaxy

Because the Sun lies in the disk of our Galaxy, we cannot see its structure as we can with distant face-on galaxies.  But recent images of the full sky have shows that our galaxy is very similar to other spiral galaxies.  The first photo below is an all-sky composite of our Galaxy as seen from Earth.  Note the similarity to the edge-on spiral shows above.  The second image below is obtained at infrared wavelengths of light where the obscuring clouds have little effect.  The final image below is a recent artist's drawing, consistent with modern observations, showing our Galaxy  as it would appear if seen face-on.  Note the Sun is about 25,000 light-years (8000 parsecs) from the center, and lies between two spiral arms. The central region of the Galaxy has a large bar, and a modest 3x106 Mo massive black hole lies at the very core.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1845|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1846|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1847|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

Astronomers study star and planet formation in the closest spiral arms which do not suffer too much obscuration from interstellar clouds and are nearby so that small and faint structures can be detected.  For example, a major nusery of young stars near the Sun is the Orion Nebula in the Orion Nebula Cloud, which likes in the Orion Spur shown in the above diagram.  It is only ~400 pc (parsecs, 1 pc ~ 3 light-years ~ 3x1016 meters) away, much closer than the Galactic Center at a distance around 8,000 pc.

node.title: The Interstellar Medium and Molecules
node.body:
The images of the Milky Way Galaxy and other galaxies shown on the previous page were mostly made in visible light, the waveband where the surfaces of stars shine. Their temperatures are thousands of degrees Kelvin (above absolute zero). But the dark clouds where stars and planets form are much colder, only tens or hundreds of degrees Kelvin. These `shine' in the microwave and infrared bands of light, and in particular exhibit the emission lines and bands produced by particular molecules. 

The interstellar medium has two major components, gas and `dust'.  The gas is mostly hydrogen and helium (H and He) produced in the Big Bang, with elements like carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, silicon, iron  (C, O, N, Si, Fe) and other elements produced in red giants.  (We will discuss this next week.)  In the cold clouds, these atoms are in the form of molecules such as H2O (water), CO (carbon monoxide), CO2 (carbon dioxide), and dozens of other molecules.  The `interstellar dust' component is poorly named; it is mostly tiny powder-like particles of rock, such as SiO2 (silicon dioxide, called `quartz' when found in Earth rock).   There are also tiny solid particles of carbon resembling the black soot that comes out of combustion on Earth (e.g. a burning candle or log). 

Interstellar clouds nearby in the Milky Way can be oddly beautiful in photographs.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1549|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__left]The first two images show the Eagle Nebula and the Orion Nebula in visible light, as seen with the Hubble Space Telescope.

The Eagle shows dark pillars of cold gas and dust illuminated by a nearby hot star. A few stars (probably with planets) are forming now in these pillars. Orion recently (about 1-2 million years ago) formed a rich cluster of stars (probably with planets). The dark cloud is behind the cluster, and the edge is brightly shining due to heating by the hottest Orion stars.[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1550|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__left]

The third image shows a much larger cloud as viewed in the infrared with the Spitzer Space Telescope. The light here is from vibrations of soot-like hydrocarbon molecules.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1551|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__left]

The final image below shows recent research maps of two emission lines of the ammonia molecule (NH3) in a small dark cloud that is likely to form stars soon.

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1552|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__left]

Interstellar molecules

To pursue our study of live in the universe, we first need to introduce some concepts and information about atoms, molecules and light. `Atoms' are tiny entities with a dense nucleus of protons and neutrons surrounded by a cloud of electrons. The number of protons defines the element: 1 = hydrogen (H), 2 = helium (He), …, 6 = carbon (C), 7 = nitrogen (N), 8 = oxygen (O), …, 26 = iron (Fe), and so on.  If you don't know or have forgotten the symbols for the elements, see a Periodic Table of Elements here.   A collection of atoms can be called a gas cloud.

When the cloud is hot, two atoms that collide will bounce off each other because the electron clouds (both negatively charges) repel each other. But when a cloud is cold and the collisions are slow and the two atoms can form a weak, but stable, bond. This occurs when the attraction of the protons is slightly stronger than the repulsion of the electrons. These entity of two or more atoms bonded together is called a `molecule'. `Chemistry' is the science devoted to the behavior and reactions between molecules.  Below are two diagrams of the water molecule, H2O.  

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1853|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

The bonds between atoms in a molecule are not entirely fixed. They can stretch and bend in various ways (see fun moving diagrams). Even at very cold temperatures, the molecules can rotate. But the behavior of atoms and molecules is not like the behavior of large objects we experience in our daily lives. Large objects can move in a smooth fashion where any energy is possible. But tiny objects follow the rules of `quantum mechanics' and can be in only a fixed number of distinct energy states. A rotating or vibrating molecule can change its energy state by emitting or absorbing a particular wavelength of light. These wavelengths are generally not in the visible band, but have longer wavelengths in the infrared and microwave bands.

Thus, astronomers can observe the sky using specialized telescopes and look for emission or absorption lines at particular wavelengths associated with the quantum transitions of specific molecules. Even for simple molecules, these patterns of spectral lines can be very complicated, often blurring together to form messy bands. But they are unique for each molecule: just as a crime investigator can identify a person from a unique fingerprint, an astronomer can identify a molecule from its unique pattern of microwave and infrared emission lines. The study of the spectral lines and patterns produced by different molecules is called "molecular spectroscopy."

Here are infrared spectra for three common molecules: water, carbon dioxide, and ethanol (the alcohol in wine and beer). To show why this is relevant to our search for live in the universe, we show the infrared spectra of three familiar planets in our Solar System. We see that Venus, Earth and Mars all have carbon dioxide in their atmospheres, but only Earth has abundant water and oxygen (inferred from it chemical byproduct, O3 or ozone).

  

The result of several decades of molecular spectroscopy of interstellar clouds has shown an amazing variety of molecules in a gas that is mostly hydrogen (H2) and helium. Most of these molecules are organic; that is, they containing carbon. Some are quite simple molecules: carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), hydrogen cyanide (HCN). But others are more complex: ethane (C2H6), ether (CH3OCH3), ethanol (CH3CH2OH), acetone (CH3CH3CO), acetic acid (CH3COOH), a simple sugar (CH2OHCHO), antifreeze (HOCH2CH2OH), and controversially, possibly an amino acid (NH2CH2COOH). Some interstellar molecules are not organic (that is, without carbon): water (H2O), nitrogen (N2), ammonia (NH3), hydrochloric acid (HCl), salt (NaCl), sulfur dioxide (SO2), and so forth. Some molecules happen to have emission lines at wavelengths that are technically difficult to detect. This is the reason that the oxygen molecule (O2) was not discovered until 2011 using the new Herschel Space Telescope.

See an up-to-date list of interstellar molecules at The Astrochymist Web site. Go to the bottom of the molecule list to see some of the complicated organic molecules found recently with the ALMA telescope (below).  So far, molecules common in life on Earth (like sugar or amino acids) have been found, but similar ones have been detected.  

To discover the molecular material from which planets (and eventually living organisms) form, we have to study the sky with infrared and microwave telescopes. Below are photos of important telescopes at the three bands: the Gemini telescope on a Hawaiian mountaintop for visible wavelengths, the Spitzer Space Telescope orbiting the Earth at infrared wavelengths (two photos), and the ALMA (Atacama Large Millimeter Array) recently built on a high plateau in Chile.  This telescope cost over $1B as a collaboration of astronomers from North & South American, East Asian and European nations.

node.title: Stars: Energy for Life
node.body: On Earth, scientists study the complicated interactions in the world around us, often tracing `cycles' that show how some feature begins, develops, and ends. Some involve physical components (such as the `water cycle': evaporation from oceans, rain and rivers flow back to oceans, some is captures in ice caps) while others involve living organisms (such as the life cycle of a human from birth through childhood, adulthood, aging and death). Similarly, astronomers can trace the physical cycles and interactions in a Galaxy, and of its components (such as the interstellar medium, stars and planets). Here we discuss the life cycle of individual stars. Stars are crucial for life in the universe: without the chemical elements they produce, planets would be made only of gases; and without their heat, planets would be too cold to sustain life.

node.title: Star Formation
node.body:
We have seen that, in a spiral galaxy like the Milky Way, a complicated "interstellar medium" resides in the space between stars. It consists of gases (mostly hydrogen and helium from the Big Bang, with a soup of interesting molecules) and tiny solid "dust grains" (some made of rock like tiny sand grains, others made of carbon like soot).  We see it best in illuminated clouds like in the Orion Nebula or Eagle Nebula.  As a spiral arm passes through a region in the Galaxy, the interstellar material is compressed and dark cold clouds form. When a cloud of interstellar medium is dense enough, gravity locally dominates other forces and a star forms by `gravitational collapse'. Material with too much spin forms a flattened disk orbiting the protostar; this is the "protoplanetary disk" where planets form. The star and disk formation process is complicated, and astrophysical modeling is underway. Thus stars, planets, and any life on these planets inherit their molecules from the interstellar medium.

Look at the recent computer simulations of the star formation process in a small interstellar cloud by Matthew Bate.

In Bate's simulations, the gas in the cloud starts off with random swirling motions known as turbulence. Then some clumps undergo gravitational collapse forming stars (white dots), but gas in filaments continue to fall into central concentrations of gas. Some stars form in isolation with their disks, but many interact with other young stars and disks in complex ways. A large fraction of stars remain in binary systems. Many stars form in large molecular clouds where hundreds or thousands of stars form together as a star cluster. Here, too, individual stars often have these protoplanetary disks. We will study protoplanetary disks later in the course to understand how diverse types of planetary systems form; this is needed to evaluate how many planets could harbor life similar to Earth's.

The central points are that

  • stars form by gravitational collapse in molecular clouds which pervade the thin disk of the Galaxy; and
  • due to the turbulence in the clouds, disks of interstellar gas and dust orbit the protostars, and these protoplanetary disks are the site of planet formation.

node.title: Stellar Evolution
node.body:
Once formed in a molecular cloud, the individual star goes through four major phases of evolution:

  • a brief pre-main sequence phase powered by release of energy from the gravitational collapse;
  • a long-lived main sequence phase powered by fusion of hydrogen to helium in the core;
  • the red giant phase powered by fusion of helium to elements up to iron;
  • death processes—the outer layers of the red giant stars are ejected, slowly or violently, and the inner core becomes one of three types of compact star (white dwarf, neutron star or black hole).

The observational evidence for the evolution of a star is often shown on the Hertzsprung-Russell (H-R) diagram. Here we plot the luminosity of the star on the vertical axis (actually, the log of the luminosity since the range of luminosities is so huge), and the surface temperature on the horizontal axis. Recall that luminosity has units of energy per second, and measures the intrinsic light output or "power" of a star. A common unit of luminosity is the `watt'; we might have a 60-watt lightbulb in our room, while the Sun today emits 4x1027 watts.  We designate one solar luminosity as 1 Lo.  Below is the best available HR diagram, obtained with the Hipparcos satellite a decade ago.  

A protostar in a molecular cloud has a relatively cool surface but is quite luminous, and thus appears in the upper-right part of the H-R diagram. It quickly (not too quickly… for a 1 Mo star like the Sun, in ~10 million years) loses power but heats its surface, moving downward and to the left on the diagram below.

When the star reaches the main sequence where the core temperature exceeds ~13 million degrees Kelvin, nuclear reactions begin in the core that fuse hydrogen to helium. In most stars, this is through the "proton-proton chain" with intermediary steps involving rare isotopes of hydrogen and helium. As over 70% of the star is hydrogen, there is a vast supply of fuel for this reaction, keeping stars on the main sequence for (in most cases) billions of years. This is the most stable and long-lived phase of stellar evolution. Our Sun today has been on the main sequence for 4.5 billion years, and will continue hydrogen-to-helium burning steadily for ~6 billion years more. Below is an artist's conception of the interior of the Sun and many other similar main sequence stars.  

If this topic is not familiar to you, learn more about stellar evolution on the interactive H-R diagram at the Cosmic-Ray website.

node.title: Red Giants: 'We are Starstuff'
node.body:
The red giant phase is particularly important for understanding the origin of elements needed for planets and living organisms. When hydrogen is depleted in the core of the main sequence star (that is, when the core is entirely helium), nuclear burning continues in a shell around the core. When the core reaches ~120 million degrees Kelvin, then helium is not longer stable and can react with itself to form heavier elements.

First, the helium flash initiates the reaction

3 4He ---> 12C + 2 gamma-rays

Stars like the Sun will then burn hydrogen to helium in a shell around the core where helium is burning to carbon.  The star becomes very luminous but the outer layers swell to huge radii and cool.  The star thus moves upward and to the right in the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.  The yellow curve in the H-R diagram below, labeled `1' for one solar mass (1 Mo). 

Cores of more massive stars (5-100 Mo) will be hot enough to burn carbon and other elements up to iron:

12C + 4He ---> 16O

16O + 4He ---> 20Ne

and similar reactions give 24Mg, 28Si, 32S, ..., 56Fe (iron).

These rare high-mass stars become supergiants, the most luminous stars in the Galaxy, during their brief red giant phases. Several nuclear reactions can occur simultaneously in the core and shells around the core (like layers of an onion; see diagram below). Each nuclear reaction releases more energy, so the stars becomes more and more luminous. These are the massive supergiants with luminosities L ~ 105-106 Lo.

Iron is the last element that can be made in this fashion because it is the most stable nucleus.  That is, any nuclear reaction involving iron requires more enegy than it emits.  Iron is thus the end-product of normal stellar nucleosynthesis.

The synthesis of nuclei in red giants/supergiants explains the relative abundances of different elements in the Universe.  The plot below shows that, after hydrogen & helium, the most abundant elements in the Sun are the even-numbered elements between 6 and 26 protons: C, O, Ne, Mg, ... Fe.  The odd-numbered elements are rarer.  Note also the rarity of elements heavier than iron; these heavy elements (like lead, gold and uranium) are formed only in the rare supernova explosions of the most massive supergiants. Similar abundances of the elements are seen in other stars, the Galaxy's interstellar medium, Jupiter and elsewhere. This universal pattern is powerful evidence for the theory of red giant stars, and implies that red giants are the main source of elements with 6-26 protons in the Universe.

How do these atoms formed inside red giant stars get out into the Galaxy? Convection (like boiling) in red giants brings these heavier elements produced in the interior to the surface. There they condense into tiny solid particles of rock (typically Mg-Si-O mixtures) and carbon which are pushed outward into space by the starlight. These explain the interstellar dust particles, which scatter and redden light in the Milky Way.  Later, the gas and dust ejected by red giant stars enter cold molecular clouds, where it undergoes gravitational collapse and forms new stars and planets.

Thus, the Earth, you and I are composed of C/N/O/Si/Fe/... atoms that were created in red giant stars before our solar system was born. The atoms were formed by nuclear reactions in the giant/supergiant phase, ejected into the interstellar medium in both gaseous and solid form, and later incorporated into the solar system, the biosphere and ourselves.  The link between living organisms and red giant stars led Carl Sagan, the famous astronomer of the 1980-90s, to declare:

"We are made of starstuff." (Carl Sagan)

node.title: Summary: The Astronomical Context for Life
node.body:
In this introductory portion of the course, we have found that normal galaxies, forming billions of years ago after the Big Bang, form stars and planets continuously from their interstellar medium. The stars produce elements heavier than helium by nuclear fusion, and these atoms are ejected into the galaxy's interstellar medium. More stars and planets form in the cold interstellar clouds, now enriched with atoms from the furnaces in stars. We thus see a `cycle' in the Galaxy, from stars to red giants which have winds and supernovae that enrich the interstellar medium the heavy elements, which then make more stars and planets.  Planets, and life, are thus the result of the long `cycle' of chemical enrichment the the Galaxy ... there could not be any planets right after the Big Bant, only billions of years later.  

These heavier atoms combined to form a wide variety of molecules, many containing carbon. Interstellar clouds can be viewed as a laboratory of organic molecules diluted in the dominant hydrogen (H2) and helium from the Big Bang. These chemicals are familiar to us -- water, molecules in Earth's atmosphere (O2, N2, CO2), methane and other hydrocarbons, alcohols and sugars. These are the molecules we see in our daily lives on the surface of Earth, the same molecules necessary for living organisms on Earth.  Thus life, like planets, are the result of the repeated cycle of star formation and death in the galaxy.  

We thus have traced profound links between the Universe, the galaxies, the stars, the interstellar medium, star and planet formation, and life on Earth. While some of this story was known ~50 years ago and Carl Sagan outlined it for the public ~30 years ago, many of the findings are very recent. Understanding the molecular universe, in particular, is a strong motivation for the most modern (and expensive) telescopes of the past ~10 years such as the infrared detecting Spitzer and Herschel Space Telescopes launched into space, and the ALMA millimeter telescope in Chile.

node.title: Theme II Life on Earth
node.body:
Week 3 treats the chemical foundations, origin and evolution of living organisms on Earth. Our coverage is necessarily brief...these are huge fields of biochemistry, cell biology, and evolutionary biology. But our text An Introduction to Astrobiology has an excellent Chapter 1 that presents much of the needed material in a compact, but well-written fashion.  The lectures in the following pages below emphasize some of the text's topics and introduces a few new ideas.  

Week 4 proceeds with some topics on terrestrial life.  Perhaps the most important topic is the interactions between dominant living organisms and the planet's atmosphere: consumption of carbon dioxide and production of oxygen by micro-organisms and plants with photosynthesis; and the recent reintroduction of carbon dioxide by a particular advanced animal ... us!  Thus the issue of `global warming' that is widely discussed in modern society is but a single example of various ways life can affect their host planet.

node.title: Origin of Life
node.body:
We begin Week 3 looking at the origin of life and we cover two topics:

  • What is Life?
  • Chemistry and Origin of Life
  • Life and Earth's atmosphere

node.title: What is Life?
node.body:
Life of Earth today exhibits tremendous diversity:

  • Green grasses uses solar blackbody radiation plus H2O and CO2 from the atmosphere to grow and produce grass seeds.
  • A white fungus grows on a dead tree in the forest, obtaining water and carbon-based molecules from the tree rather than the atmosphere, and may reproduce nearly in place so as to gradually cover more of the tree (and perhaps break off and be moved to a new location by wind or another animal) or may create spores to spread similar to seeds.
  • Humans consume H2O and organic molecules from plants and animals plus O2 from the atmosphere to grow, move around and make baby humans through sexual reproduction.  
  • Bacteria near mid-oceanic ridges at the ocean floor use sulfur-based chemicals and/or geothermal heat to grow and reproduce in darkness.  

It is extremely difficult to write an complete definition that includes all of this variety of life on Earth, let alone one that is useful for the search of extraterrestrial life.  Here are two possibilities (see our text sec 1.1.1 for a similar discussion): 

A living organism is something that can reproduce and evolve through natural selection.

A living organism extracts and organizes energy and material from its environment to preserve its existence, grow and produce similar independent organisms.

The fact that scientists seriously consider two definitions that are so different from each other demonstrates how hard it is to develop a good definition for life.  For example, these definitions do not have some criteria satisfied by all terrestrial (Earth-based) life, such as `constituted of carbon-based molecules' or `require liquid water as a solvent during some phase of their life'.  This is intentional.  We wonder if life forms could exist on other planets that have different chemistries and solvents.  For example, we will learn shortly that Saturn's moon Titan has rain/streams/lakes of liquid methane that are extremely different from environments on Earth, but it is not inconceivable that they could harbor life.

Most scientists agree that some things are not alive:

  • Star It has a well-defined life-cycle (protostar --> main sequence star --> red giant --> white dwarf or neutron star) and interacts with its environs (formed by gravitational collapse of ambient gas, illuminates planets).  But a star does not actively organize external energy or material and does not reproduce.  
  • Planet It has a complex internal and atmospheric structure and could be said to extract and organize energy from its host star, but the key planet properties were set near the time of its formation based on the mass and angular momentum of the material that formed the planet.  While a planet may be said to `evolve' as in change properties, it does not reproduce, therefore it does not `evolve' in the technical sense refering to natural selection.  
  • Robot or computer program?   Some computer programs are effective at learning from repeated trials. They fall underthe rubrics of `machine learning algorithms' or, less technically, `artificial intelligence' (AI). When an AI software system is connected to mechanical device, it is often called a robot. It is still unclear whether some future AI will achieve human-like self-awareness and creativity (though this is not a requirement for life). This issue addressed in a thoughtful way by the 2004 Hollywood movie I, Robot. It is debated whether a robot/AI could be built that is programmed to make a similar new robot (known as a Turing machine) and, if so, would it be alive? But we are far from having robots reproduce and evolve through natural selection.  You might find interesting some discussions of these issues with leading scientists here and  here.
  • Virus?  These are exceedingly small biological structures consisting of protein and RNA/DNA that invade living cells and use their DNA-->RNA-->protein machinery to reproduce themselves.  Viruses are based on same chemistry as living organisms on Earth but are parasitic, requiring host cells for reproduction.  It is not clear whether they should be considered living organisms.  

Living organisms are part of the natural world on Earth,

but have remarkable properties that are not shared by other parts

of the terrestrial environment like the rocky surface, oceans, or atmosphere.

We now show that the molecules that constitute living organisms

are drawn from the molecules that astronomers

find throughout the Galaxy.

node.title: Chemistry and the Origin of Life
node.body:
Chemical foundations of life

All known living organisms on Earth are based on organic (carbon-based) molecules : chains and rings of carbon atoms with H, O, N and occasional other elements. These are often combinations and polymers of simple molecules found in the Galaxy's interstellar gas and dust, which entered into the solar nebula and are now found in the atmospheres and ices around the Solar System. Examples:

  • CH4 (methane). Chains of methane give propane, octane (gasoline), wax and other hydrocarbons with H and C atoms.  Add carbon rings to get soot and coal.
  • Chain of 5 CH4 + 6 H2O + CO2 = C6H12O6, a common sugar produced by photosynthesis (Fig 1.5). Chains of sugar give starch, chitin and cellulose; the latter is the principal structural molecule of plants (e.g. the wood of trees). These are carbohydrates with H, C and O atoms. 
  • Chain of 3 CH4 + 1 H2O + 1 CO2 + 1 NH3 = C4O3H6N gives alanine, one of ~20 common amino acids (Fig 1.6). Chains of amino acids give proteins which are principal structural and functional molecules in all living organisms on Earth.
  • Ring of 4 CH4, 2 NH3, 1 H2O and 1 CO2 gives nucleic acid thymine (Fig 1.8). Huge polymers of sugars, nucleic acids and PO4 molecules gives deoxyribonucleic acid or DNA (Fig 1.9), the principal self-reproducing molecule containing the genetic code in living organisms.

Terrestrial life is thus based on macromolecules (cellulose, proteins, DNA, etc.).  Carbon is the crucial element for all known Earth-life.  All known Earth-organisms require liquid water as a solvent for at least some life stage.  The huge, complicated molecules of terrestrial life are themselves based on simple molecules, which  can found distributed throughout the Milky Way galaxy .

Chemistry of the Galaxy

It may be useful to review our earlier class on molecules in the interstellar medium.  We found that there are dozens of known organic (carbon-based) molecular species identified in interstellar clouds.  Many are also found in protoplanetary disks where planets form.  Our text's Table 1.3 also gives a list.  Note that these are not exactly the same molecules that lie at the foundation of life on Earth (e.g. sugars, amino acids, bases), but they are closely related.  Thus, the Galaxy provides a rich mixture of organic molecules from which life can form .... if conditions are right!

Origin of life on Earth

The first clear cut examples of living organisms appearing in fossils is ~3.5 billion years ago, or ~1 billion years after Earth formed.  There is a debate among paleontologists ... some are convinced by evidence that living organisms were present as early as 0.5 billion years after Earth's formation (sec 2.4.5).   These are simple unicellular bacteria and algae which grew in mats on the surface of the ancient ocean.  The evidence for them are fossil structures called stramatolites  seen in ancient rockbeds (Fig. 2.16).  

We do not know exactly how the first self-reproducing living system formed.  Laboratory experiments by Miller & Urey starting in the 1950s show that amino acids and other fundamental organic molecules of living organisms can form from mixtures of H2O, CO2, CH4 and NH3 plus solar energy and soils (Fig 1.19).  Other early experiments have taken amino acids and lipids in the laboratory and made cell-like spheres (Fig 1.30).  

However, no self-reproducing molecule or cell has been formed in the laboratory.  We can only guess that somewhere on the Earth's complex surface, over hundreds of millions of years, a complicated molecular system based on left-handed amino acids emerged, began eating other organic molecules, and began reproducing.    

In the 19th century, Charles Darwin suggested life formed in a `warm little pond'.  It is plausible that the early Earth's seas concentrated organic molecules in drying pools or ponds  (sec 1.6.3).  And the chemistry in such shallow ponds can be accelerated by catalysis with certain minerals (sec 1.7.3).  Nonetheless, many attempts to reproduce the formation of complex polymers in simulated ponds, as we see in living organisms,  have failed.  

Some discussions of life on Earth, often motivated by ancient religious texts that describe the creation of life by a deity, conclude from this failure that the generation of self-reproducing chemical systems from naturally occuring chemicals is impossible.  Most scientists argue that the failure of laboratory experiments so far does not mean that ... over vast range of conditions and millions of years ... that it did not succeed on the early Earth.  However, the expression "Absence of evidence does not imply evidence of absence" applies to such situation.  

While the basic idea of Miller-Urey-like experiments is foundational, the details of these experiments were subsequently criticized for using gas atmospheres that are unlikely to be representative of the early Earth's atmospheres.  Even more recently, there has been renewed debate about the early Earth's atmosphere, so this laboratory work is far from conclusive.  Further complicating matters, recent advances in gene sequencing has tried to identify a last universal common ancestor (LUCA).    While we don't have a definitive LUCA, several lines of evidence point towards genomes most similar to organisms currently living deep in the ocean near hydrothermal vents.  If life on Earth originated in such an enviroment, then the Miller-Urey experiments are still interesting scientifically, but may be totally unrelated to the origin of life on Earth.

In summary, the origin of life on Earth remains incompletely explained.  The ingredients of simple organic molecules are widespread in the galaxy, and are now being studied in protoplanetary disks where planets form (using the new ALMA telescope in Chile).  Organic molecules like amino acids were definitely present in our Sun's protoplanetary disk, as evidenced by the rich organic chemicals found in carbonaceous chondrites, certain rare meteorites from the Asteroid Belt that have landed on Earth (sec 1.5.3 and Table 1.5).  But we don't know how the first self-reproducing molecular system emerged.   But once the first RNA-type self-reproducing system did appear, then the development of a wide variety of living organisms comparatively easy to explain based on natural selection.  We treat the evolution of life on Earth in the next class.

node.title: The Evolution of Life
node.body:
Important stages of evolution of life on Earth

  • Development of the first self-reproducing molecular systems, potentially based on RNA or another self-catalyzing information-carrying molecule.  A model of RNA world is outlined in sec 1.8.1.  
  • Development from a variety of primitive bacteria now seen in marshes, hot springs, caves and deep ocean vents. Probably ~3.8 Gyr ago.  Below are photos of ancient forms of life before photosynthesis arose that exist today around deep ocean vents (Fig 1.36) and in boiling hot springs in volcanic zones (Fig 2.27).
  • Development of photosynthetic bacteria and algae (e.g. cyanobacteria which may have made the stramatolites) producing the oxygen-rich atmosphere.  3.0-2.5 GYr ago
  • Development of a more complex biochemical system seen in most cells today (eukaryotes, mitochondria). 1.2 Gyr ago
  • Development of simple animals (Precambrian era, 0.6 Gyr ago) including fishes (0.4 Gyr ago), insects & dinosaurs (0.25 Gyr ago), mammals (0.065 Gyr ago), primates (0.005 Gyr ago), hominids (~0.003 Gyr ago) and the hypothetical most-recent common human ancestors to all humans today (~0.0002 Gyr ago).

Most species that have lived on Earth are now extinct (see Tree of life for many examples). The processes of the evolution of life, proposed in the 19th century by Charles Darwin, are well-established. In particular, recent projects to determine the sequence of the DNA genetic codes of different organisms shows without doubt that all life forms on Earth, including humans, are related to each other.  

Tree of LIfe

While there is no single classification system of living organisms that all biologists accept, most modern systems are roughly similar.  First prokaryotes originated ~3.8 GYr ago during Archean eon (3.9-2.5 GYr).  There were two types:

  • Archaebacteria  Developed in early atmosphere rich in CO2  and NH3. Present today as extremophiles of several types: some live in very hot water (thermophiles), acids or salty water that metabolize methane or sulfur.  Some are found in hot springs (e.g. Yellowstone National Park), dark caves, deep-sea vent environments, etc.  Some live within cracks of rocks or in ice. 
  • Eubacteria  Had early type of anerobic (no oxygen) photosynthesis. Spread over huge mats on seas, producing calcium-rich stromatolite fossils. After 3.0-2.5 GYr, some developed modern oxygen-producing photosynthesis; e.g. contemporary cyanobacteria.  Oxygen slowly accumulates in the atmosphere over the next 1-2 GYr.   Some symbiotically entered the early eukaryotic cells as chloroplasts (~1.0 GYr ago), giving rise to modern photosynthetic protists and plants.  Other eubacteria developed aerobic respiration and entered.
  • Eukaryotes as mitochondria (~1.2 GYr ago).  Eukaryotes, which have more complex cell structure with nuclei and other specialized organelles, started appearing ~0.9 GYr ago, and are divided into three kingdoms: plants, fungi and animals.

Historically, life forms were classified by their appearance, structure, life cycle, etc.  These schemes have been superceded by molecular evolutionary genetics, where similarities in DNA, RNA, etc. are quantitatively measured.  A major result is the recognition of the Archaea kingdom of primitive bacteria may be the oldest form of life.  Our text gives a Tree of Life, a `phylogenic tree', in Fig. 1.37.  Here is another simple version:

Check out the interactive Tree of Life.  Click on the "Tree of Life" tab at top to see one well-respected phylogenic tree based on DNA sequence studies.  Expand to read the species names.  Humans (Homo sapiens) are near the top in the pink area, with its near-neighbors the chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes), mouse (Mus musculus), rat (Rattus norvegicus) and chicken (Gallus gallus).  The house fly (Drosophilia melanogaster) is nearby.  But nearly the entire rest of the tree consists of micro-organisms; you may recognize some of their names (streptococcus, E. coli, salmonella, etc).  The portion in green shows the most ancient organisms (Archaea) which include extremophiles: organisms that live on methane or sulfur molecules, endure high salt or temperatures, and so forth.  

The oldest known fossilized organism (3.9 GYr ago)  resemble cyanobacteria which are still common today (e.g. the scum in your kitchen drain may be cyanobacteria).  Past cyanobacteria are likely responsible for some oil deposits.  Fossil microorganisms are identified by their microscopic morphology (ofter filamentary or globular), their organic carbon content (the original DNA,  etc. is long gone),  and particularly the high isotopic ratio of 13C/12C characteristics of photosynthetic processes (sec 2.4.5).  Their ages are determined by radioactive dating of the rock formations where they are found.

Processes of evolution

The basic concepts of evolution of populations were developed by Charles Darwin during the 1800s (Box 1.1), but have been refined by population & genetic studies during the past half century following the discovery of DNA/RNA.  An individual's genetic composition is determined by processes such as:  fertilization which combines genetic information from two parents; crossing over and other shuffling of chromosomal information during cell reproduction; and mutation where a small-scale genetic change is inherited by offspring.  A population's gene pool is further affected by: natural selection where different genetic manifestations have different influences on individuals'  survival in different environments, and genetic drift as populations change.  Diverse life forms arise as populations adapt to varying conditions. Extinctions occur when all individuals of a species die out; this may occur gradually or in discrete events triggered by external forces (asteroid impacts, rapid climatic change, volcanism, continental drift). Most species of life that have existed on Earth (~millions) are now extinct.  However, throughout evolution, the basic biochemical basis of inheritance (DNA <--> RNA <--> proteins, metabolism using ADP/ATP, etc.) has remained largely unchanged.

Example of Evolution:  Origin and Diversification of Birds on Isolated Islands

Charles Darwin, the originator of modern theory of evolution, derived many of his ideas by studying the variety of animals on the isolated Galapagos Islands off the Pacific coast of South America. His analysis was based mainly on the easily seen characteristics like the structure of bird beaks.  Darwin did not know the underlying mechanisms for genetic transmission and diversification; this did not emerge until the 1950's when James Watson and Francis Crick used X-ray crystallography taken by Rosalind Franklin to unravel the structure and genetic code of DNA molecules.  

 

Today, Darwin's basic idea has been superbly validated by studied of the genetic code.  Above are results from a 2011 statistical analysis of sequences of >20,000 DNA nucleic acid bases for Hawaiian birds (bottom) compared to common birds on large continents (middle and top).  The left-hand  `phylogenic tree' is based on mitochondrial DNA while the (very similar) right-hand tree is based on nuclear DNA.  The Hawaiian birds are found to be closely related to Asian finches, and only distantly related to other birds like the sparrow.  Combining mutation rates with other data, the biologists can trace the progression of the Asian finches from the western Hawaiian islands (~5 million years ago) to the eastern Big Island (<1 million years ago).  See a news report on these findings.  

Life of Earth is incredibly rich and complex: there have been millions of species adapting to an incredible range of conditions.   A few of these species have astonishing intelligence, including us humans.  Yet all organisms share the same biochemical machinery (DNA, proteins, cells, etc.) and have closely intertwined genetic codes.  Despite the diversity of species, life on Earth is cohesive ... we, our puppy, the tree, the fruit fly and nasty bacteria are all cousins.

node.title: Life and Earth's Atmosphere
node.body:
Here we tell a remarkable story.  From an astronomical perspective, Earth has the wrong atmosphere! Where does its oxygen come from? What happened to its carbon dioxide? What role did life play in changing the atmosphere billions of years ago ... and what role is it playing today?  This topic is perhaps the only time when our "Life in the Universe" studies address issues of great concern to public welfare.

    

Let us compare the three principal terrestrial planets: Venus, Earth, and Mars.  Each has a layer of volatile gases, liquids or solids on their solid surface. This is called the atmosphere of the planet. If the solar nebula theory for the origin of the solar system is right, then the atmospheres should have basically the same composition since they formed from the same protoplanetary disk material. But they don't!

    Venus: 96% CO2, 3% N2, 1% H 2SO4 
    Earth: 0.02-0.7% CO2 (range over past 0.5 GYr), 78% N2, 21% O2, + lots of liquid/ice H2O 
    Mars: 96% CO2, 3% N2, 1% Argon + lots of ice CO2 & H2O
    Ices/gases in outer solar system and interstellar medium: H2, He, CO, CH4, NH3 and H2O.

Glossary of Chemicals

  • CO2 = carbon dioxide
  • N2 = nitrogen
  • H2SO4 = sulfuric acid
  • O2 = oxygen
  • H2 = hydrogen
  • He = helium
  • CaCO3 = calcium carbonate
  • H2CO = carbonic acid, C6H12O 6 = sugar
  • NH3 = ammonia, CH4 = methane
  • H 2O = water, O3 = ozone

Planetary astronomers have developed a complicated scenario to explain why the planet atmospheres differ so much from the original solar nebula material.

Phase I: Planets form by gravitational collapse in protoplanetary disk around young Sun, 4.5 billion years ago.  The H and He gas that dominates the disk gas rapidly escapes (evaporates) from the inner planets due to their weak gravity and high temperatures. Only Jupiter and Saturn are massive enough, and cold enough, to retain the light hydrogen and helium atoms. Heavier molecules with oxygen, nitrogen and/or carbon can be retained by Venus/Earth/Mars. The smallest bodies like Mercury/Moon/asteroids cannot retain any gaseous atmosphere.

Phase II: CO2, H2O, NH3 are released from the molten interiors of the planets by outgassing, including volcanism, geysers, and hydrothermal vents. Water can also be deposited on the surface by collisions with comets and asteroids. (There is still significant debate among scientists on the relative contribution of outgassing and comets or asteroids to Earth's ocean water.)

  • On all three planets, NH3 is split by the Sun's ultraviolet light, the H atoms escape and the N atoms form N2 gas which we now see in all three planetary atmospheres.
  • On hot Venus, H2O is a gas (steam) and is destroyed by solar UV light like NH3. On moderate-temperature Earth, H2O is a liquid (water) or solid (ice) and collects into oceans and polar ice caps. On cold Mars, H2O is entirely solid and resides in polar ice caps (and possibly permafrost below the surface) 

  • On Venus and Mars, the CO2 is unchanged and remains the dominant gas constituent of the atmosphere. But on Earth the CO2 gradually dissolves in the liquid water oceans (CO2 + H2O ---> H2CO) where it combines with other molecules to form solid minerals (e.g. CaCO3, limestone). These reactions proceed both by inorganic chemical reactions and by living organisms (e.g. diatoms and mollusk shells in shallow seas form thick layers of limestome). The atmospheric CO2 thus enters into the Earth's crust, where it is gradually is pushed into the Earth’s mantle in subduction zones by plate tectonics. Thus Earth alone has seen most of its CO2 transported from its atmosphere into its interior.
  • On Mars, much of the atmosphere is eroded by the solar wind. Some of this is simply due to the weaker gravity due to its lower mass.  Some of the atmospheric loss is likely due to the lack of a protective magnetic field (today).  It's thought that Mars once had a liquid core to generate a magnetic field, but since Mars was smaller, it cooled more rapidly and lost its magnetic field.  Some combination of those factors (and perhaps others) has resuled in a modern Mars with a very thin atmosphere.

Phase III (only on Earth): Living organisms produce O2 on Earth. Free oxygen is difficult to form by inorganic chemistry and is very reactive with other molecules. But it is released in large quantities by green plants which undergo photosynthesis :

6 CO2 + 6 H2O + solar light    --->    C6H12O6 + 6 O 2

Thus green plants have altered physical conditions on Earth in a very significant way, consuming the CO2 and releasing abundant O2 in our atmosphere.  As a result, nearly all of the Earth's CO2 has been depleted, and it constitutes only <0.1% of the atmosphere today.  Note that some living organisms benefit from this atmospheric change:  metabolic animals like humans breathe the oxygen, and eat the sugars and other organic molecules formed by green plants, drink the water from the atmosphere, and release some CO2 back to the atmosphere.

Phase IV (only on Earth):  During the past ~300 years, human industrial society has been releasing CO2 into the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels: coal, oil and methane (natural gas). These fuels are the buried remains of photosynthetic plants which lived 107-8 years ago. This rapid resupply of CO2 has increased the atmosphere's CO2 from 0.028% to 0.041% today and it is projected to grow substantially in the 21st century and beyond. 

  


The Greenhouse Effect

All molecules have quantized rotational and vibrational transitions. The molecule CO 2 happens to have the following quantum properties: it is transparent to visible light (i.e. most of the Sun's T~6000 K blackbody light) but strongly absorbs infrared light (i.e. most of a planet's T~300 K blackbody light). So CO2 in a planet's atmosphere acts as a blanket keeping heat in. This `greenhouse effect' is strongest on Venus, which has an extremely hot surface due to its dense CO2 atmosphere.  But it is also present on Earth and Mars.  On Mars, increased CO2 from Olympus Mons and the other 3 volcanoes ~2-3 billion years ago probably led to the warming that produced the rivers and seas which are now cold and dry.  On Earth, roughly 90% of the infrared radiation from the Earth's surface is absorbed by the atmosphere.  It is eventually re-radiated out to space, but is causes a substantial warming of the surface by trapping the radiation so efficiently.  

Question: Will the rise in Earth's CO2 due to human industrial activity cause a global warming of the Earth's surface?

This is one of the most important scientific questions of our time. There is now a broad consensus among climate scientists that global temperatures are indeed rising since the late 20th century, and that this is due to the rapid reintroduction of CO2 by fossil fuel burning.  Due to the long residence time of in the atmosphere before it is absorbed into the oceans (~1000 years), the CO2 concentration is projected to continue to rise into the foreseeable future.  The increases are likely to be even greater due to increasing or even accelerating CO2 production as more societies "moderize" and use more fossil fuels per capita.  Up-to-date information on climate issues can be found at the latest (2014) reports of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change; see the synthesis report where the figures here were obtained.  Penn State's Professor Richard Alley, and several other Penn State faculty, are principal authors of the IPCC report.  

The figure below shows the rise in CO2 production over the past ~250 years due to modern industrial society. 

The panels below present the manifestations of the resulting increased greenhouse effect and global warming: the temperature of the atmosphere at the Earth's surface (both global and regional), the melting of ices at the poles (similar melting of glaciers is seen in mountain ranges and Greenland), and the rise of the average sea level.  The relationships between greenhouse gases rise and global warming is complicated; for instance, the warmer oceans evaporate faster, leading to more clouds where are generally reflect sunlight back into space, which cools the Earth.  But the total effect is a net heating of 1-2 watts per square meter, and industrial human processes dominate the heating.  The total sunlight energy is 1400 W/m2, and the net heating is 1-2 W/m2, roughly 0.1% of the Sun's energy on the Earth.  

An increase of ~0.1% of the total, does not seem very big.  However, and unfortunately, both measured evidence and detailed calculations indicate that this small heating has rather considerable effects on things we care about, such as the sea level, agricultural zones, storms, fresh water and deserts.  And the effects in the near future ... in your lifetimes during the 21st century ... are predicted to be strong.  The figures below show global and regional changes expected up to 2100 for two models: one (RCP6.0) where the world's greenhouse emission is sharply curtailed, and another (RCP8.5) where it continues to grow without check.    For the latter model, the average warming is 4 degrees C (7 degrees F) but the effect is not evenly distributed across the globe. The strongest heating is in the Arctic region, and there is great concern that the melting of permafrost in the tundra of Siberia and Canada may release yet more greenhouse gases, particularly methane.  

  

Making predictions about the future of a complex system like the Earth is always difficult.  Nevertheless, it is important that scientists provide society and policy makers with their best assessments based on the data and models avaliable. Some of the potential consequences are so severe, that they could have significant implications for society at large and particularly people living in areas likely to be affected by flooding or extreme weather.  Examples of some potential consequences that have been predicted include:

  • Sea levels are projected to rise 0.4-0.9 meters over the next century, due to thermal expansion of the oceans and partial melting of the polar ice caps.  On longer timescales, the Greenland ice sheet may melt entirely, leading to 7-meter rise in sea levels.  Coastal cities (NYC, Philadelphia, Washington D.C., Los Angeles, New Orleans in US; Shanghai, Tokyo, Calcutta, etc) and low-lying areas (nearly all of Florida, Netherlands, Bangladesh, etc) would be flooded. 
  • Glaciers continue to shrink, winter snows reduce, and Arctic ice disappears in summer.  These beginnings of these effects can be dramatically seen through time lapse photography, such as the Extreme Ice Project. 
  • Weather extremes (droughts, floods, hot spells) are projected to increase. Hurricanes become stronger because warmer air stores more energy and moisture.  Regional weather patterns, such as rainfall, will change.  There may be some advanages (e.g., opening of a Northwestet package through the Artic Ocean), but there will also likely be some people who are affected adversely.  
  • Agricultural zones are projected to shift towards poles. Tropical diseases such as malaria and cholera are projected to expand to new areas.  Extinctions of plant/animal species as habitats warm (already happening with coral reefs and other fragile environments).  
  • Oceans currents may change.  There is worry that the Gulf Stream which warms Europes may reverse.  This has happened in the past (long before people were around to farm) and could be devestating to agricultural economies and perhaps the global food supply.
The effects of global warming are particularly evident in the rapid reduction of ice coverage at the Earth's polar and high mountain ragions. See short videos of the 10-year recession of a glacier near Juneau Alaska  here and warming at Glacier National Park in Montana here. Short videos of Arctic Ice are here and here. The Antarctic ice has been less affected, but its outer regions are recently decreasing (see here. On the timescale of one or more centuries, it is possible -- but still not well-established -- that all of the polar ice will melt. If this occurs, flooding of coastal cities around the world is likely, as shown in the video here.)

We thus see that the atmospheres of planets can change greatly, both from physical processes (such as the loss of water from Venus) and from biological processes (such as the increase of oxygen from green plants).

Modern human society is now increasing greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and, even though the quantities seem very small, it has increased the Earth's temperature perceptibly in recent decades.  Ice is melting, ocean levels are rising, deserts are increasing.  Climate scientists agree that the Earth's temperature will significantly more during the next centuries.  Human society will make difficult choices about how to deal with the associated challenges.
