node.title: The Terrestrial Planets
node.body:
Earth and Mars orbit the Sun within the `Habitable Zone' where liquid water can potentially be present on the surface, depending on the atmospheric pressure and composition (and the presence of sufficient water). We therefore focus on the properties of these two planets and review the properties of Venus and Mercury only to contrast the conditions for planets too close to their star to be habitable.  

Earth

Rotating sphere with oceans of liquid H2O and brown rocky continents, covered with a thin gaseous atmosphere with swirling clouds of H2O clouds. Polar caps of frozen H2O. Continents show mountain ranges, volcanos, rivers and occasional impact craters. Below are two typical views of Earth, one from space and ther other from the surface.  See some beautiful images of Earth at NASA's Visible Earth (esp. the Blue Marble project).

      

But if one looks under the oceans, another remarkable pattern of mid-oceanic ridges and ocean trenches are seen!  Watch a beautiful 2-minute video of the slowly spinning Earth here. 

 

Earth's interior is still mostly molten from its formation 4.5 billion years ago. The solid crust of light silicates is very thin: only 5-50 km (vs. total radius of 6400 km). Under the thin crust is a thick mantle of melted silicates, a liquid outer core, and an inner core of solid iron/nickel.

Earth's surface features are explained by plate tectonics. First introduced by Alfred Wegener in the 1930s and largely disparaged at the time, it is now completely confirmed by GPS and radio astronomical measurements of continental motions. The Earth's surface is broken into ~20 crustal plates, which are moved in different directions by convection currents in the mantle. New crust forms by uplift and spreading of mantle material at mid-oceanic ridges, with the newest rock along the ridge line. Old crust is either subducted into the mantle along a trench, or is crumpled upward into mountain ranges (e.g. the Himalaya Mountains being produced today as the Indian plate crashes into the Asian plate). Plate motions and subduction are violent processes and produce volcanoes, mountain ranges and earthquakes along plate boundaries.

Typical plate motions are 1-5 cm per year, roughly the rate at which fingernails grow, amounting to roughly 103 kilometers every 108 years. The diagrams below are two representations of convection from the mantle and its effects on the surface tectonic plates. 

Earth's active plate tectonics serve a key role in the "carbon cycle" that helps maintain the carbon dioxide concentration of Earth's atmosphere. 

Earth's crustal motions today:

  • Atlantic Ocean is widening, separating South America from Africa and North America from Europe.  North American & Europe have collided repeatedly in the past. The Appalachian Mountains around us now are from 2 collisions ago --  its counterparts on the other side are the Scottish highlands and Atlas Mountains in Morocco. 
  • Australia and India are pushing into Asia. India's collision with Asia continues to raise the Himalaya Mountains.
  • A sliver of western California is on the Pacific plate, which is sliding northward past the North American Plate, i.e., Los Angeles is moving towards San Francisco. This produces earthquakes (e.g. along the San Andreas fault in California) and volcanos (e.g. Mt. St. Helens in Washington State).

Since the Earth is 4.5 x 109 years old, the continents have collided and rearranged their configurations dozens of times. For example, 200 million years ago, all continents were stuck together into one super-continent, Pangaea. Note that if there were no plate tectonics, volcanism, and mountain building, rain would erode the continents into oceans and there might be no "dry land" on Earth today. 

Earth is unique among the planets in having a relatively large-sized moon - the Moon, which is 1/80 the mass of Earth and orbits at a distance of 55 Earth radii. For this reason the Earth-Moon system is occasionally referred to somewhat humorously as a "binary planet". The most likely way for such a massive and nearby Moon to have been formed is by a cataclysmic collision, towards the end of the formation of the Solar System, between the proto-Earth and another roughly Mars-sized planetesimal. The collision would have ejected a large amount of Earth's crust into orbit, where it could have collected into the spherical body we see today. Key consequences of Earth's large Moon for life on Earth are that it raises large tides in our oceans, and stabilizes the tilt of Earth's axis (which is responsible for the seasons) over very long timescales. Tides in the Earth-Moon system are also slowing down Earth's rotation, and hence, the length of a day: At the time of the dinosaurs, each day was ~23 hours long, and currently the day is lengthening by 2 milliseconds per century. 

Mars

Mars' rotation rate (1/24.6 hours) and axial tilt (25.19 deg) give it a day and seasonal temparature variations. However, Mars is significantly smaller and so has weaker gravity (40% of Earth's) and a much thinner atmosphere (<1% Earth's surface pressure), with a predominantly carbon dioxide (3% nitrogen) composition which offers no evidence of current life. 

Below are three images of Mars. The first visual picture, from a telescope on Earth, shows dark and light patches once thought to be 'canals' built by the Martians themselves, along with a polar ice cap and some light cloud cover. The second visual picture (center) from an orbiting satellite probe shows the Valle Marineris, two large volcanos, streambeds, and craters. The third image shows the four extinct volcanoes in exaggerated relief.  

    

The surface of Mars consists of lots of red-colored dust covering rocks (often a grey-greenish color), plus small polar ice caps of frozen CO2 and H2O. The red color is from oxidized iron-rich minerals (i.e. rust). Some regions are heavily cratered - these are more ancient surfaces that have not changed in billions of years, while other lightly-cratered regions have been renewed more recently by lava (volcanism) or water erosion. The region of the planet imaged by VIking (image in center, and exaggerated model on right) exhibits four huge extinct volcanos and a huge canyon system.  Olympus Mons: largest volcano in the solar system (size of PA and 25 km high). Valles Marineris is the deepest and longest canyon system in the Solar System, as big as the U.S. It may have resulted from the separation of two tectonic plates long ago when the interior of the planet was still molten. 

  

Mars is now mostly cooled to a solid, but had a molten interior for much of its history. For some period (up to ~2 billion years ago?), active volcanism brought molten rock up from the interior. Most remarkably, small features around certain canyons and craters suggest that liquid water once flowed on Mars. Possibly due to a greenhouse effect and global warming from gases ejected by volcanos. Today nearly all the water on the surface is frozen.  Only very recently have scientists found evidence for liquid water briefly being exposed on the surface of Mars (before sublimating or freezing).  Carl Sagan and others suggest that life may have formed on Mars during its wet period. Following are some of the remarkable photos taken by Mars orbiters during the past decades showing the complex surface of the planet.

  
   

Several robots roved Mars during the 2000s, and the `Curiosity' mission is now active.  They all found remarkable small-scale evidence for past lakes and flowing water on the Martian surface.  On the left is a 3cm x 3cm closeup of small `blueberry'-like rocks that must have formed under water.  On the right is an image released a few months ago from NASA's Curiosity mission showing sedimentary clasts, rock again formed under water.   

    

Browse some of the remarkable pictures taken from orbit around Mars using the European Space Agency's Mars Express interactive image browser or images of NASA's Mars Global Surveyor. The Mars Science Laboratory, nicknamed Curiosity, was launched in 2011 and landed on Mars several months later, and is still roving around.  See its recent activities here.  There are lots of fascinating photos here.  More NASA science findings about Mars appear here.

The interior of Mars is mostly solid, unlike Earth's interior that is molten. This is because Mars is smaller and less massive (about 1/10 the mass of Earth) and hence has cooled faster since its formation 4.5 billion years ago. (Mercury and the Moon are even smaller and have entirely cooled.)  Earth's surface is very young, constantly remade by erosion (rain, rivers), volcanic lava flows, and plate tectonics. Mars's surface is partly old with many impact craters, and partly newer with lava flows and water erosion. The surfaces of planets thus reflect conditions in the planetary interiors.

node.title: Jovian Planets and Moons
node.body:
The Jovian planets - Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune - probably have cores (suspected to be liquid metal for Jupiter and Saturn, but primarily ice for Uranus and Neptune), but are "mostly atmospheres," comprised of dense gas. Below are photographs of the planets by robotic probes, and an artist's diagram of their interiors. The Jovian interiors are composed primarily of H2 and He, with important amounts of methane (CH4), water (H2O), ammonia (NH3) and related molecules. The Jovian planets thus reflect better the original material than the terrestrial planets where most of the gases have escaped. 

Given the extremely high pressures at the interface with any surface, it seems unlikely that the Jovian planets harbor living organisms. We will therefore review them briefly and concentrate instead on their moons which seem more likely sites for life.  

     

Jupiter has more mass than all of the other planets put together, and is only about 1/10 the mass it would need to initiate deuterium fusion reactions in its core (the "easiest" type of fusion for a star). Thanks to its mass and 10-year orbit, Jupiter would likely be the first planet discovered by an alien civilization searching for planets around our Sun using techniques like those we use today (as we will discuss in the final unit of the course). Jupiter shines more brightly in the night sky than any star, and is outshined only by the Moon and Venus. Its strong magnetic field causes occasional bright radio flares brighter than any other radio phenomenon in the Solar System apart from the Sun. Its atmosphere exhibits bands caused by high-altitude winds and gargantuan hurricane-like stoms, including the famous "Red Spot" storm, which is roughly the size of ten Earths and has persisted in its atmosphere for more than three centuries. Jupiter has four large moons, discovered by Galileo, that rival Mercury in size and some of which may offer suitable habitats for life, as we discuss below and will explore further in the weeks ahead. 

Saturn is a less massive, more distant version of Jupiter exhibiting similar visual colors, including banded high-velocity clouds and storms, and having a similar atmospheric composition. Its appearance in telescopes is the most dramatic of all the planets, thanks to its giant ring system, likely the disrupted remains of a moon that wandered too close to the planet in the relatively recent past (<1 Ga ago) and was torn apart by Saturn's tidal forces. Saturn has a single massive moon, Titan, roughly the size of Mercury, the only planetary satellite in the Solar System to have a substantial atmosphere and weather. Titan is another possible habitat for life which we will explore in more detail in the weeks ahead. Saturn, easily observed with the naked eye, is the most distant (slowest moving) of the planets known to ancient astronomers. 

Uranus and Neptune have been called the "ice giants" because they exist in the cold outer reaches of the Solar System and exhibit atmospheres with significant ice content and a different mix of gases than Jupiter and Saturn, giving them their blue-green (or if you prefer, cyan) appearance in visual-light images. Both are too faint to be seen with the naked eye (with ocassional exceptions for Uranus), and were not discovered until after telescopes were in widespread astronomical use. Uranus is noted for the unusual 97 degree tilt of its rotational axis, which means it effectively rolls around the Solar System on its side instead of spinning like a top as the other planets do (Venus can be considered to be upside down, and spins slowly, which is also unusual). Neptune has a single massive moon, Triton, which orbits in the "wrong" (retrograde) direction and so is thought to be a captured Kuiper Belt object. Triton's properties, including its very tenuous nitrogen atmosphere, are very similar to those of Pluto and other massive Kuiper Belt objects, and with current understanding it is too cold and too far from the Sun to possibly support life. 

Our current picture of the interiors of these gas giants is shown in the figure below. 

Moons of Jupiter 

Jupiter has four large inner moons discovered by Galileo: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto. The pictures here are from the Galileo robot probe launched by NASA that orbited Jupiter and photographed its moons from 1995-2003.

Io is closest to Jupiter and, subjected to enormous tidal forces of the giant planet, should have its spin locked to its orbital period like our Moon's spin is locked to its orbit, with the same side always facing its planet. But the pull of the next moon out, Europa, disturbs Io's orbit, with the result that Io is constantly being "massaged" by Jupiter's tidal forces, which heat and melt its icy and rocky interior. As a result, Io is the most volcanically active body in the Solar System (below). With many constantly erupting volcanos, its surface covered with recent lava flows, and its complete lack of any atmosphere, Io's surface and interior are probably too harsh and unstable for life.  

Europa (below, left) has an icy surface with long dark cracks and no craters. These surfaces show evidence of having been repeatedly melted and refrozen. Models of this phenomenon suggest there is a large ocean beneath a thick icy crust that may contain more liquid water than exists in all the oceans of Earth. As with Io, tidal forces of Jupiter likely provide sufficient heat to keep this water from freezing. The evidence for existence of these oceans, their likely properties, and their potential for harboring life will be a focus for us in the weeks ahead. 

Ganymede (below, right) and Callisto exhibit relatively young surfaces that, again, suggest the presence of large quantities of liquid water - or, at the very least, "slush" - below the surface of both moons, again because of Jupiter's tidal influence, combined with the tidal forces of the other inner moons. We will discuss prospects for life on these moons as well. 

  

Moons of Saturn 

Saturn's moons, discovered by Christian Huygens in the 1600s, are now being investigated by the Cassini probe which arrived there in 2005.  There are dozens of moons, most with ancient icy surfaces covered in craters. Some have large cracks suggesting heating and expansion from large collisions. Saturn's largest moon is Titan, the only moon with a substantial atmosphere and observed weather patterns. The surface features are invisible due to clouds (below, left), and models suggest that Titan may have liquid N2 (nitrogen), CH4 (methane),  or C2H6 (ethane) oceans.

See an excellent video of Huyghens probe's descent onto Titan and an artist's view of Titan's interior.

Cassini dropped a research probe named Huygens (built by the European Space Agency) onto Titan in 2005. It took some remarkable photos during its descent (below, center) and after landing on the surface (below, right) - the only visible light photos we have of the surface of this alien world. The last photo shows stream-beds kilometers in length and surface material with a mix of light and dark colors. It is much too cold for liquid water; the liquid seen flowing on Titan's surface (center) is likely to be methane or ethane. 

  

Saturn's moon Enceladus is another example of an icy moon like the Galilean satellites of Jupiter. The existence of liquid water under its surface has been confirmed by the Cassini mission's observations of jets of water vapor erupting from its surface. We will discuss Enceladus along with Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto in a couple of weeks. 

Moons of Uranus and Neptune

Uranus and Neptune have a number of prominent moons, most with ancient, heavily cratered icy surfaces. Uranus' moon Miranda (below, left) is remarkable: it looks like different terrains have been pieced together. Giant cliff separates two regions. Perhaps Miranda was shattered into pieces by collision with an asteroid/planetisimal, and reformed itself.  Triton (below, right) is the largest of Neptune's moons and has very strange charateristics: it orbits in the wrong direction, and its surface has two different terrains (smooth melted material, and rough colored material). The moon is extremely cold and the surface is mainly nitrogen ice (N2, bluish)  on one side and methane ice (CH4, pinkish) on the other. It appears to have (active?) volcanos (erupting nitrogen? water? soot?).  Triton is the only large moon with a retrograde orbit, so it may have melted during its capture by Neptune long ago. But the surface has very few craters, so it must have been altered many times since the original capture.

node.title: Minor Bodies: Asteroids, Comets, Kuiper Belt Objects
node.body:
Asteroids

Asteroids and comets are small rocky and icy bodies left over from the Sun's protoplanetary disk. The term "asteroid" is used to refer to billions of small rocky bodies of a vast range of sizs that orbit the Sun. Most of them are in roughly circular orbits in the Asteroid Belt between Mars & Jupiter. It is likely that gravitational perturbations of Jupiter and, to a much lesser extent, Mars prevented the formation of a bona fide planet at this orbit in the Solar System. Some asteroids have unusual orbits, such as the Trojan Asteroids that are found tracking Jupiter's orbit in two "clouds" centered 60 degrees ahead of and behind the giant planet.  The figure below shows asteroids with known orbits ... this is not an artist's painting, but a plot of the real locations of the larger & brighter bodies in the Asteroid Belt.  

A relatively small number of asteroids have had their orbits altered by Jupiter's gravity and can approach Earth. Meteors (also called 'shooting stars', though they have nothing to do with stars!) are fragments of asteroids or comet material which burn up in Earth's atmosphere, making a brief streak in the sky. Meteorites are the pieces that don't burn up and land on Earth where they can be collected and studied in detail. Meteorites landing in most places are hard to distinguish from regular Earth rocks, so most meteorites are found in deserts or on the polar ice caps (e.g., Greenland or Antarctica).  

In recent years, a few asteroids have  been photographed by robotic probes during close fly-bys: Eros, Ida and its tiny 'moon' Dactyl, Mathilde, and most recently Vesta. The fly-bys have revealed that the surfaces of these asteroids are rocky (silicate) with craters from impacts by other asteroids. In 2001, the robotic NEAR probe crashed into Eros, taking closeup photos on the way in. Mathilde is darker and less dense; it may be a less well-bound, loose 'rubble pile' containing mostly sooty carbonaceous material.  

   

Take a look at the remarkable movies of Eros spinning as it orbits the Sun here.  These movies cover only a few hours; imagine how Eros has been spinning like this for 4.5 billion years.

Asteroids occasionally come close to planets and collide with them. Asteroid collisions of sufficient size will produce impact craters. The Moon and Mercury show many such craters, showing that our Solar System is a hazardous environment; most of the craters on Earth, Venus, and Mars have been erased over time by volcanism and erosion. Below left is a relatively new crater on Earth that you can visit in Arizona. Below right is an older, heavily eroded,  crater in Canada from 200 Myr ago.  A huge crater from a ~10 km-size asteroid that impacted 65 million years ago was identified under water, off the coast of Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. Some combination of the tidal waves (tsunamis), atmospheric debris, hemisphere-spanning forest fires, and Sun-obscuring dust and soot that followed this impact probably killed most land-based life on Earth, leading to the extinction of the dinosaurs and many other species that marks the Cretaceous-Tertiary ("K-T") boundary in the geological record. It is suspected that asteroid or comet impacts were also responsible for some of the other mass extinctions in Earth's past. Astronomical efforts are under way to discover and map out the orbits of all large asteroids with orbits that could allow them to hit Earth, so that we will have enough warning to organize evacuations (for small objects) or deflect the asteroid's orbit (for large objects). Deflecting the orbit of a large asteroid would require a dedicated space mission and years of advance warning to be successful. Luckily, the chances are low that an impact large enough to have an impact on a global scale will occur in the next ~thousand years.  

  

Meteorites, which are pieces of asteroids landing on Earth, can be studied in the laboratory in great detail to tell us about ancient planetisimals. Their properties are surprisingly diverse and complex. Most seem to be made of rock similar to Earth and Moon, but much of the rock is in small melted spheres called chondrules.  Some are iron-rich and must have been formed inside melted ('differentiated') planetisimals. Others are definitely unmelted; they still have grains inherited from the Galactic material from which the solar system formed long ago.  Below left is an ordinary chondritic meteorite.  Below right is a piece of the Murchison meteorite, a rare type of carbonaceous chondrite where amino acids and other organic molecules have been found.  

    

Comets

Comets, like asteroids, are debris left over from the solar nebula and the formation of the Solar System. While asteroids are rocky bodies found (for the most part) in the Asteroid Belt between Mars and Jupiter, comets are mainly icy bodies that are found (for the most part) in the outer reaches of the Solar System in the Kuiper Belt, beginning just beyond the orbit of Neptune, and in the spherical Oort Cloud, far beyond at 50,000 AU, which effectively defines the edge of the Solar System. Most cometary bodies never come into the inner Solar System. Occasionally, however, a comet's orbit is altered by some gravitational encounter and it zooms towards the Sun. Its orbit typically has an eccentricity of e=99%, a semi-major axis of a=50,000 AU, and an orbital period of P~106 years. A few comets that enter the inner reaches of the Solar System in this way are redirected into shorter orbits and become "periodic" comets; the most famous of these is Halley's Comet with an orbital period P=76 years. Below are some photos from the last passage of Comet Halley near Earth in 1986. We now have close-up images of several comets from robotic probes: they are irregularly shaped, loosly packed bodies of water ice, rocks, and dust. 

Spend some time learning about the Deep Impact mission to Comet Tempel 1 in 2005 here.  NASA sent a spacecraft to approach a comet as it was approaching the Sun, and ejected a metal probe to slam into the surface, releasing ice and rocky particles that were then studied by telescopes on or near Earth.  Take a look at the `Night of the Comet' interactive feature, as well as the approach and departure videos (`Journey to a Comet' and `Tempel Fades into the Night').  You may be interested in reading `Genesis of a Comet' to link the findings to the protoplanetary disk where planets form.  

In summer 2011, NASA's Dawn spacecraft visited Vesta, one of the largest asteroids in the Asteroid Belt.  See video overviews of this mission here.

Amazingly, astronomers witnessed the collision of a comet with Jupiter in 1994! The comet was broken into fragments by Jupiter's gravitational tidal forces on its first close passage by the planet in July 1992 and impacted the planet on its next orbit over July 16 to 22, 1994. These impacts resulted in huge disruptions to the atmosphere of Jupiter which were observed from Earth-based observatories, the Hubble Space Telescope, and the Galileo spacecraft, then on its way to Jupter. Here are pictures before and after the collision taken by the Hubble Space Telescope. 
   

Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs)

Recently, astronomers have discovered hundreds of Solar System bodies in orbits beyond Neptune. These are called Trans-Neptunian Objects (TNOs) or Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs, named after astronomer Gerard Kuiper).  We now know that Pluto is thus just one among a huge number of rocky/icy bodies in the outer solar system. In the "zoom out" of the Solar System below, the upper-right panel has the best scale to show the Kuiper Belt (labeled in cyan).  

The Kuiper Belt extends from 30 to 50 AU, with a sharp outer edge that is not well explained by current models. The Kuiper Belt objects are probably primitive objects, largely unchanged since the formation of the Solar System. Those with approximately circular orbits have probably had these orbits since birth, while those with more elliptical orbits - including Pluto - have experienced gravitational interactions wtih Neptune.

Pluto, and several other known Kuiper Belt objects, orbit the Sun twice in the time Neptune orbits it three times; they have a mean orbital radius of ~39 AU (with various individual eccentricities and inclinations) which puts their orbit in "resonance" with Neptune's, making their orbits stable over long timescales. Pluto has three moons (below). In 2006, NASA launched the New Horizons mission to Pluto and hopefully one or two other KBOs. It flew by Pluto and its moons in 2015 and is scheduled to fly by 2014 MU69 near January 1, 2019.  Watch some of the amazing  videos containing images obtained by New Horizons during the Pluto and Charon encounters.

The artist's painting below shows the largest KBOs known so far. Eris is slightly bigger than Pluto, and the others are somewhat smaller. Because Pluto is no longer alone, the international astronomers' society classified all of these Kuiper Belt objects including Pluto as 'dwarf planets' in 2005 - the famous "demotion of Pluto". Sedna, alone among these trans-Neptunian objects, is not a Kuiper Belt object, since its orbit extends out to 937 AU and inward only as far as 76 AU which is beyond the edge of the Kuiper Belt (see the diagram of Sedna's orbit, as a red ellipse, in the lower-right panel of the figure above). Sedna is likely a former Oort Cloud object which has experienced multiple gravitational perturbations leading to its current position.

node.title: Arrangement of Planets in our Solar System
node.body:
Sun, Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Asteroid Belt, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Kuiper Belt Objects (including Pluto and other dwarf planets). Below are real-color images of the terrestrial planets (lwdr) and the Jovian planets (right) to scale.  Note how Earth and Venus are about the same size, while the other terrestrial planets (including Moon) are smaller. Note how the outer planets are far bigger than the inner planets with Jupiter and Saturn the largest. 

  

Visualize planetary orbits with a digital orrery. First take a look at the configuration of the orbits right now.  Then click on the arrow and then slide the green balls to change the speed, zoom and other characteristics of future motions.  Note how the inner planets orbit faster ... this is Kepler's Third Law, P2 = a3 (the square of the orbital period is proportional to the cube of the orbit size).  While the terrestrial planets have few moons (Earth has one large moon, Mars has two small ones captured from the Asteroid Belt), the Jovian planets are orbited by an endless number of small bodies.  See a table of 181 named moons with links to photos and more information at the Windows to the Universe website. 

Venus, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn are easily seen with the naked eye and have been known since antiquity. In the late 1600s, Isaac Newton Laws of Motion and Gravity, combined with the methods of calculus he invented, gave a quantitative understanding of the elliptical orbits and masses of the planets and their moons.  Uranus was discovered with a telescope by amateur German astronomer William Herschel in 1781, later appointed Royal Astronomer of England. Neptune was discovered in 1846 in France based on predictions using Newton's celestial mechanics.  Uranus had a non-elliptical motion due to the pull of a then-unknown planet. The first asteroid in the Asteroid Belt between Mars and Jupiter, Ceres, was discovered by accident in 1801.  Today, tens of thousands of asteroids have known orbits.   Altogether, the discovery of the outer Solar System bodies caused tremendous excitement throughout Europe during the 18-19th centuries, giving confidence both in the improved technology of telescopes, in the theoretical predictions of Newton's "celestial mechanics," and in the rationality of the world around us.

Beyond Neptune are many minor bodies collectively known as Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs), most discovered since the 1990s. The most famous is Pluto, discoveredi in the U.S. in 1930 based on perturbations of Uranus' orbit after long searching. Michael Brown (at Caltech in California) and Devid Jewitt (at the University of Hawaii) have found hundreds of KBOs, and new large surveys are planned to find many more.

node.title: General Considerations
node.body:
Conditions for Life Arising on Planets and Moons

Liquid Oceans or Ponds

A liquid is needed as solvent for speeding up chemical reactions which are slow in gases (and extremely slow in solids). The most promising molecule is water (H2O)  Water has nice advantages: solvent for many materials (that is, many chemicals dissolve in water); wide range of liquid phase (between its freezing temperature 0oC and boiling temperature 100oC); has a polar structure (a property of liquid water that promotes chemical reactions); and its solid phase (ice) floats on its liquid phas (water). But there are other possible solvents where life conceivably might form including ammonia (NH3), methane (CH4) or other hydrocarbons.  

Organic Molecules

These are carbon-based (C) molecules with hydrogen (H), oxygen (O) and nitrogen (N). Terrestrial biological molecules also use small quantities of ~21 other elements: phosphorus (P) in DNA, calcium (Ca) in bones/teeth, iron (Fe) in blood, etc. Living organisms based on non-carbon molecules seems doubtful. For example, silicon (Si) has the same valence as carbon (4 free electrons), but polymers based on silicon tends to be solid crystals (rock) rather than chains and rings.  

Energy

A source of energy to drive chemical reactions is needed. For terrestrial life today, the principal energy source is sunlight that, through photosynthetic plants with chlorophyll, can produce organic molecules like sugars from simple atmospheric molecules like water and carbon dioxide.  But some terrestrial life forms (mostly archaea bacteria or extremophiles) get energy from sulfur, hydrogen or methane in unusual locations such as deep sea vents.  

Life in the Solar System?  

From these general conditions for a habitable planet or moon, we can see why Earth is a great place for life to arise and thrive. Its orbit is perfectly placed in the habitable zone where water is mostly liquid (oceans, lakes, rain).  As we learned last week, the early Earth had lots of carbon in its atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide (CO2) which became available for living organisms.

Sunlight on Earth is bright as a source of energy, but not too strong to destroy complex organic molecules.  Basically, Earth is a great place for life!!

But, based on the conditions above, we can pretty much exclude some locations in the Solar System as habitable environments:  

   

  • The planet Mercury and our Moon are small with gravity too weak to hold on to any gaseous or liquid atmosphere.  There are no organic (C-based) molecules or oceans on Mercury or Moon, just a rocky surface.  

  

  • Venus can also be excluded as a possible site for life because its surface is so hot due to the runaway greenhouse effect from its dense CO2 atmosphere.  All water boiled away billions of years ago, and any organic molecules on Venus would quickly be destroyed by the heat.
  • The Jovian planets—Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune—are unlikely site for the emergence of living organisms because their cores are buried under enormously dense atmospheres of hydrogen or methane.   There are carbon-rich molecules, so it is conceivable that (from gas chemistry rather than water-based liquid chemistry) self-reproducing organisms arose in the swirling Jovian atmospheres, but this seems doubtful.

  

  • Comets, which spend most of their lives far from the Sun beyond the Kuiper Belt, might seem to be inhospitable to life due to the cold temperatures and lack of energy source.  But they do have two important ingredients:  water (comets are mostly made of water ice) and organic molecules.  When it was imaged by spacecraft during its 1986 approach to the Sun, the nucleus of Comet Halley was `black as velvet', probably covered with some carbon material like soot or coal.  While not harboring life forms themselves, comets may have been important in helping life arise on the early Earth.  Many likely impacted Earth, giving it water for its oceans and simple organic molecules for early living organisms.  

  

  • Some asteroids in the Asteroid Belt are also very interesting with respect to life.  The most primitive meteorites which come from a class of asteroids in the Asteroid Belt are called carbonaceous chondrites.  These have rocky chondrules surrounded by a dark carbon-rich matrix similar to coal.  In this matrix, dozens of different amino acids and other organic molecules have been found in trace amounts.  These molecules are "racemic" (equal quantities of right- and left-handed molecules), while amino acids in living organisms on Earth are all left-handed.  This shows they are definitely not due to contamination after they landed on Earth, but were formed in the interstellar medium or the early solar nebula.   As with comets, it is likely that the impacts of many asteroids on the early Earth provided water and organic materials that could be valuable for the origin of life on Earth

It thus seems that, aside from Earth, most of the Solar System seems inhospitable to life.  But, in recent decades, interest by scientists has concentrated on the possibility of life in two specific Solar System environments:  The surface of Mars, and the surface or interiors of some Jovian moons.

We now proceed to investigate these possibilities.

node.title: Jovian Moons
node.body:
Prior to the fly-by missions of the Voyager probes in the 1980s, there was little expectation of liquids needed for life anywhere in the Solar System beyond Mars. The reason is simply temperature: the Sun's light is so faint at these distances that no body's surface can reach the melting temperature of water.  Scientists expected that the moons would either be rocky like the asteroids, or icy with ancient frozen surfaces, showing only craters from many asteroid impacts.  Jupiter's biggest moon, Callisto (shown below), is a good example of this, as well as many smaller Jovian moons.  

It was thus a big surprise when Voyager found several moons with young, active surfaces, showing few impact craters. Understanding these moons was a major motivation for the complex and expensive missions of the 2000s: the NASA's Galileo probe, which orbited within Jupiter's system, and European Space Agency's (ESA's) Cassini mission that is still orbiting within Saturn's system.  Jupiter's innermost moon, Io (not shown here, see LUBS Fig 9.9), nearly entirely melted by tidal stresses, has many active volcanoes that perpetually cover the surface with new material.  

But it was Jupiter's moon Europa (and similarly, Ganymede) that seemed most relevant to the search for life in the Solar System. It has a water ice surface like Callisto, but very few craters.  The surface must have been melted and refrozen.  The strange grooves, rough patches, and multicolored ice suggest that this melting is a recurrent process, not from a single violent event. Study the pictures below.  Dark ice fills some grooves and patches on the surface.  This suggests that the ice covering is not very thick, and liquid (or slushy) water lies below and wells up when the surface cracks.  The rough patches on the surface (chaotic terrain) may be the product of ice plates grinding against each other, similar to mountain-building on Earth due to plate tectonics. 

This requires that Europa have a liquid water layer beneath a relatively thin ice crust.  This is supported by the presence of a weak magnetic field around Europa.  What keeps it above freezing temperature?  Perhaps it is tidal forces (weaker than Io's) due to its slightly elliptical orbit and perturbations by other moons.  Perhaps large impacts episodically melt the interior.  The thickness of the ice crust and the water ocean is quite uncertain; below are two models for Europa's interior.  NASA engineers and scientists have conceptually designed a mission that would land on Europa with a probe that would melt its way through the ice and swim in the hidden ocean.  But this ice-penetrating robot mission has not been approved by NASA or Congress.

  

 

Jupiter's moon Europa is not the only one that appears to have melted interior.  Neptune's moon Triton is bizarre, half covered with an ancient cratered surface and have with a smooth uncratered surface.  Perhaps it collided with another moon and partially melted.  Saturn's moon Enceladus shows some craters, but also has discolorations and grooves.  Here the Cassini probe has photographed geysers (essentially water volcanoes) along a long ridge.  As with Europa, this can be explained only if the surface ice is relatively thin and a (partially) melted layer lies below.  Here are some photos of Enceladus.

  

We finally come to Saturn's moon Titan, the largest in the Solar System.  It was already known from ground-based studies that it is the only moon with its own atmosphere, mostly nitrogen (N2) with some methane (CH4).  The surface cannot be seen in visible light due to the thick clouds, but Cassini has obtained detailed maps of the surface in infrared light and radar reflectance.   

 

The remarkable Cassini mission has a separate probe names Huyghens that was launched into Titan's atmosphere, descending slowly with parachutes, and landing softly.  The results were amazing!  The photos during the descent showed a complicated system of streams flowing into lakes.  The landing was squishy, onto a marshy surface.  The `rocks' on the surface (probably water ice) seemed embedded in a muddy material.  

What is the liquid on Titan?  It is much too cold for liquid water, and the atmosphere does not show water vapor.  The liquid seems to be a hydrocarbon: methane, perhaps combined with ethane (C2H6).  On Earth, this is called LNG, liquified natural gas, and is used as a fuel.  Titan seems to have a full climate with polar methane ice caps, methane clouds and rainstorms, rivers and lakes.  Cassini has traced a seasonal cycle involving warming with lake evaporation, and cooling with expanding ice caps.  Models of Titan's interior suggest that another liquid layer may be present, this time liquid ammonia (NH3). 

  

One can only speculate whether life can arise on Titan's surface where the temperature is around 90o K.  Recent laboratory experiments (similar to the Miller-Urey experiments for early Earth) indicate that amino acids and nucleic acids, critical components of proteins and DNA, could form if the temperature were hotter.  Astronomers note that, in a few billion years, the Sun will become a red giant star, boiling water on Earth but warming Titan to more habitable temperatures.  Altogether, after Earth, Titan seems to have the best chance for life in the Solar System with a solid surface, carbon-rich chemistry, a liquid solvent, and ecological variety.  Last year, NASA approved funds for preliminary study of a Titan Mare Explorer that would splash-land in one of its methane lakes and study its chemistry.      

We thus find that, contrary to any reasonable expectation before detailed study with robotic probes, that some Jovian moons have liquid on (or close to) their surfaces.  Europa and similar moons have water oceans below their ice coverings, and Titan has incredible liquid hydrocarbon lakes on its surface.

It is likely that, in coming decades, humans will send more probes to the moons to study them ... and look for primitive live forms.

node.title: Life on Mars
node.body:
Chapter 3 of our text An Introduction to Astrobiology gives a detailed and very informative treatment of the Martian surface, atmosphere and history from the perspective of the question of whether the planet can -- or could in the past -- harbor living organisms.  The final answer is that, despite intensive effort over decades, there is no evidence for life on Mars, but the possibility of past life is real.   This Web page can be used as a commentary to assist as you read Chapter 3. We will skip text sections 3.4.4, 3.5 and 3.6, and all of the blue-color Boxes.

Historical perspective (Chpt 3.1)


Enthusiasm for the possibility -- even supposed certitude -- that life exists on Mars has persisted for centuries. Below left is a typical image of Mars obtainable from a ground-based telescope.  In the late-1800s, Giovanni Schiaperelli claimed he saw `canali', an Italian word that can mean either canals (implying that they were engineered, rather than arising through weathering) or channels (which can be either man-made or arising through weathering).  'Canali' was translated to "canals" in English, and it just so happened to be during an era when humans were building increasingly impressive canals (shoftly after the completion of the Suez canal and before an early attempt at the Panama canal).   In a series of popular books, Percival Lowell (1895-1908) proclaimed that they represented constructions of an advanced civilization dying of thirst.  In 1898, author and futurist H. G. Wells wrote a popular novel about an invasion of Earth by technologically advanced Martians.  This was recouped in 1938 in a radio drama by Orson Welles that caused widespread panic.  By the late 1920s, it was well established that the surface of Mars was dry. Yet, some speculation remained, and it was not until NASA's robotic flybys (1960s) and landers (Viking missions, 1970s) that is was completely established that no large forms of life is present on Mars;  thousands of pictures have been returned from the Martian surface, and no Martian animals, plants, footprints or other indications of large life forms is seen.  The controversy today is whether there might be microbial life, or perhaps fossils of past life from an era when the climate was warmer and liquid water was prevalent.

  

Martian geography (Chpt 3.1.1)

Surprisingly, the most prominent feature of the Martian surface is actually not well-understood: the dramatic difference in cratering between the southern and northern hemispheres (Figure 3.5).  This is known as the Martian dichotomy.  A heavily cratered surface is ancient, unchanged since the first ~billion years of the Solar System's 4.5 billion year history when many planetesimals remained from the planet formation process in the Sun's protoplanetary disk.  In particular, several hundred million years after the formation, the planets were subject to the Late Heavy Bombardment ... this caused, for example, the `mare' on our Moon.  

If the southern portion of Mars' surface has been unchanged for most of its history, why is the northern portion (about 1/3 of the surface) so free of craters? One possibility is a truly giant impact hit the north after most of the other bombardment was completed.  We see river beds flowing from the southern portion into the north, so perhaps evidence of the giant crater have been mostly eroded by water flows.  Another possibility is early tectonic activity caused by a molten mantle under the Martian crust.  Earth has a thin crust and lots of tectonic activity with ~20 plates that constantly slam into each other, subduct under each other, and cause volcanic eruptions.  The result on Earth is that all ancient impact craters are erased.  The giant canyon Valles Marineris on Mars does resemble a rift valley where two plates are separating on Earth, and there are several huge extinct volcanoes.  But we really don't know the explanation for the Martian dichotomy.

The Martian atmosphere (Chpt 3.2)

[There are lots of details in this section that we don't have to study, including Table 3.1, Fig 3.9, and the details of chemical reactions (3.2)-(3.6)]  

Amount of atmosphere:  It is very interesting to compare the atmospheres of Mars, Earth and Venus, trying to understanding the similarities and differences.  Earth as an atmosphere with intermediate density, around 1 bar pressure.  But most of the volatile material is liquid water in the oceans; only a tiny fraction of water is in vapor or clouds.  This contasts sharply with Venus that has an extraordinarily dense atmosphere with roughly 100 bar pressure at the surface.  Due to its proximity to the Sun, it is too hot for any molecule (particularly water) to be liquid, so essentially every volatile molecule entered the atmosphere.  On the other hand, Mars has a very low density atmosphere around 1 mbar (millibar = 1/1000 bar) pressure.  We do expect a planet with lower gravity like Mars to retain less atmosphere, and some volatiles are stored in the frozen polar caps.  But Mars still seems to have lost a lot of its original atmosphere.  We believe this is due to the solar wind that couples with the outer Martian atmosphere and blows it away into the outer Solar System.  This process is not well-understood, and NASA's MAVEN probe was specifically designed to investigate this process: "Scientists will use MAVEN data to determine the role that loss of volatiles from the Mars atmosphere to space has played through time, giving insight into the history of Mars' atmosphere and climate, liquid water, and planetary habitability".  MAVEN was launched to Mars in November 2013 (delayed from the 2012 launch listed in Table 3.1) and has begun collecting data to address these questions.

Composition of atmosphere Both Mars and Venus seem to have their original atmospheres provided by volatile chemicals that accompanied the planetesimals that formed the planets (with some expected changes, such as ammonia NH3 undergoing photolysis to form nitrogen N2).  These atmospheres early are expected to have been 96% CO2 (Table 3.2).  So the big question is: Why does Earth have only 0.03% CO2 in its atmosphere?  And why does Earth have so much oxygen O2, a very reactive gas?  The history of Earth's atmosphere is complex, but there are two major ingredients.  First, unlike Venus (where the oceans boiled long ago) and Mars (where the oceans froze long ago), Earth has liquid water oceans that dissolve atmospheric CO2; to form carbonic acid, which undergoes chemical reactions into limestone and other carbonates that is incorporated into crustal rock.  We see that Earth's CO2 abundance is likely similar to that of  Venus, if one considers these rocks (Table 3.6).  Second, around ~3-2 billion years ago, microbial life (probably cyanobacteria) developed the chemical reactions known as photosynthesis that converts atmospheric CO2 into organic molecules like sugars, starch and cellulose.  We learned about the role of cyanobacteria during Theme II on the development of life on Earth.  

Evidence for liquid water in Mars' past (Chpt 3.4)

In our class on The terrestrial planets in our Review of our Solar System, we described many surface features of Mars indicating liquid water was present in the past:  streambeds flowing from overfilled craters; craters surrounded by mud flows; dry meandering riverbeds; lake shorelines; gullies around the Valle Marineris canyon system; scarps (cliffs) around the base of Mons Olympus.  Recent rovers making close-up studies of the Martian landscape found ripple patterns in rock; sedimentary layers of rock; carbonates (like limestone) and ball-shaped hematite minerals that can only form under water.  Our text covers much of the same material in 3.4.1-2, but also discusses how advanced techniques (not simple imaging of the surface) can be used to locate current water content under the Martian surface (pp. 104-106).  You can read online some recent findings about water on Mars released since the textbook was published including seasonal changes in gullies, a layer of gypsum (calcium sulfate with water, CaSO4-2H2O), and radar indications of a former large ocean. One research group estimates that Mars has been dry for ~600 million years

If water once flowed on Mars, the atmosphere must have been more massive than it is today.  If Mars had a significantly more massive atmosphere, then we would also suspect that the temperature on the surface where the water flowed would have been considerably warmer than the global average temperature on Mars today due to an increased greenhouse effect from more carbon dioxide and other gases (water? methane? sulfur dioxide? nitrous oxide?) in the past.  Several causes for the gradual loss of warming atmosphere may be involved:  the ablation (stripping away) of Mars' atmosphere by the Sun's wind (see Amount of atmosphere above); the destruction of water (H2O) by the Sun's ultraviolet radiation and subsequent loss of hydrogen to space; ejection due to the explosions from large asteroid impacts; the end of active volcanism as the planet cooled and crust thickened; chaotic changes in the planet's obliquity (axis of rotation).  Our understanding of Mars' ancient climate is still quite uncertain and is actively studied today.  Professor James Kasting in Penn State's College of Earth and Mineral Sciences is one of the world's distinguished scholars studying the atmospheres and climates of the terrestrial planets.  You can see a talk he gave to astronomy undergraduates in 2008 on the early warming of Mars. 

Evidence for life on Mars (Chpt 3.3)

We have no evidence for life on Mars.  No Martian rabbit has been photographed hopping across the surface of the planet.  While sedimentary rocks have been seen, no fossils of ancient life has yet been photographed.  There was once an argument that a meteorite called ALH 84001, that was ejected from the Martian surface by an asteroid impact, has micro-fossils, but it is not widely believed this evidence is not convincing (Chpt 3.5).   No messages or visits from Martian civilizations have been identified (outside of fictional stories).  

But with the clear knowledge that liquid water once flowed profusely on Mars, and the presence of carbon dioxide gas in the atmosphere and carbonate minerals in the rock indicating that organic (carbon-based) molecules were present, and of course the presence of sunlight as an energy source, we satisfy the basic conditions for the emergence of living organisms.  Thus, there is intense interest today in establishing whether life once was present on Mars.

In the late-1970s, NASA launched two excellent probes that landed softly on Mars (although, unlike more recent probes, they did not have wheels and the ability to move) and provided our first close-up view of the Martian surface.  These Viking landers had a robotic shovel that scooped up soil and placed in into three small laboratories specifically designed to search for active life forms (Chpt 3.3).  The results were tantalizing!  When Martian soil is placed into water, it fizzes, absorbing carbon dioxide and releasing oxygen just like green plants on Earth.  However, a mass spectrometer experiment revealed no organic molecules at all.  These apparently contradictory results have been explained as the consequence of the Sun's ultraviolet light irradiating the soil giving rise to suboxide or peroxide minerals.  When placed in water, these materials can absorb carbon dioxide and emit oxygen ... but without any metabolism of living organisms (analogous to the fizzing of a common treatment for stomach distress).  See details here.

  

There is one other curiosity (sec 3.4.5).  Telescopes in Hawaii have taken infrared spectra of the Martian atmosphere for many years.  In 2003, methane was seen over localized regions of the northern hemisphere during its summer.  Methane on Mars should be rapidly (few years) destroyed by solar ultraviolet ... so where did it come from? Is it from the ancient atmosphere, trapped in the rock for billions of years and suddenly released?  Or, as on Earth, is the methane generated by microbial life?  This puzzle has not been solved.  A recent probe by NASA, the Mars Science Lander (nicknamed Curiosity), now on the Martian surface has a variety of advanced experiments specifically to look for microbial life.  While there have been many interesting geological and geochemical results supporting the idea that Mars once have significant liquid water, no evidence for current or past life has yet emerged.

node.title: The Discovery of Exoplanets
node.body:
Exoplanets: Historical Context

For most of the history of astronomy, there was only one planetary system known: our Solar System.  Despite some past enthusiasms (see the historical overview in the 'Introduction' lecture of Week 1), most astronomers were very pessimistic that planets could be found orbiting other stars by now. The reflected light (in the visible light band) due to Earth is billions of times fainter than the the sun, and the Earth is so close to the Sun that the sunlight dwarfs the faint light reflected by Earth for any alien observers looking at the Sun from a planet orbiting another star. The dynamical effects — pulling and pushing through its gravitational interactions—of an Earth-analog planet on its host star are tiny: typically velocities of less than a meter per second (hundreds of millions times smaller than the speed of light), typical motions less than a thousandth of an arcsecond on the sky.  When an Earth-size planet briefly passes in front of a sun-like star, the fraction of the star's surface blocked by the planet is just ~0.01%.

When I was starting out in science, all of these measurements were completely impossible to achieve.  Thus, no one had any empirically-based knowledge of whether planetary systems were rare or common, whether our Solar System is typical or extraordinary. And by inference, no one had any empirically-based knowledge about whether planets that could host life.  Given the impracticality of detecting planets like those in our solar system, no rational astronomer would devote serious effort to discovering planetary systems.  Even the few who did dream of searching for planets, acknowledged that they couldn't justify spending the time, money or telescope time just to search for planets.  Instead, they gradually developed the technology to detect low-mass stars and brown dwarfs, in hopes that someday it would be possible to discover planets around other stars.  Fortunately, nature produces some planetary systems that are much easier to detect that our own.  

The situation completely changed with the discovery of the first exoplanet orbiting the Sun-like star 51 Pegasii in 1995. It was found because the situation was totally unlike our Solar System: A planet with mass greater than Jupiter's was orbiting the star closer than Mercury, not far above the star's surface. This was extraordinary! As "hot Jupiters" were found, astronomers feverishly worked to improve the quality of their spectrographs, their high-resolution cameras, and their photometric cameras ..... vast efforts have been exerted since ~2000 to improve the technologies for planet detection.  

The work has been rewarded more richly than even optimists imagined. Only since ~2010, have we had scientific data to conclude that roughly half of the stars we see at night have planetary systems of some sort (and perhaps even more). Most stars with one detectable planet have additional planets. Many are unlike our Solar System, but the data are strongly indicating that a non-trivial fraction of stars have roughly Earth-size or Earth-mass planets in Earth-line orbits. This provides a profound vindication for the optimists about Life in the Universe that we discussed in Week 1 of the class—from Lucretius in ancient Rome, to Bernard de Fontenelle in Renaissance France, to Carl Sagan in 20th century America.  

Unfortunately, there is much more that we do not know about these planets.  In many cases, we know either the planet's size or mass, but not both.  We know precious little about their composition, atmospheres, and surfaces.  Penn State's Center for Exoplanets and Habitable Worlds includes several faculty designing the next generation of planet hunting instruments and surveys.  

We will spend four weeks, Weeks 8-11, studying how the recent discoveries of exoplanets were made, the charcteristics of the planets, and the abundance of known planets.  This sets the stage for the final theme of our course, discussion of the potential for life on these exoplanets. This week, Week 8, we will lay the groundwork for the exoplanetary discoveries by discussing methods for finding planets.  

PLEASE BE CLEAR:  ASTRONOMERS HAVE FOUND LOTS OF PLANETS.  THEY HAVE NOT FOUND ANY LIFE ON THESE PLANETS.

Summary of Planet Discovery Methods

  • Direct imaging:  Planets reflect starlight and reemit energy absorbed as thermal infrared radiation.
  • Astrometry:  Gravitation pull of planet moves star back and forth in the sky during the orbit
  • Radial velocity:  Gravitational pull of planet causes star's velocity to increase and decrease during the orbit
  • Transits:  A planet passes in front of a star, causing an eclipse that causes the measured starlight slightly to decrease.
  • Microlensing: A star with a planet passes in front of a background star, temporarily increasing the ammount of starlight detected due to gravitational lensing

Catalogs of Exoplanets

There are some general resources that you can glance at now, but refer back repeatedly during our study of exoplanets.  Take a look at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory's PlanetQuest website which gives an atlas of the known extrasolar planets with some nice interactive displays.  See the excellent Exoplanets Orbit Database (maintained by Penn State Professor Jason Wright and his advisees) and the Extrasolar Planets Encyclopaedia for details on each known planet.   These have interactive data tools that can be used to make histogram and correlation plots such as those show in some of the online lectures.  These catalog list thousands of planets and planetary systems, and the numbers continue to grow during the course of the semester.  You may notice that the number of exoplanets on each site doesn't match exactly.  There are a variety of reasons, ranging from which site was updated most recently to the curators making different judgements about which planets should be included.

Michael Perryman's Summary of Exoplanet Discoveries

Michael Perryman has been a leading figure in the European Space Agency's efforts to find planets around other stars.  He is also author of a major advanced text in the field.  His diagram, now a few years out of date,  summarizes the success of different methods for finding planets. The different branches of the tree show different methods.  The depth of the tree downwards indicates how sensitive the method is for discovering smaller planets.  On the axis on the left side, MJ refers to one Jupiter mass and MO (circle with a plus inside) refers to one Earth mass.  Numbers at the bottom indicates how many planets or multiple-planet systems had been found with each method (as of 2015).  Dotted lines indicate technologies under development but not yet achieved. I suggest that you come back to this summary after you have studied about the various methods this week.

node.title: Direct Imaging Method
node.body:
In a regular telescope, the image of a star is blurred by fluctuations in Earth's upper atmosphere by about 1 arcsecond. Except for the very nearest stars, the faint light from any orbiting planets will lie within this bright blur, and thus be undetectable.  Several technologies have (or still are) emerged in recent years to improve this situation:

  • Adaptive optics is a complicated process whereby a flexible glass mirror in the telescope's optics is rapidly deformed (bent) to compensate for the atmospheric fluctuations.  This greatly improves the effective focus of the image.
  • A coronograph is introduced into the optical system of the camera, placing an opaque dot on the star image. This allows faint light from orbiting planets to be see without the glare of the host star.
  • Interferometry is a sophisticated technique whereby the star is imaged by two closely-space telescopes, and the signal is processed to "null" (essentially, erase) the stellar image, leaving faint emission from any planets.  A $1 billion NASA space mission was under development using this technique, but has been cancelled due to technical difficulties and cost overruns.

These methods have been successful in detecting several dozen planets around other stars.  This method can only find planets that are quite distant from the star, typically 20-100 AU (Astronomical Unit = Earth-Sun distance).  The most remarkable case is HR 8799, a nearby star with about 2 solar masses and 4 orbiting planets ... over years, we have direct images that show the planets orbiting the star!  These planets have been imaged both with NASA's Hubble Space Telescope in space and with active optics coronagraphs on mountaintop telescopes.

node.title: Astrometry Method
node.body:
This topic is briefly covered in section 6.6.1.  Again, we don't need to know the mathematical details.

When a planet orbits a star, the star orbits the planet!  Or, as Isaac Newton showed in his masterful work on the dynamics (motions and forces) of massive objects, both the planet and the star orbit the `center of mass' of the system.  Since the star is much more massive than the planet (our Sun is ~thousand times more massivethan Jupiter, and ~million time more than Earth), the star's motion is very small compared to the size of the planet's orbit.

If several planets are present, then they each pull the star in different directions at different orbital periods, giving rise to a complicated wobble pattern that would tell a good deal about the planetary system.  Here is how the Sun would look if its position could be accurately monitored from another star:

Learn more about the Sun's wobble with the interactive applet at the UNL's star wobble website. What planets have the greatest dynamical effect on the Sun?

Unfortunately, a quantitative evaluation of this effect shows it is extremely small.  If the Sun were viewed from a star 10 parcsec distant and that is a very close star), then the maximum wobble is only about 1/1000 of an arcsecond.  Even the most accurate telescope available today cannot achieve this accuracy in the visible or infrared band.  It is there not a surprise that no planets have yet been discovered due to the  astrometric wobble of the host star.

This situation is expected to change in a few years with the arrival of data from the "GAIA" mission led by the European Space Agency (ESA). From space, beyond the distorting effects of Earth's atmosphere, the mission will be able to measure the positions of 1 billion stars in our Galaxy to micro-arcsecond precision, far beyond the capabilities of the best ground-based observatories. It is expected that GAIA will thus detect many massive planets via the astrometric motions of their host stars; however, its precision is not sufficient to promise detection of Earth-like planets in the habitable zones of (most of) these stars.

node.title: Radial Velocity Method
node.body:
This topic is treated in detail in our text, sec 6.6.2.  Fig 6.18 shows the first detected exoplanetary signal in the spectrum of the solar-like star 51 Pegasi.  But we will not be responsible for the full mathematical treatment in the text.  It is useful to look it over: for example, equation (6.20) shows how the orbit size (ap) can be established from the orbital period and the mass of the host star, and equation (6.24) shows how the mass of the planet (Mp) can be estimated from the maximum Doppler velocity of the star, its mass, and the orbit size.   But we don't have to learn all of the mathematical details.  

The most successful technique for detection and confirmation of planets has been via the small, periodic (repeating) alternating Doppler redshifts and blueshifts in the star's light which indicate it is being pushed and pulled by an unseen planet. Swiss astronomers Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz (see Fig. 7.1 on page 233) made the first discovery of a planet around a Sun-like star in 1995 with their detection of a periodic wobble in the motions of the star 51 Pegasi. Since then, they and other groups have found several hundred planets via the Doppler wobbles of Sun-like stars due to their orbiting planets.  As of October 2016, Exoplanets Data Explorer (set the "Filter" to say "PLANETDISCMETH == 'RV' ") lists 482 planets, while the catalog at the Extrasolar Planets Encyclopedia lists over 600.

The Doppler effect is illustrated in the first diagram below. The unseen planet orbits the visible star, which undergoes a small blueshift (motion towards us) when the planet is receding, and a small redshift (motion away from us) when the planet is approaching.  The second image below shows the complicated visible band spectrum of a Sun-like star showing the many absorption lines that shift blueward and redward as the planet orbits the star.  Tthe Dopper shifts are smaller than 1-part-in-a-million, so the shifts are smaller than the width of a line.  The best spectrograph today, built specially for planet detection, can detect stellar motions as small as 1 meter/sec (walking speed), or a few billionths of the rest wavelength of the absorption line.  

The astronomer takes the spectrum of a star over and over again -- for weeks, months and years --  hoping to find some variation in the radial velocity.  If a variation is found, then mathematical tools are used to search for the orbital period which can range from days to years.  The radial velocity data are `folded' modulo this period and replotted like the following graph.  

In this case, the star exhibits a +10 to -10 meter/s motion with the planet's orbital period of 17 days.  The shape of the curve gives the eccentricity of the system; a pure sine wave indicates a perfectly circular orbit.  A calculation based on Newton's Laws of Motion and Gravity allow the mass of the planet to be estimated; here it about 0.11 times the mass of Jupiter.  So, we have a case here of a `hot Nepture' orbiting closer to the star than Mercury orbits our Sun (Mercury's orbital period is about 3 months, greater than 17 days).    

In some cases, the wobble is complicated because several planets with different orbital periods pull on the star; there are known cases where 3, 4, and even possibly 6 planets have been found to orbit a single star using radial velocity techniques.  A famous example is the bright star Upsilon Andromedae that has three planets in orbits similar to the terrestrial planets in our Solar System ... but the planets are much more massive!

node.title: Transit and Transit Timing Methods
node.body:
Planetary Transit Method

This topic is covered in section 6.4, rather briefly considering its great importance today.  Here the math is easy: equation (6.9) shows that the radius of the planet (Rp) divided by the radius of the host star (R*) can be easily measured from the fraction of starlight obscured during the transit.  Figure 6.11 shows recent data on the first planetary transit discovered around star HD 209458. 

When a planet's orbit happens, by chance, to be aligned along the line-of-sight between Earth and the host star, then the planet's disk will pass in front of the star's disk and eclipse a tiny fraction of the starlight.  This is called the transit of a planet across the star.  The phenomenon has been well-known for centuries because, every few years, Venus transits across the Sun's disk as seen from Earth.  This was historically important because it allowed accurate measurement of the Earth-Sun distance in the 1700-1800s.  The latest transit of Venus took place last summer, June 5-6 2012, and was visible to U.S. amateur astronomers with telescopes equipped to image the sun. The next transit is in 2117, but you can see a NASA movie of the transit.    

The diagrams below illustrate the phenomena involving a planet orbiting another star.  The starlight brightness dims slightly when the planet transits; this dip is typically 0.01-1% of the light, so the brightness measurements must be very accurate.  This is best achieved using a telescope on a satellite in space where the shimmering of our atmosphere is not present.  If the orbital speed of the planet is known from radial velocity measurements, its radius can be directly measured by the duration of the eclipse ingress and egress (the short tilted lines in the brightness diagrams below). 

The first discovery of a planetary transit was HD 209458, detected in 2000 by the young astronomer David Charbonneau who observed a system already known to have a Jupiter-mass planet in an rapid orbit around the star.  The left panel below shows his now-famous data (in this case, the dip is very strong at 1.5% of the starlight), and the right panel shows an artist's drawing of the system.  

  

Transit and radial velocity studies are very complementary.  Radial velocity studies tell us the size, period, and ellipticity of the planet's orbit, give an estimate of the planet's mass, and tell us the number of planets (actually, the number that cause a significant velocity perturbation over the timespan of observations).  Transit studies can tell us the radius of the planet, orbital inclination (tilt), and the number of planets (actually, the number of planets that transit, big enough to be detected given the quality of the data, and close enough to their star that they can be detected multiple times within the timespan of observations).  In some cases where followup spectroscopy and infrared studies can be made, we learn the planet's surface temperature, albedo (reflectivity), and details about its atmosphere. The best understanding arises when both transit and radial velocity observations are available for the same system - knowing the planet's size and mass, we can calculate its average density, which gives a strong idea of its composition (see Fig. 7.12 on page 254 of our textbook).  

A revolution is now underway in the discovery of planetary transits. In 2009, NASA launched its Kepler mission. This is a telescope orbiting Earth (left panel below) with a huge CCD camera (right panel below... your cell phone probably has a small CCD camera) that observed the brightness of ~160,000 stars at a time.  The satellite system reported the brightness of each star roughly once every thirty minutes nearly continuously for four years.  (While many stars have variable brightness for some reason (magnetic starspots, binary star companion), others are very nearly constant and one can sensitively search for tiny periodic dips due to the transit of a planet. As we will see in coming lectures, the Kepler mission has revolutionized planet detection with several thousand candidate planets. Today, most of the planets known were identified by the Kepler mission.  Most of the planets it finds are in planetary systems having multiple planets, and many of the systems exhibiting remarkable properties. 

  

Exercise the Extrasolar Planet Simulators, both the radial velocity and transit methods, provided by the University of Nebraska.   They give a good feeling for the variety of signals ... and noise ... that can be expected in real observations.  The descriptions of the methods (click under "Main Content") are also nice with more detail than given in our text

Transit Timing Method

When a planet is observed to transit its host star, it will transit the star every orbit, in a highly predictable fashion. In fact, the transits will follow one another with absolutely clock-like regularity... unless the planet's orbital motions are being perturbed by the gravitational influence of other planets in the system. In the latter case, we can expect to observe transit timing variations - subtle drifting of the transit times, compared to an exactly periodic signal - which will (in time) reveal the mass and orbit of the perturbing planet. This entirely different method of planet discovery has been maturing at a furious rate thanks to the continuing observations of the Kepler mission, which not only detects planets in transit, but also continues to observe them as they transit their host star, over and over again.   Penn State Professor Eric Ford was a member of the Kepler Science team and one of the leaders of studying multiple-planet systems with transit timing variations.

node.title: Microlensing Method
node.body:
This topic is covered in our text's section 6.5, and again we don't cover the mathematics. 

When a massive body  passes in front of a luminous object (like another star) as seen from Earth, then the background starlight can be focussed and amplified by the intervening body. This process in known as `microlensing', a type of `gravitational lensing' that was known by Albert Einstein a century ago. As the foreground star passes slowly in front of the background star, the brightness of the background star shows a slow rise and fall in brightness, typically lasting several weeks. But if the foreground star also has one or more planets in a fortuitous orbital location, then the planet also causes a lensing event, but much quicker. See the diagram below.

Perhaps the most remarkable system found so far using gravitational microlensing is named OGLE-2006-BLG-109.  Its weird brightness variations are modeled by planets very similar to our Solar System: a Jupiter-mass planet and a Saturn-mass planet at distances 2 and 4 AU.  Here is the brightness variation seen in 2006.  Once the event was triggered, telescopes around the world (New Zealand, Australia, Israel, Canary Islands, Chile, United States) observed the star nearly continuously for ~10 days.  This was essential to capture the complexity of the event, and thus model the planetary system.
