node.title: The Exoplanetary Census Today
node.body:
As of March 2018, the Extrasolar Planet Encyclopedia (http://exoplanet.eu) lists:

  • 746 planets orbiting 553 stars found using radial velocity techniques, including 134 multiple planet systems.  These are found in the way Mayor & Queloz discovered 51 Peg b in 1995; repeated measurement of Dopper shifts in the spectra of stars looking for tiny periodic motions caused by the gravitational pull of orbiting planets. 
  • 2789 `confirmed' planets in 2082 systems including 461 multiple planet systems, plus several thousand very probable additional cases, found using transit detection.  These are found in the way that Charbonneau discovered HD 209458 b in 2000; repeated measurement of the brightness of a star looking for tiny dips in the star's brightness due to the passage of a planet across its disk (a transit).  The great majority of these transiting planets were found using  NASA's Kepler mission, but others are found using ground-base telescopes or the French/Euro CoRoT satellite (originally designed to study stellar variability and only incidentally finding a few dozen planets).
  • 67 planets orbiting 65 stars found using gravitational microlensing detection including 2 multiple planet systems.  These are found by staring at millions of stars in the crowded plane of the Milky Way Galaxy waiting for the rare occurrence that one passes directly in front of another.  The background starlight is then greatly amplified for a brief period and, if the foreground star has an orbiting planet in the right place, a secondary amplification is seen.  
  • 92 planets orbiting 85 stars found by direct imaging including 5 multiple planet systems.  These are found by directly imaging nearby stars with instruments equiped with active optics so that very sharp images are obtained.  Only planets with very large orbits, typically beyond the orbit of Uranus, can be seen in this fashion.  In addition, in most cases, the central starlight is removed with a dark spot in front of the detector (this is called a coronograph).   

Each method has its own limitations in detecting planets:  some can only find the more massive planets (radial velocities, microlensing), or the larger planets with smaller orbits (transit), or planets with the largest orbits (direct imaging), or planets with orbits that are fortuitously (by chance) observed at favorable orientations (radial velocities, transit, microlensing).  Astronomers try very hard to understand the limitations of each survey in order to calculate the global properties of all planets from the samples available today.  

This follows a broad principle of the scientific method:  we are usually interested in global phenomena or processes in the natural world, not just the properties of the small sample in our laboratory or telescope.  Note that this principle doesn't work where there is only one object, such as understanding global warming on the Earth today or understanding the origins of our Universe.  But it does work when there are vast underlying populations, such as planets orbiting stars in our Galaxy.

I can also make some personal comments from watching this field for 20 years

  1. Most of the discoveries were made possible by improving the sensitivity of existing instruments, sometimes made enormously better, by clever engineering.  My respect for engineering teams, in universities & industry, U.S. and Europe, is really high ... they are often superb!  
  2. I personally didn't believe that gravitational lensing of planets would work.  But with dozens of discoveries, often very valuable because they don't depend on the planet being near or far from the star, it clearly has been a success. This is a case where my evaulation at the time was wrong .... can't even trust my own judgment! 
  3. The discovery of planets is going very well, and spectroscopists are finally developing instruments that can characterize the planets' atmospheric composition and extent.  But the astrophysicists who try to model the origin of planetary systems are having a tough time.  The best earlier predictions proved entirely wrong when NASA's Kepler mission results emerged.  The physical processes of planet formation are not just a calculation of Newton'g gravity, but involves the physics of rocks, ices, dust, pebbles, moons, ion-molecular chemistry, radioactive decay, ... ...  I think that the theorists will be pondering these issues throughout the 21st century, just as theorists figured out the physical origin and structure of stars between ~1880-1970.  

How many planets in the Galaxy?

It is difficult to estimate the total fraction of stars hosting planetary systems from radial velocity or Kepler data due to the complicated limitations of each survey.  Kepler has found ~8,000 likely planets from observations of ~190,000 stars for several years.  But the true fraction of stars with planets is certainly much greater than 8,000/190,000 ~4%, because only a small fraction of planets will show transits when viewed from a single direction.  Also many stars have variable brightness or other problem that hinders finding planetary transits.  The radial velocity results indicate at least 10% of stars have Jupiter-like planets, and probably many more.  A recent estimate from microlensing studies (which has less bias but much smaller samples) suggests that the fraction may be as high as 50%, as illustrated on the European Southern Observatory website.  

Today the best estimates are 50% to 100% of stars have planets.  If the stellar mass of our Galaxy is around 300 billion solar masses (estimated from the Galaxy's rotation curve) and if the typical star has mass around 0.3 Mo (estimated from the observed distribution of stellar masses), then there are about 1 trillion (1x1015) stars in the Galaxy.  If nearly all of them have planets, then there is nearly a trillion planets in the Galaxy.  

Next week we will return to this counting exercise, concentrating on the number of habitable planets in the Galaxy.

node.title: General Properties of Exoplanets
node.body:
Let us now look at some of the collective properties of planetary systems known today, keeping in mind that these are small and biased samples.  

Results from Radial Velocity Surveys

Radial velocity surveys have various limitations, but they can find planetary systems with reasonable reliability when the planet's gravitional pull is sufficiently strong;  that is, the planet's mass can't be too small and its orbital period can not too long.  In particular, expect the radial velocity surveys to undercount the lower mass planets ... they are particularly good at finding the more massive gaseous (Jupiter-like) planets.  Using Newton's version of Kepler's Third Law of Planetary Orbits, we can estimate the mass of these planets ... but we don't get their radius.  

The following diagrams have been extensively discussed as important summaries of the radial velocity surveys.  The first one plots the planetary mass in units of Jupiter's mass against the semi-major axis (i.e. radius for a circular orbit) in Astronomical Units.  We use logarithmic units because the range of the variables is very large; so the masses range from around 0.001 MJup (1e-3) to 100 MJup (1e+2).  The second diagram plots the orbit's eccentricity (where 0 is a circular orbit and 0.9 is highly elongated) against the semi-major axis. It is useful to remember where Earth lies on these plots: it has mass = 0.003 MJup, radius = 0.09 RJup, semi-major axis = 1.0 AU, and eccentricity near 0.0. 

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1889|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

[ciscode|rev=1|tool=elmsmedia|item=1890|entity_type=node|render=display_mode|display_mode=image__lightboxed]

The first plot seems to show three distinct groups: 

  1. Starting on the left side, we see planets with roughly Jupiter's mass and very small orbits, a few percent of an AU.  These planets orbit their host stars in a few days, rather than in a few years as we seen in our Solar System.  51 Peg b, the first clearly detected planet (1995), is one of these planets.  These are nicknamed hot Jupiters, because they low so close to their host stars; indeed, in a few cases, we see spectroscopic evidence that the gases from the planet's atmosphere are being heated and flow away from the host star.  But we need to explain how these planets got their tiny orbits considering that Jupiters are expected to form in the outer parts of protoplanetary disks. 
  2. We then see a  group of planets with masses around 0.03 MJup ~ 10 MEarth with orbit sizes around 0.1 AU.  These were found relatively recently using the most accurate spectrographs; then are nicknamed super-Earths.  In most cases, they lie too close to the host star to be in the Habitable Zones, so they are hot ... in some cases, the surface may be molten rock!
  3. A considerable number of radial velocity planets have masses several times Jupiter and orbit sizes of several AU.  Clearly, our Jupiter is a rather modest planet among the gaseous giants orbiting other planets. 

The second diagram above shows that many planets have very eccentric (elliptical) orbits.   This was a big surprise!  In our Solar System, planet orbits are nearly circular (eccentricities mostly less than that 0.05).  In the early years around 1995-2000, we found mostly eccentric Jupiters, but today with more sensitive spectrographs, we see eccentric super-Earths too.  This raises a big question: how did these planets got high eccentricities considering that they formed in protoplanetary disks where the orbits should be nearly perfectly circular.

If we count the number of planets found with radial velocity surveys against the number of stars that were observed, we found that at least 10% of all Sun-like stars examined show radial velocity signatures of Jovian planets.  And there are probably many more stars with less massive planets that cannot be detected in this fashion.  But by this method alone, we predict that (for a trillion stars in our Galaxy) there will be tens-to-hundreds of billions of planets in our Galaxy.  Wow!   

A major lesson from both diagrams is that few systems resemble our Solar System.  The terrestrial planets (Mercury through Mars) would not be detectable using radial velocity methods, so our Solar System would show only two planets on these graphs:  Jupiter (1 MJup mass at 5 AU semi-major axis and 5% eccentricity), and Saturn (0.3 MJup at 10 A.U. and 6% eccentricity). It is not yet clear whether our Solar System has a rare configuration of planets, or whether better surveys will find many Solar System analogs.  

Results from Transiting Planets

The Kepler survey is, by far, the best source of transiting planets.  Kepler has detected over 8,000 probable planetary systems of which >1000 are `confirmed' with additional spectroscopic evidence.  But it is widely believed that >90% of the Kepler `probable' planets are real, and that many more planetary transits are hidden by brightness variations in the host star.  That is why you are participating in the PlanetHunters citizen science effor to find new transits within variable light curves!  

The computer-generated poster below shows the host stars (with realistic surface colors) and small black dots to representing the sizes of the transiting planet. 

The plot below compares the radii of Kepler planets (in units of RJup, Jupiter's radius) to their orbit size (in units of AU, the Earth-Sun distance).  Recall that the transit method can give the planet's radius (by timing the ingress/egress of the transit lightcurve) but not the planet's mass or eccentricity.  

  1. We clearly see again a clump of Jupiter-like planets (R~1-2 RJup) with very small orbits (a~0.02-0.06 AU).  These are the hot Jupiters that we saw in the radial velocity surveys above.
  2. Most of the planets have sizes between ~0.07 and ~0.4 RJup.  For comparison, in our Solar System Neptune has radius 0.35 RJup and Earth has radius 0.09 RJup.  So these exoplanets are often called Neptunes, super-Earths, and Earths.  Note however the tilt in the lower envelope of the Kepler planets in this diagram. This is an instrumental limitation: transits of very small planets orbiting far from the star produce transits too faint for the Kepler detectors to see.  Thus there are only a couple (out of thousands) of Kepler exoplanets that are Earth twins with radius ~0.09 RJup and orbit ~1 AU.  

The Kepler Team has performed a final re-analysis of its data, and the latest list of Kepler planetary candidates should be announced in 2006 (possibly during our semester).  Below is a histogram of planet radii shown by the Kepler Team at conferences from their earlier analysis.   The most common planets found are super-Earths and Neptunes, and Jupiters are much rarer.  Earths (and sub-Earths??) are probably much more numerous than found due to instrumental limitations.

Below are some artist's drawings comparing some of the well-studied Kepler planet sizes to the familiar planets of our Solar System.

node.title: Multiplanet Systems
node.body:
Hundreds of the exoplanets -- from transit, radial velocity, microlensing and direct imaging surveys --  are in multiple planet systems.  Watch the totally fun animation of all known Kepler multiple planet systems below.  This is a winner!!  

In this class, we select a few of the fascinating exoplanetary systems that have been characterized in some detail.  

Upsilon Andromedae

This was the first exciting multiplanetary system, discovered during 1996-1999 with the radial velocity method.  Below is a diagram of the orbits (with Mercury, Venus and Earth shown with dashed orbits), and an artist's view of the planets.  This system illustrates two common phenomena not seen in our Solar System:  a "hot Jupiter" orbiting extremely close to the host star (ups And b, 4.6 day orbit); and orbital that are more eccentric than the near-circular orbits in our Solar System.  

HR 8799

Direct imaging of exoplanets in telescopes is extremely difficult as reflect such a tiny faction of the starlight and are so close to the star. But it has succeed in a few cases with technologically advanced active optics and coronographic techniques on large telescopes. The most famous case is HR 8799 in the image below. The bright central star has been suppressed and three planets are revealed. The arrows show their motion over several years, and estimates of their masses (around 10 Jupiter masses) and orbits (far beyond our Kuiper Belt) are shown.

Gleise 581

Gl 581 is a nearby star with a very complicated radial velocity behavior that can only be explained if the star is orbited by 4, or possibly more, planets.  Here is the early radial velocity data and an artists conception of the planets involved.  All four planets orbit very close to the host star, closer than Mercury orbits our Sun.  The blue region in the second diagram is the Habitable Zone that we will discuss next week.  

Kepler 11 bcdefg

This is one of the most spectacular planetary systems to emerge from NASA's Kepler satellite's monitoring of ~160,000 stars: 6 planets orbiting a Sun-like star.  The top diagram shows the data:  brightness (vertical axis showing the star's brightness measured with incredible accuracy of around 0.01%) plotted against time (horizontal axis, showing ~1.5 years of monitoring).  Dozens of tiny dips are seen in the star's brightness that are modeled as the transits of 6 planets (second and third panel below).  These planets are `super-Earths' and `Neptunes' with masses around 3-20 Earth masses.  All of them orbit close to the host star, too hot to be in the star's Habitable Zone. The planets' radii, measured from the ingress/egress times of the transit eclipses, are consistent with densities around 0.5-2 g/cm3.  This suggests they are made mostly of gases rather than solid rock.    

  

Note that the multiplanet models are not always reliable: the data is sparse or noisy, and different multiplanet models can often reasonably fit the same dataset.  The systems we see here are also probably incomplete: there easily can be more lower-mass (Earth-like??) planets in these systems that we can't yet detect.  Nonetheless, we are very confident that multiple planets are indeed present because, in some cases, we can detect very tiny gravitational interactions between the planets.  In Kepler data, the transits are seen sometimes to be slightly earlier or later than expected, consistent with gravitational tugs by the other planets, which can be detected as transit timing variations.

node.title: Exoplanet Composition
node.body:
While it is possible in a few cases, with great difficulty, to obtain spectra of the atmospheres of exoplanets, we do have a crude measure of planet composition for some dozens of exoplanets.  This comes from the density of the planet:  Density = Mass / Volume = Mass / (4/3 pi) Radius3 for a sphere.  A trivial example might be: a pound of feathers occupies a much larger volume than a pound of steel, so steel has a much higher density than feathers.  

When a planet is detected both using the radial velocity method (which gives a measurement of the mass) and the transit method (which gives a measurement of the radius), we can combine these to estimate the density.  A gas giant planet will have low density below 1 g/cm3 (one gram per cubic centimeter).  A planet of solid water ice will have density at 1 g/cm^3.  Solid rocky (silicate) planets should have densities around 3-4 g/cm3.   A pure iron planet would have density around 8 g/cm3.  So we have a real ability to evaluate something about the composition of planets without actually measuring their spectrum.  See the artist's drawing below for predictions of different planet compositions. 

Here are the latest results I just obtained last week from the exoplanet.eu database:

  

Jupiter of course lies at M=1.0 MJup and R=1.0 RJup.  Many of the exoplanets are roughly around Jupiter's position in the diagram, though with somewhat bigger radii.   This suggest they are gaseous hydrogen-rich giants.  Earth lies at M=0.003 MJup  and R=0.1 RJup at the bottom-left of the diagram, and a few Earth-like rocky planets have been found.  And of course, there are planets with intermediate masses and radii between Earth and Jupiter.  But perhaps the most interesting aspect is the wide range in radii for a fixed mass ... this suggests a variety of compositions are present.

It is easier to interpret these results from a similar plot of the lower-left portion of the diagram made last year by the Kepler Team:

Here we see that planets near the upper envelope of the distribution (higher radius for a given mass) have densities around 0.5-1 g/cm3, roughly similar to Saturn which is dominated by H and He (hydrogen and helium).  Those in the middle of the distribution have densities similar to Uranus & Neptune which are dominated by CH4 and NH3 (methane and ammonia).  But a few have densities similar to Earth (silicate rock with iron core) or even denser (pure iron?).  

Finally, I reproduce below a similar plot from (student) Lauren Weiss and (professor) Geoffroy Marcy at University of California - Berkeley, members of the Kepler Team.  You can find their paper here.   The dots represent the observed exoplanets (error bars omitted).  The dashed red curve shows a relationship expected for Earth-like composition (silicates plus an iron core); they believe this fits the data for planets with small radii, <1.5 REarth.  The dashed black line is fitted to the data for larger planets.  Here the mass rises much slower than (radius)3, indicating lower densities for larger planets.  The two blue dots at the upper right are Uranus and Neptune ... so it appears that most exoplanets with radii similar to these planets have lower mass, and hence lower densities, than Uranus & Neptune.  They claim their curves are evidence for a transition from rocky planets (r<1.5 REarth) to gaseous planets (r>1.5 REarth).  This interpretation is being hotly debated in the research community.

We immediately can make a few conclusions:  

  1. There are exoplanets that seem fairly similar -- in mass and radius -- to Earth, Uranus/Neptune and Saturn/Jupiter.  But there is a lot of scatter in this relationship suggesting that different planets have different compositions.  This suggests that both rocky and gaseous planets are common among exoplanets.  There may be a transition between the two types around radium ~1.5 REarth or  mass ~2 MEarth, but this isn't yet very clear.  
  2. Most of the planets follow a broad relationship where radius increases with mass.  This is expected for planets of any reasonable composition.  But it is hard to distinguish true differences in planet density from measurement errors from the noisy (both radial velocity and transit) data and complications in the models needed to estimate masses and radii.  
  3.  There appear to be a few planets with very small radii at all masses; this implies they are very dense.  Pure iron planets??  This is not at all clear yet.  ​

One planet with very low density has attracted considerable attention recently.  It is a `super-Earth' with 6 MEarth (Earth masses) orbiting very close to a low mass M-type star near the Sun, GJ 1214.  Both the mass and radius have been measured, and the resulting density is around 1 g/cm3, consistent with pure water.  It has been nicknamed Water-world.  Below is a more realistic model of its interior: mostly water but with a rocky/iron solid core and a hydrogen-helium atmosphere.
