node.title: Protoplanetary Disks
node.body:
The discovery of protoplanetary disks around young stars

After Isaac Newton explained the motions of planets in our Solar System using his Laws of Motion and Gravity, scholars tried to explain how our planetary system might have originated.  The model that proved successful was envisioned by Immanuel Kant in a book Universal Natural History (1755); he later became famous as a philosopher (rather than a scientist).  Kant proposed that our Solar System condensed out of a gaseous disk orbiting the Sun, long ago.  

Immanuel Kant's model for the Solar System was largely forgotten for many years, and astrophysicists thought about star formation mainly with a simplistic spherical model.  Here gas and dust in interstellar clouds undergo gravitational collapse, falling directly into the core where a star forms.  We thus expected protostars to be enshrouded in a spherical envelope of dust and gas.  This envelope has, in fact, recently been seen using millimeter telescopes.

But the flattened structure orbiting the protostar, the protoplanetary disk where planets can form, eluded detection until the 1980-90s.  Three steps can be traced in their discovery and study:

1. IRAS (InfraRed Astronomical Satellite) detected strong infrared emission around young stars. IRAS was a collaboration between NASA, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands in the 1980s.   Infrared astronomy had been in a very primitive state due to the difficulty of designing sensitive detectors and the infrared brightness of the Earth's atmosphere, even during nighttime.   When the first infrared telescope was launched into space, it found that some stars had tens, hundreds or thousands of times more infrared emission than expected.  The excess was found in intermediate-mass stars like Vega, and in young stars in molecular clouds.  The best explanation was a flattened disk of dusty gas at temperatures around T ~ 100-500 K (degrees Kelvin, the Earth's surface is at T=300K).  However, the IRAS telescope detected the infrared emission from the disks, it did not focus well enough to image the disk, and did not have high spectral resolution to study the composition of the disks.

2. In the early 1990s, NASA's Hubble Space Telescope observed some these nearby young stars and clearly imaged the disks.  Three types are shown below:  the AB Auriga and HD 141569 disks are seen in reflected starlight; several disks around protostars in the nearby Taurus molecular cloud are seen in silhouette against the illuminated gas above and below the disk; and disks around young stars in the Orion Nebula Cluster are seen in silhouette against the bright emission behind the stars.  These were the first time astronomers directly saw the protoplanetary disks where planets form.  

   

  

3. In the mid-2000s,  NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope observed hundreds of protoplanetary disks.  Spitzer still could not focus well-enough to image the disks, but had an excellent infrared spectrometer to obtain detailed spectra of the protoplanetary disks.  Three examples are shown below.  The AA Tau disk shows water (H2), carbon dioxide (CO2), hydrogen cyanide (HCN), and acetylene (H2C2).  The HH 46 disk shows ices (CO2, H2O, and alcohol CH3OH), gas (CH4 methane), and rock (silicates).  The CRBR 2422.8-3423 disk shows gasses (CO, CO2, and NH3) , rock (silicates), and ices (water). Spitzer thus showed the composition of disks are closely related to the composition of planets. 

Read more about these Spitzer Space Telescope spectra of protoplanetary disks:  AA Tau; HH 46; and CRBR 2422.8-3423.

node.title: Planet formation and the early Solar System
node.body:
Having found protoplanetary disks orbiting virtually all young stars, we now have to figure out how planets form in these disks.  Planet formation is still incompletely understood ... many physical processes seem to be involved, and astrophysicists are struggling today to put them all together in a coherent fashion.  Much insight, however, is obtained by studying ancient bodies in our Solar System.  Earth and the other planets have erased their origins, but the small rocky bodies from the Asteroid Belt, a few of which have landed on Earth as meteorites, provide essential clues.  So we model the origin of our own Solar System, and adapt that model to explain exoplanetary systems.

Origin of our Solar System

During the 20th century, this view was elaborated, based on part on study of meteorites (rocks from the Asteroid Belt that have landed by chance on Earth) and interstellar dust.  Meteorites show dust and pebbles from the formation process, and interstellar dust shows spectral signatures of silicates (rock) and soot-like carbon.  These dust particles were ejected into the interstellar medium by red giant stars and collected in molecular clouds in the Galaxy.  When the conditions are right, portions of the cloud collapse due to self-gravity, and stars form (look again Matthew Bate's marvelous computer simulation of star formation in a cloud from Week 3).   Due to swirling motions (called `angular momentum' in physics), not all of the gas and dust can enter the protostar, but orbits the protostar in a protoplanetary disk.  

For our Solar System, conditions in the protoplanetary disk 4.5 billion years ago can not be directly inferred from the larger planets like Earth or Jupiter, but are revealed in smaller ancient bodies like asteroids (most in the Asteroid Belt between Mars and Jupiter, and in the Kuiper Belt beyond Neptune), comets, and tiny dust particles between these bodies.  

        

In this well-accepted planet formation model, dust particles in the disk around the proto-Sun stick together.  Some (for reasons not yet understood) are melted into small (millimeter-sized) chondrules seen in meteorites. You can see these melted chondrules in the photo above right.  Here an ancient meteorite (small asteroid that fell by chance on Earth and was retrieved by scientists) is cut open to show it is made mostly of millimeter-sized melted pieces of rock; these are the chondrules.  One of the problems in modern planet formation theory is we have several models for chondrule melting, but don't know which (if any) is right).

In the protoplanetary disk, the tiny interstellar dust particles and pebbles collide and merge, forming planetisimals on roughly kilometer scales. In the early stages, the merging is caused by sticking; this sticking probably most effective in the cooler parts of the disk outside the snow line (T=273C where water freezes). When the bodies become sufficient large (roughly kilometer size), then gravitational focusing becomes important.  The larger planetisimals grow faster, sweeping all of the rock in a ring around the Sun. After tens of millions of years, only a few large, well-separated protoplanets are left.  Other small bodies are scattered to outer eccentric orbits, as we see today in the Kuiper Belt and Oort Cloud where most comets reside.  The few very largest bodies attract hydrogen and other gas … these become the giant gas planets like Jupiter.  Others remain rocky like Earth and Mars, with a bit of atmosphere from the volatile molecules (like water, methane, ammonia, and carbon dioxide) that was originally in the interstellar dust.  This planet formation scenario is called the core accretion model.    

Here are computer simulations of the merging of planetisimals into several planets during the early stages of our Solar system.  The first movie is by John Chambers at Carnegie Institution of Washington, and the second  movie is by Sean Raymond of University of Bordeaux.  

New models of our early Solar System

In a wonderful series of papers in 2005, Alesandro Morbidelli, Hal Levison and colleagues elaborated on this model for our Solar System at later times (~50-1000 million years after formation).  Now called the `Nice model' after Nice Observatory in France, a sudden instability in the planets occurs: Neptune and Uranus can trade places, and a flood of planetisimals bombard the inner Solar System, causing the mare on our Moon.  

See Levison's simulations of Solar System dynamics according to the Nice model.  A more detailed description of the model is available here.  

Finally, we examine dynamical simulations of the early Solar System that follows water molecules.  In the inner Solar System, inside the `snow line' around 3-5 Astronomical Units, water is vaporized (steam) and cannot enter planetary bodies.  Outside the snow line, the water is solid (ice) and can be in growing planets.  So, it is a puzzle why Earth (and frozen in its polar ice caps, Mars) today has any water at all!! So there is a general problem in getting water on planets in the Habitable Zones.

The Earth and Mars must have inherited water from bodies that had been formed in the outer Solar Sytem, and later impacted Earth.  One possibility is that some of Earth's water comes from comets.  Another possibility is that is comes from planetisimals that bounced around in the early Solar System.  Above are snapshots from a simulation by Avi Mandell, Sean Raymond and Steinn Sigurdsson (Avi was a Penn State graduate student and Steinn is a Penn State faculty member) in 2007.  Here follow the blue representing water-rich bodies, and `HZ' represents the Habitable Zone.  If a Jupiter-like planet migrates inward, then water-rich bodies can also  migrate inwards and impact only an Earth-like planet in an Earth-like orbit.

node.title: Explaining hot and eccentric Jupiters
node.body:
Having established a reasonable model for how our Solar System emerged from its protoplanetary disk, we now see what changes are needed for exoplanetary systems.  Two topics are nicely understood: the origin of `hot Jupiters', and the origin of `eccentric Jupiters'.   The hot Jupiter issue is discussed in more detail in our text, An Introduction to Astrobiology, Chpt. 7.3.  Other issues are still under study and debate; for example, of all the gas giants undergo inward migration, then there should not be any terrestrial planets in the Habitable Zones! 

Planet Migration - Hot Jupiters (Chpt 7.3)

This was the most remarkable observational discovery, starting with 51 Peg in 1995.  Astrophysicists quickly found an explanation:  Jupiters form in the outer disks (around a few Astronomical Units where Jupiter and Saturn lie today), but can quickly "migrate" inward towards the star just after they formed in the protoplanetary disk.  This is due to complicated gravitational interactions between the protoplanet and the gas disk.  Calculations show that, as the protoplanet grows, it produces spiral-shaped ripples in the disk, migrates inwards towards the star, and opens a 'gap' in the disk,  Such gaps are detected in a number of protoplanetary disks.  

Look at several calculations of these effects by astrophysicists.  First, we have a brief animation by Frederic Masset of a Jupiter-like planet forming in a disk quickly (just a few hundred years) migrating inward and forming a disk 'gap'.   Here is another animation by Philip Armitage showing how the protoplanet is expected to form ripples in the disk and opens up the gap.  Masset has a pretty movie of how such a system might look if you visited it with a spaceship.  

Planet Interactions - Eccentric Jupiters, Reversing Migration

In our Solar System, the gas giant planets Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, & Neptune have nearly-circular orbits and lie in the same plane. But we have found that many of the exoplanetary systems discovered in Doppler (radial velocity) searches have Jupiters in high-eccentricity, inclined orbits. Fortunately, astrophysicists quickly found a convincing explanation for these eccentric Jupiters. 

When two or three proto-Jupiters form in a protoplanetary disk and start to migrate, their gravitational interactions can easily become resonant and unstable, as when one planet orbits at half the period of the other (we encountered this phenomenon earlier, with the four major moons of Jupiter). Unstable orbital interactions can easily lead to a cataclysmic realignment of the planets' orbits. From simulations of such systems, theorists find that a frequent outcome is for one of the gas giants to collide with the host star or be ejected from the planetary system; at the same time, the remaining gas giant acquires a high-eccentricity orbit. As most of the planetary systems found so far with Doppler searches have eccentric Jupiter-mass planets, this appears to be a common occurrence, with a relatively small minority of planetary systems having their Jupiters in nearly-circular orbits as in our Solar System. 

Planetary interactions also offer an escape from the relentless forces of planetary migration that tend to draw all young gas giant planets into the inner reaches of their planetary system, with severe consequences for any habitable-zone planets that might be forming there. Specifically, the gravitational interaction of two gas giant planets - for example, our Jupiter and Saturn - can act to halt or even reverse the inward migration of the inner planet (Jupiter, in our case), holding it in place until the protoplanetary disk has dissipated, and all of the protoplanetary objects are either ejected from the system, or incorporated into a planet. Once the disk is dissipated, the forces of planetary migration stop, and planetary orbits are generally stable for the very long term (> Ga). 

Growth and survival of terrestrial planets

The exoplanet discoveries have not given much insight yet into the phases of planet growth where planetesimals collide and merge to form protoplanets, and bombardment continues until most planetesimals are depleted or confined to stable asteroid belts.

The discovery of planet migration as a common process (supported by numerical simulations of protoplanetary disks) raises a big problem when gas giant planets formed in the outer reaches of the planetary system migrate inward: they will push the smaller rocky planetesimals and planets into the star or scatter them out of the system! So planetary systems with hot Jupiters are unlikely to host habitable terrestrial planets. A calculation by John Chambers (bottom animation here) suggests that the planets we see around older stars are just the remnants after many earlier planets spiraled into the star. A calculation by Sean Raymond shows a possible solution: here the Jovian planet migrates partway, allowing some small inner planets to form. As this movie progresses also watch the water shown in blue; water from icy planetisimals can impact the inner planets giving oceans on rocky planets near the Habitable Zone. It is still not clear why some Jupiters spiral in while others don't, and under what conditions inner rocky planets can survive.

node.title: Conclusions: Exoplanets in the Galaxy
node.body:
Astronomers have made remarkable progress in discovering and characterizing exoplanets and the disks from which they emerged.  Astrophysicists are making significant progress in modeling the processes of planet formation and planetary system evolution, although major questions still remain.  Overall, from the 1980s to the present day, astronomy has laid an empirical foundation for the argument that the conditions for life are prevalent throughout the Galaxy.  This is a remarkable scientific achievement.   Here is an outline of what we have learned.

  • We now have direct observational evidence (IRAS, Hubble, Spitzer space telescopes) that most or all stars are born with protoplanetary disks arising from material that had too much spin to fall onto the protostar.  These disks have dust, molecular gases and ices inherited from the interstellar cloud, and these are very similar to the composition of ancient bodies (comets, asteroids) in our Solar System.
  • Astrophysicists have a model where the tiny rock+ice interstellar `dust' particles merge to form pebbles, then boulders, then planetesimals, and eventually protoplanets.  These models are validated by computer simulations, and match reasonably well to properties of meteorites (pieces of asteroids) found on Earth.  
  • Recent surveys of older stars using a variety of sensitive and specialized techniques (radial velocity, transit, microlensing, direct imaging) have found several thousand planets orbiting ordinary stars in our Galaxy.
  • Careful calculations based on the limitations of these surveys indicate that most, or all, stars have planetary systems ... thus most protoplanetary disks successfully produce planets.  And recent (2013-18) estimates indicate that hundreds of millions, or billions, of Earth-like planets in Habitable Zones probably exist in our Galaxy.  

From a broad Galactic perspective, astronomers have learned a great deal how habitable planets arise in the Galaxy:  gasses and dust particles ejected into the interstellar medium from red giant stars; the molecules and dust in molecular clouds; the gravitational collapse of cloud cores to form protostars with protoplanetary disks; the solid particles in the disks merge into protoplanets; the protoplanets may interact with the disk (e.g. migration to form hot Jupiters) and other protoplanets (e.g. eccentric Jupiters); the planetary systems then last for billions of years to be detected by exoplanetary surveys.  

Earth-size and Earth-mass planets are not rare in the galaxy!

With this foundation in empirical astronomical findings, we now turn to Theme V of the course where we ask more speculative questions: Could there be living organisms on these other planets?  Could such organisms be intelligent, even more advanced technologically than us?  Could such aliens have visited us, or could we visit them in the future?  Could there be a Galactic-wide civilization?

node.title: Theme V: Life Around Other Stars
node.body:
We have established quite a lot about the possibilities of extraterrestrial life:

  • Most stars are born with protoplanetary disks, many of these produce planetary systems (e.g. the extrasolar planets found from Doppler wobble and transits), and some of these quite reasonably produce planets in the habitable zone (i.e. liquid water). 
  • The molecular clouds and protoplanetary disks have molecules that lie at the foundation of terrestrial life: H2O, CO2, and a variety of small carbon based molecules (e.g. acids, alcohols, hydrocarbons)
  • The biochemistry of terrestrial life constructs carbon-based macromolecules from these ingredients (cellulose, proteins, DNA) from which a remarkable variety of organisms living in a wide range of environments (extremophiles in ocean vents, hot volcanic springs, in rock, in ice) have developed (archaea, bacteria, fleas, chimpanzees and humans). 
  • The formation of the first life forms on Earth -- the leap from small molecules to self-reproducing macromolecules -- is not yet understood.  But the evolution of increasingly complex and diverse life forms from simpler ones is well-understood. 
  • A wide diversity of sophisticated lifeforms exists on Earth, but there is no advanced life elsewhere in the Solar System, although there is a possibility of primitive (e.g. archaea-type) life on Mars or Jovian moons such as Europa & Titan.  
  • In the past half-century, humans have demonstrated the ability to send robotic probes throughout the Solar System, though not to other stars.  These probes undoubtedly have terrestrial microbes, and thus conceivably could bring terrestrial life to other worlds.  


Based on these findings, during Theme V of the course, we ask questions like:

  • What are the possibilities of intelligent life on habitable planets orbiting other stars?
  • What are the possibilities of us communicating with them (or vice versa) using light?
  • What are the possibilities of us traveling to them (or vice versa) using space ships?
  • Has such interstellar travel yet occurred?  Can we become a space-faring civilization? Have we been visited by aliens?
  • Can there be a Galaxy-wide civilization with closely linked societies on many habitable planets?
  • What is the meaning and context of life in the Universe, both from a cultural viewpoint and from a modern cosmological viewpoint?   

Theme V has several sections:

  1. Drake Equation: How Many Aliens Are Out There?
  2. How Far Away Are the Aliens?
  3. How to Find Evidence of Life on Exoplanets?  [Reading: Chapter 8 of our textbook]
  4. Search of Extraterrestrial Intelligences (SETI)  [Reading: Chapter 9 of our textbook]
  5. Interstellar travel: Very Hard But Not Impossible
  6. Colonizing the Galaxy
  7. UFOs: Have the Aliens Visited Us?
  8. Perspectives on Life in the Universe

node.title: Drake Equation: How many aliens are out there?
node.body:
In 1961, astronomer Frank Drake developed a formula to estimate the number of intelligent species or communicable civilizations in our Galaxy that we could communicate with at this instant of time. The Drake Equation is not a real physical equation (like Newton's equations of motion and gravity), but it is a useful way to organize our knowledge and thoughts regarding the number of cummunicable civilizations in the Galaxy.  We will see that reasonable estimates range from 1 (only us) to 104.  

Ni  = N* x fh x Np x fe x fl x fi x Li/LMW 

Values need to be determined for each factor. Some can be calculated fairly easily, other are only rough guesses. A wide range of information is needed to determine Ni. 

N* = Number of stars in the galaxy.  Current estimates indicate that the mass of the Milky Way Galaxy is (except for distant Dark Matter) around 300 billion (3 x 1011) Mo.  The most common star has M~0.3 Mo.  We estimate there are roughly 300 billion (3 x 1011) to a trillion (1 x 1012) stars in the Milky Way.   This is actually one of the best known terms in the Drake equation!
fh = Fraction of these stars that can host habitable planets.   The width of habitable zones depends critically on both the luminosity of the host star and the atmospheric conditions of the planet.  High mass stars (OBAF) may evolve so fast that intelligent life would not have the time to develop (at least in a way similar to what happened on Earth).  However, these stars are rare.   M stars are most common, and some years ago there was concern that a planet in the habitable zone of an M star would be uninhabitable due to tidal locking and damaging stellar flares.  But it is now widely considered that planets orbiting M stars are reasonable hosts for life forms.   Stars in binary systems with 0.1-40AU  separations will not permit planet on stable orbits in the habitable zone.   Combining all of these ideas, some astronomers might estimate fh~0.5, while others might estimate fh~0.05, where differences stem largely from different ideas of what makes a star a good host for a habitable planet.   While this range may seem large, it turns out there will be much larger uncertainties later on.  Let's take a value of fh~0.1 here. 
Np = number of planets per star. Our own solar system has ~8 planets plus lots of minor bodies.  Based on Kepler and microlensing results, we now are have clear observational evidence that, averaged over all stars, Np>0.5.  Furthermore, a substantial fraction (10-30%) of planetary systems successfully detected with radial velocity, transit, or microlensing have multiple planets (2-7). But these our technologies are still limited: radial velocities can only detect heavier planets in closer orbits, transit searches miss most planets because the orbits are not aligned correctly for the planet to pass in front of the star from our viewpoint, microlensing depends on rare chance alignments of foreground and background stars, and so forth. So the true number of planets per host star must be higher.  Planet formation calculations (e.g. oligarchic growth of planetary embryos) suggest that the most common outcome is likely to be a few to several planets spaced somewhat regularly in a configuration that is likely to be stable for billions of years.   Reasonable estimates might range from Np=1 to ~10 planets per star.  Let's take a value of 5 planets here. 
fe = Fraction of the above planets to have Earth-like conditions suitable for life.  This restricts planets of interest to those with rocky compositions and nearly-circular orbits in the Habitable Zone where water is liquid.  The higher estimates of Np place most of the planets outside of the Habitable Zone, either too close (hot) or too far (cold).  Planetary mass and atmospheric composition play an important role in habitability, e.g. through the carbonate-silicate cycle.  In our own system, 1-2 out of 8 planets are suitable for life for extended periods (say, >1 Gyr).  A handful of the thousands of known extrasolar planets fall within the Habitable Zone, though often with eccentric orbits. Using statistical extrapolation from the Kepler mission sample, several researchers estimate that roughly 1-10% of sun-like stars have planets between 1 and 1.6 times the radius of Earth planets with orbital periods vaguely near the Habitable Zone.  However, there is worry that, although the temperature might allow surface liquid water, the atmosphere may have been evaporated by the host star, or otherwise have a composition inhospitable to life.  Altogether, I suggest an estimate around fe~0.01-0.1; let's assume 0.02 here. 
fl = Fraction of the above "suitable planets" that lead to the development of primitive life forms.  Miller-Urey experiments show that biotic material (e.g.. amino acids, lipids) can arise in an environment like the early Earth.  Simple biotic material may also be brought in by infalling interstellar particles or comets. Life may take a wide variety of forms from sulfur metabolizing, deep-sea vent bacteria to oxygen-breathing animals.  Nonetheless, there has been no success in producing self-reproducing macromolecular systems in the laboratory, so the mechanism of life formation is still unknown and we can not estimate its probability in a scientific or statistical way yet.  The integrated probability over billions of years and over an entire planet is unknown.  The probability of life getting started in a limited time or location might be very small.  Alternatively, the origin of life may be nearly inevitable under the right conditions.  In order to progress, let's assume fl =0.01; that is, one-in-a-hundred planets in the Habitable Zones actually develop simple living organisms. 

fi = Fraction of the above planets with primitive life that develop advanced lifeforms, `communicating civilizations' that can communicate or travel between the stars.  This is a question of the efficiency of biological evolution.  We recall that, on Earth, only unicellular organisms existed from around 3.0 to 0.5 Gyr before the present.  There were a variety of organisms (extremophiles, cyanobacteria, etc) but none were multicellular with different cell types.  That began only at the beginning of the Cambrian Era ~500 million years ago when sponges, jellyfish, worms, etc. began to develop.  We have little understanding of the causes of the Cambrian Explosion, and no way to scientifically or statistical estimate the probability that advanced civilizations will arise from a hypothetical group of planets with life.  So this factor is nearly completely unknown.  In order to progress, let's guess fi = 0.001; one in a thousand planets with simple life develop radio telescopes and space craft.  

L/LMW = Lifetime of communicating civilization / Lifetime of Milky Way.  The lifetime of the Milky Way with stars having sufficiently high metallicity for planet formation is ~10 Gyr (1011 yr). Our radio telescopes have been in existence less than ~102 years (since 1946). So on Earth today, this fraction is extremely small, ~102/1011 = 10-9.  There is no scientific or statistical way to estimate a maximum to this value.   Earth has had human-like mammals that can flexibly adapt their environments for a few million years.   In order to progress, let's use this estimate and assume that advanced civilizations can last a million years, so L/LMW =10-5.
 

OK, let's multiply:

Ni  = N* x fh x Np x fe x fl x fi x Li/LMW = 1012  x 0.1 x 5 x 0.02 x 0.01 x 0.001 x 10-5  

      = 100  ~ 1 to 10 

Of course, we know there is at least one communicable civilization in the Galaxy today --  ourselves -- so a lower limit is Ni =1.  Optimistic estimates for various factors could give Ni  = 106  or more.  A reasonable range is therefore 

Ni = 100 - 106

In summary, we know so little that it is not crazy to consider the possibility of that thousands or millions of intelligent civilizations are now alive in the Galaxy.  But if multiple terms in the Drake equation are quite small, then there might be only a few,or we might be the only communicating civilization in the Milky Way today.  
Similar discussions of the Drake Equation can be found in our textbook (section 6.1.1, less detailed than my treatment) and online at here, here and here.

node.title: How Far Away Are the Aliens?
node.body:
OK, let's make our jargon simpler.  Drake's equation refers to the number of life forms on habitable planets in the Galaxy that are intelligent in the sense that they have radio telescopes.  Most of us have seen `science fiction' movies or read novels about such life forms ... and let's call them aliens just to use simpler teminology. 

We can use our estimate of the Drake Equation to ask the question: What is the average distance between civilizations in the Galaxy?

Consider that most stars lie in the Galactic disk (the Galactic halo has fewer stars and these have lower metallicities, so plausibly fewer planets).  The Milky Way disk is roughly a cylinder with radius R and height h (in light years):

2 pi R2 x h ~ 2 pi (100,000 ly)2 1,500 ly ~  1 x 1014 cubic light years

Then the density of alien civilizations is their number divided by this volume: 

Density of civilizations is = Ni / (1 X 1014) civilizations per cubic light year

If they are randomly distributed throughout the Galactic disk (not necessarily true!), then the 

Average distance between civilizations d = 1 / (Density)1/3 = (1x1014/Ni)1/3 light years

So, if Ni=100, the average distance between civilizations d ~ (1x1014/100)1/3 = 10,000 ly.  For Ni=10,000, d ~ 2,000 ly.  For Ni=1,000,000, d ~ 500 ly.

The distance in light years is the time it takes to send a message in years. Twice this number is the time to send a message and get a reply.  So, meaningful conversations can take place on the timescales of human societies (say, a human lifetime around 100 years) only if one takes extremely optimistic numbers in the Drake Equation resulting in many millions of civilizations.  For less optimistic values, it is possible that civilizations can never meaningfully communicate (i.e. back-and-forth conversation) because the time to send/receive a message is longer than the duration of a civilization. Of course, if Ni=1, we are the only communicable civilization, and there is no one else to talk to.

I would like to point out the nature of our argument here. This is not a philosophical, or subjective, discussion. It is quantitative. We are using arithmetic (Drake's equation), geometry (cylinder shape), and algebra (density estimation) to evaluate a quantity of interest (How far away are they?) for a reasonable range of values representing our empirical knowledge and uncertainty. This is an example of scientific inference -- the scientific method -- at work, even though the result is still uncertain.

node.title: Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences (SETI)
node.body:
If Ni (minus one, ourselves) intelligences exist in the Galaxy at a typical distance of hundreds (optimistic Ni) to tens-of-thousands (pessimistic Ni) light years distance, how do we best communicate with them?  On Earth, advanced organisms communicate by sound waves that travel through air or water.  But in interstellar space, such waves are difficult to produce and travel slowly.  It is best to use light waves that travel at c=300,000 kilometers/second.  Physics tells us that nothing can travel faster than light!  

What waveband should we use?

Let us recall the types of light we can produce and detect, the electromagnetic spectrum:

Sixty years ago, scientists like Frank Drake, Phil Morrison, and Josef Schlovsky asked:  Which wavebands of light are best for communicating across our Galactic disk?

  • Hard X-rays/gamma-rays: Hard to produce, impossible to focus
  • Ultraviolet/soft X-rays: Absorbed by atoms in interstellar gas (and Earth's atmosphere)
  • Optical: Signals overwhelmed by starlight (unless pulsed rapidly)
  • Infrared: Overwhelmed by interstellar & interplanetary dust emission (and Earth's atmosphere)
  • Microwave: Overwhelmed by the cosmic microwave background radiation from the Big Bang that formed the Universe
  • Centimeter-wavelength (1-30 GHz) radio: YES! No problem!!
  • Longer than meter wavelength: Overwhelmed by interstellar electron synchrotron emission
  • Non-electromagnetic radiation: neutrino beams? neutron beams? other subatomic particles? Technologies ineffective or not available to us yet.

So it seems that radio wavelengths are best for interstellar communication.  Large radio telescopes sensitive to centimeter wavelength light are easily constructed (e.g. Arecibo Telescope in Puerto Rico, Very Large Array in New Mexico - photos below), radio waves are easily focused (paraboloid shaped dishes), radio receivers are extremely sensitive for reception, and radio broadcasting is easy (e.g. TV stations, radar at airports). Existing radio telescopes could easily detect a typical terrestrial radio/TV broadcast across the Galaxy -- if it were beamed directly towards us.

 

What frequency should we use? 

Examples: AM band from 0.5-1.6 MHz; FM from 88-108 MHz; TV scattered from 50-1000 MHz, plus police/taxi radios, airport/military radar, satellite communications, etc. Only a few narrow bands are kept quiet for radio astronomy.  Arguments have been made that the best frequency to use is around 1420 MHz (21.1 cm), the emission line of cold hydrogen.  
But the best answer is: "We can not know what frequencies the alien civilizations will use to listen or broadcast their signals".  So we build build receivers that analyze signals from many (million, billion!) channels simultaneously within broad radio astronomical bands. 

How do we recognize an alien signal? 

Criteria might include: narrow band signal at wavelength not produced by atoms & molecules; rapid variations in signal intensity (a message!) but not a radio pulsar; signal seen from star with good lifezone for habitable planets: signal seen in different telescopes (not local interference); periodic intensity or Doppler shifts from from their planet's rotation/orbit; signal contains complex information. 

Could Earth be detected by other civilizations? 

Major emission in centimeter band are military radar (esp. over Alaska and Siberia) and TV stations (esp. over US and Europe). See our text's Figure 9.6 for the daily variation expected in some radio band as the Earth rotates and various radio transmitters rise and set. The Arecibo Telescope could detect these signals out to a few parsecs (tens of stars. Even with our current technology, we could increase sensitivity 100-fold to detect such signals from many thousands of stars. (For example, we could build a large antenna inside a crater on the Moon.) TV broadcasts from 1978 had ~10 million watts power, and are now 20 lightyears (6 pc) away with ~20 A-G-K main sequence stars and hundreds of lower-mass M stars. Now that we know that most stars have planetary systems, and perhaps 1-10% have nearly Earth-size planets in Habitable Zones, it is not impossible that an advanced civilization has already picked up our early radio, television, and radar signals. Indeed, this is the plot of the movie Contact based on the early career of Dr. Jill Tarter, Director of the SETI institute in California. (She is still active, and was a member of the Kepler Science Team.) So the answer to this question is a clear Yes !

A large SETI project: Project Phoenix 

About 1000 solar-like stars within 50 pc have been targeted with Parkes (Australia) 210-foot, Green Bank (West Virginia) 140-foot, and Arecibo (Puerto Rico) 1000-meter telescopes during the 1990s. ~50 million channels at 1-2 Hz resolution between 1-3 GHz (30-10 cm wavelength) are examined for continuous and pulsed signals, including frequency drifts.  Stars with newly discovered planets were included in search. They used private funding because Federal funding was shut off in 1993 by Congress.  They would have required confirmation by an independent observatory required for identifying a candidate extreterrestrial signal.  The main technical challenge they faced was: elimination of human radio interference.  The image below shows frequency (horizontal axis) vs. time (vertical axis) brightness plot with an example of interference.
Excerpt from the Project Phoenix diaries, March 21 2002 at Arecibo (by Seth Shostak, SETI Institute): 
Jane Jordan and I tried not to get too excited. A signal picked up while observing target 4505, a star very slightly dimmer than the Sun that's 117 light-years away, was persistent and passing all the usual tests. We moved the telescope off the star system, and the signal went away. We ran it back on the target, and the signal reappeared. It was looking good. We continued to examine 4505 until the Earth?s rotation took it beyond Arecibo?s field of view, and it looked good all the while.
Nonetheless, we've developed a certain  resistance to easy adrenaline rushes.  The microwave band is increasingly  jammed by interference from orbiting  satellites, so false alarms are common.  As target 4505 drifted out of sight to the west, I wrote in the log book "should be  re-observed." The next night, we did exactly that. This time the signal was seen not only in the direction of the star,  but in other directions as well. Sadly, it was just more earthly interference, and definitely not extraterrestrial. 
One of these days, this small scenario may end differently. And occasionally we think about that.  It's after midnight. Jill Tarter has taken over the observing, so I walk outside the control room to the patio that overlooks the telescope. Overhead, the familiar  winter constellations prick the humid air. Is there more out there than simply the  frigid blackness of space and the silent boiling of the stars? Are there hidden places where the sounds of life are being made and heard? Do beings exist that  can see the universe and understand what they see? It seems impossible to imagine otherwise.

Allen Telescope Array 

Initially funded by Paul Allen, founder of Microsoft Corp with Bill Gates, the Allen Telescope Array of small antennas has been constructed in northern California for full-time SETI search.  This increased SETI observations considerably over earlier levels, but the project is suffering from lack of funds.  Initially planned to comprise 350 6-member dishes, only 42 have been built.   The ATA has four primary advantages for scientific studies over other major radio telescopes: a very wide field-of-view (2.45° at λ = 21cm), complete instantaneous frequency coverage from 0.5 to 11.2 GHz, multiple simultaneous electronic backends, and active interference mitigation. The instantaneous area of sky imaged is 17 times that of the VLA. The instantaneous frequency coverage of more than 4 octaves is unprecedented in radio astronomy.
  
Despite funding problems, the ATA has been operating for several years and is mostly devoted to SETI searches.  It both make shallow scans of large portions of the sky and deeper observations targetted at selected stars.  These include stars near the Sun and stars with known exoplanets (e.g. in the Kepler field).    

The results from all SETI programs over 50 years are clear:  

No extraterrestrial signals have been detected !!  

Not a single convincing alien signal has emerged from ANY SETI observation to date
Nonetheless, the search continues and, some would argue that it should be expanded.  Jill Tarter gives the following analogy: We have only sampled the stars in the Galaxy to the level of a teaspoon of sea water has sampled the world's oceans.  If you don't see a fish in the teaspoon, can you infer that fish don't exist in the ocean?

node.title: Interstellar Travel: Very hard but not impossible
node.body:
This lecture uses some physics and math (algebra level).  
While you do not have to reproduce these calculations,
you should be able to understand the logical flow and the basic results. 

Recall after our Drake equation discussion that the distance to the body-of-interest in the Galaxy is

d = (2x1013/N)1/3 parsecs,

where N is the number of bodies-of-interest.  If we were interested in advanced communicable civilizations, and we had chosen inputs to the Drake Equation that resulted in an estimate of N~104, then N is a relative small number by astronomical standards.  But if we are interested in visiting any nearby habitable planet, N~109, a much bigger number.

Let's assume here an intermediate value of N~106.  Then the equation above tells us that the nearest habitable planet is at a distance of d = 30 parsecs ~ 100 lightyears ~ 1x1018 meters.  Our current spacecraft (e.g. Space Shuttle, planetary probes) travel at a speed around v = 104 m/s, so the travel time would be

t = d/v = 1x1018 m / 104 m/s = 1x1014 sec ~ 3 million years. 

This roughly the age of hominids ... human-like primates roved the savannahs of Africa 3 million years ago.  This is far too long for a convenient visit to a new planet!

The obvious solution is to develop rocket propulsions that give faster speeds, say v = 0.1 c = 3x107 m/s.   Now the travel time would be

t = 1x1018 m / 3x107 m/s = 3x1010 s = 1 thousand years,

which is still very long but not inconceivable.

Let's check whether the human body can tolerate the acceleration and deceleration up to these speeds.  A spacecraft acceleration equivalent to the gravitational acceleration we feel on Earth's surface would be a ~ v/t ~ 10 m/s2.  To reach a speed of v=0.1c would take

t ~ v / a = 3x107 m/s / 10 m/s2 = 1 month,

which is no problem.

Now let's check the power requirements.  Assume the spacecraft has a mass of 100 tons, equivalent to a dozen trucks.  Its kinetic energy is

E = 1/2 m v2 = 1/2 (1x105 kg) (3x107 m/s)2 = 5x1019 watt-sec.

The engine power must thus be at least

E / t = 5x1019 watt-s / 3x1010 s ~ 2000 megawatts,

comparable to a big modern power station that generates electricity for a major city.  (Here I've assumed acceleration throughout the thousand-year trip.) This doesn't seem too difficult ... we obviously know how to build a power station. But how do we fit the power station into a small spacecraft and, more importantly, how do we fit all of its fuel supply into this small volume. Coal, petroleum, even uranium to power the plant for a thousand years cannot fit.

The only choice is to use the most efficient source of energy known, one that directly taps Einstein's equivalence of mass and energy, E=mc2.  For such a fuel, we only need a small mass:

m = E / c2 ~ 5x1019 watt-s / (3x108 m/s)2 = 500 kg,

which is within the mass budget for our interstellar spaceship.

So we can, in principle, build and power an interstellar space ship that will take (only!) a thousand years to reach the nearest habitable planet.  But the only efficient way we know to derive this energy is from the annihilation of matter and anti-matter, and we have not been able to make and transport more than infinitisimal quantities of anti-matter. The giant particle accelerator at Fermilab's Main Injector (underground near Chicago) can accumulate ~10-8 grams of antiprotons/year. If Fermilab uses ~10-4 of modern society's energy resources, it would take 109 years to collect the fuel our spaceship. This is reduced to ~105 years if one could tap all of the solar energy incident on the Earth's surface, and less if one could build a Ringworld or a Dyson sphere to trap a greater fraction of their Sun's energy output. The antiprotons produced must then be cooled with electrons in magnetic traps and (perhaps) stored as solid antihydrogen until needed for flight propulsion. See the analysis Production and trapping of antimatter for space propulsion applications by (former-PSU Physics professor) G. A. Smith & colleagues.

We thus find that it is totally impractical to fuel an interstellar spaceship, even though it is not physically impossible to build it.  Arguments have been made to mitigate this problem; for instance, build a `ramjet' that collects protons (or even some antiprotons) from the interstellar medium as the space ship travels forward.  But designs have always encountered enormous practical barriers.  Another possibility is to build a "sail" that is propelled by reflecting light.  

Indeed, in 2016 a team announced a new interstellar travel project within the goal of sending tiny probes ("gram scale") to Alpha Centauri using a lightsail and arrays of antennas transmitting gigawatt-hours of energy to accelerate them to roughly a 1/6 the speed light.  The project leaders deem this to feasible with realistic technological improvements within a few decades. The initial effort is funded by a Silicon Valley billionaire, and advisory council includes distinguished astrophysicists. See the New York Times article here.

Conclusion:

The distances between existing intelligent civilizations is likely to be >1000 light years, but the distances to neraby habitable planets may only be ~100 lightyears.  It is physically possible for a civilization  to travel such distances if the travel time is long (say 103 yrs).  Is very difficult, but it is not physically impossible. While we cannot build a functioning interstellar space ship today, we know that, at lesat in principle, it is not impossible. Perhaps a more advance civilization, or perhaps in ourselves in the far future, can build one.  

If we were to focus on very small probes and the very closest stars, then it's not inconceivable that humans could send very small satellites to some of the nearest stars within our life times.

node.title: Colonizing the Galaxy
node.body:
Einstein's Special Relativity requires that travel by massive objects occur at sub-light speeds, and light-based communication travels at the speed of light. If habitable planets are relatively common (as recent astronomical discoveries suggest), typical distances between them may be (say) tens of light years. It will thus take decades to send/receive a message, and many/many years to travel between these planets. This would resemble the 17th century when it took weeks for a ship to travel between Europe and the Americas -- but much slower. Meaningful interchange between the home planet and colonies will be ineffective, and colonies will be largely independent. A tightly knit Galactic Empire is thus very unlikely.

Colonizing the Galaxy, however, could occur surprisingly rapidly if interstellar space travel were achieved. Imagine that we or another intelligent species did acquire the technology (and desire) to colonize neighboring habitable planets. Let us guess:

  • The PMXZVQ civilization travels at v=0.1c so it takes 500 years to reach a habitable planet 50 lightyears away.
  • They take 4000 years for the colony to get settled, establish farms and factories, communicate with home base 50 times, and build new spaceships.
  • They proceed onto new habitable planets, reaching the nearest in 500 years.

The civilization would thus radiate outward from its original planet at roughly 50 LY/5000 yrs or 50,000 LY in 50 million years. The entire Galaxy could thus be colonized in 107 yrs. This is only 1/500th the age of the Sun and 0.0001 times the age of the Galaxy -- an extremely brief moment!

Some scholars (e.g. Enrico Fermi, Frank Tipler) use this calculation to conclude that no spacefaring civilization has yet existed in the Galaxy. If it had, Earth would have rapidly been colonized at least once, perhaps many times. Yet we have no clear evidence of ancient or present alien civilizations, and we find no non-DNA-based lifeforms. Maybe we are alone in the Galaxy? Perhaps the development of intelligent life is very rare, or even life itself is rare? This line of reasoning is nicknamed the Fermi paradox (thought it isn't really a paradox, just a logical argument). It is discussed briefly in Chpt 9.5 of our textbook.

A great deal has been said about the Fermi paradox -- `Where are the aliens?' -- mostly empty speculation.  But I can recommend a few contributions:

  • Marcelo Gleiser from Dartmouth College has outlines a few possible explanations
  • A Fermi's Paradox Web site outlines various possibilities
  • The SETI Institute thinks we are alone
  • Alan Stern, a prominent space scientist, suggests the aliens are under ice
  • Nick Bostrom of Oxford University described a Great Filter
  • David Schneider of IEEE Spectrum (an engineering journal) gives possibilities relating to computers
  • A Web site self-styled `We come from the future' gives `11 of the Weirdest' solutions to the Fermi Paradox

Conclusion: Travel between "uninhabited but habitable" planets may be significantly easier that travel between the rare intelligent civilizations, as the discovery of many extrasolar planets indicates planetary systems around solar-type stars are common.  The distances to travel may be ~10 lightyears to ~1000 lightyears.  It is conceivable a civilization could achieve this: one-way invasion/colonization of the Milky Way Galaxy is not impossible.  However, the planets will be largely decoupled from each other, and a meaningful Galactic civilization (government, trade, culture, etc) seems unachievable.

node.title: UFOs: Have aliens visited us?
node.body:
Can people distinguish between science and pseudo-science?

A poll of 1000 adult Americans by the Center for Survey and Research Analysis in 2005 shows that

  • 60% believe extraterrestrial life exists on other planets.
  • 37% believe that houses can be haunted
  • 25% believe people can hear from, or communicate mentally, with the dead
  • 25% think that astrology can affect people
  • 51% said no to the statement: "Do you believe that extraterrestrial beings have visited Earth at some time in the past"  (This view in decreasing in popularity: 41% said No in a 1990 poll, and 38% said No in a 2001poll)

The International Center for the Study of Scientific Literacy reports that 20% of Americans are not sure whether the Sun revolves around the Earth or the other way ‘round.

One should be careful in interpreting survey results.  For example, a non-random Internet survey from a radio show "The X Zone" with 19,000 respondents found 77% believe in ghosts and 93% do not believe astronauts really walked on the Moon.  See Seth Shoshak discussion for details.


See  http://ufoevidence.org for more examples

One can argue that UFOs definitely exist: anything in the air that is not immediately explained is unidentified. Upon investigation, 90% of reports to the Center for UFO Studies end up identified (nocturnal advertising aircraft, Venus or other planets, weather balloons, atmospheric refraction, hoaxes, pranks, etc). Similarly, only a few of the 1000 incidents reported to the 1960s panel headed by astronomer J. Allen Hynek were difficult to explain. These often depended on the testimony of unreliable witnesses (e.g. who make other unsubstantiated and unlikely claims). Lawyers and judges know that eyewitness accounts are often very inaccurate.

It is quite suspicious that the number of UFO sightings are highly variable (e.g. 1966 had 3 times as many reports as 1963, 1952 was 8 times higher than 1951) but the fraction that remain unexplained always remains ~1%, according to the US Air Force Project Bluebook. How could the many people reporting false sightings know that the small number of true UFO sightings has increased or decreased? A more reasonable explanation is that none of the sightings are due to aliens, are 1% are simply completely false or too complicated to easily understand.

One complication is the assertion that the U.S. government has knowledge of UFOs and suppresses it.  Indeed, it's not uncommon for governments or people with political power to try to keep secrets.  However, it's also quite common that such secrets eventually become public.  For example, the Roswell Incident (strange stuff falling from the sky in New Mexico in 1947, early reports of recovery of a large disk) may have a factual basis in secret Air Force research involving aviation and balloon technology which has only recently been declassified. However, there is no evidence that the government is withholding any evidence that UFOs are of extraterrestrial origin.

Another complication is that hoaxes, pranks and frauds are also common among UFO sightings and similar claims for alien presence.  The most famous case (not flying objects) are the British crop circles.  These strange geometric patterns appeared overnight randomly in English wheat and or other crop fields for ~30 years.  Then, in 1991, two men admitted to creating the circles as a hoax since 1978, and they demonstrated their method for journalists (see instructions here).  Thousands of copy-cat patterns appeared worldwide.    See a good presentation of the crop circle story on Wikipedia.  Nonetheless, many fans believe they arise from magical or extraterrestrial causes (e.g. see the million-view YouTube video here).

Recall also that millions of people suffer from schizophrenia and similar serious mental diseases that involve hallucinations.  They often cannot distinguish their internal experience of imaginary phenomena from real experiences of physical phenomena.  Subjective reports can thus be wrong due to honest error, purposeful fraud, or medical disease. 

Here are some further thoughts from the Center for UFO Studies:

About 90%-95% of all UFO reports prove to be IFOs [Identified Flying Objects], after an examination of the evidence by a trained investigator. People report natural or conventional objects as UFOs because they do not recognize them as such, due to unusual environmental conditions, ignorance, or the rarity of a natural event. For example, people have reported the planet Venus as a UFO ... or stars near the horizon. ... Generally, sightings occur in rural areas, small towns, and near military installations.

Returning to Unidentified Flying Objects, there are few unquestionably authentic pictures of UFOs. Many so-called UFO photographs are really natural phenomena (such as strangely shaped clouds) or are light leaks in the camera or flaws that were introduced when the film was developed. Some photos are deliberate hoaxes made by people who want you to believe they have seen UFOs; for any number of reasons, such as fame, money, or to promote a religious or philosophical viewpoint.

Recently, the most significant Radar-Visual cases have come from Belgium where triangular-shaped UFOs were seen by military personnel and civilians and detected on military radar. The Belgian Air Force has publicly aired recordings of radar trackings that show objects making fantastic maneuvers at incredibly high speeds that are far beyond the capabilities of conventional aircraft.  

There is increasing discussion of the possibilities that some UFO sightings are new technology military aircraft.  Here are photos of a few publicly known advanced aircraft from the U.S. military: AGM-129 cruise missile, Boeing X-15A Waverider, Honeywell RQ-16 T-Hawk, McDonnell Douglas A-12 Avenger II (cancelled), and a MZ-3A blimp. The images are from Wikipedia.  These aircraft definitely look odd, and might be mistaken for a UFO.  And there are probably more advanced aircraft being tested that are not yet announced.

         

http://www.ufoseek.com/Alternative_Explanations/Secret_Military_Aircraft/

Despite the lack of success in discovering extraterrestrial signals, all astronomers consider the evidence for many habitable worlds to be very convincing, and thus the possibility of extraterrestrial life (though difficult to quantify) is not necessarily low. Yet nearly all astronomers discount the argument that Unidentified Flying Objects are good evidence for spaceships from extraterrestrial intelligences.  Why such skepticism?  

The main problem is that the evidence for the UFO-alien connection is always so fragmentary. Why are UFO photographs usually blurred or indistinct, or easily altered using Photoshop? Why is there no physical evidence anywhere (even claimed by UFO enthusiasts) for alien materials or technologies? Even a small technological object that could not be manufactured on Earth, or a smudge of complex organic material that is not based on DNA/protein/etc chemistry, could be convincing if it were examined in multiple laboratories around the world.  Instead, we have endless subjective reports or unconvincing non-physical evidence.   In this respect, UFOs resemble claims for parapsychology and ESP, sightings of Bigfoot, the Loch Ness monster, ghosts or (in past centuries) fairies and Leprechauns. We all like stories about imaginary creatures ... but adults generally don't believe they are real.  

In summary, there is no credible or scientifically accepted evidence that alien life forms have visited Earth in recent times. However, `absence of evidence does not imply evidence of absence'; it is impossible to disprove the hypothesis that aliens visit Earth if the visits can leave no tangible evidence. In this sense, the alien UFO hypothesis is not a scientific theory -- it is not falsifiable. However, it is verifiable if any physical material (manufactured or biological) inconsistent with a terrestrial origin were produced associated with a UFO report.

What might realistic alien visitors be like?

From the Drake Equation and our discussion of interstellar spaceflight, we infer that it is possible that the Galaxy has spacefaring civilizations Let's think about what a scientifically plausible alien visit might be like:

  • Very large and massive spaceship capable of v > 0.1 c (c = speed of light) travel and conditions to keep organisms alive for (say) 104 years. Fictional examples from Hollywood of really huge alien space ships include the mother ship in Independence Day and the underwater ship in The Abyss.
  • Spaceship must have more advanced technology than ours, but still obeying physical laws. No Warp Drives or other faster-than-light travel. Probably powered by nuclear fusion, black hole accretion or similar highly efficient energy source based on E=mc2. Ship likely to be heavily shielded against rocket emissions, cosmic rays and interstellar debris. Streamlined shapes are unnecessary.
  • Alien morphology unlike any on Earth. Not humanoid with two arms, two legs and head (e.g. in the movies E.T., Close Encounters of the Third Kind, StarTrek, etc). Not resembling insects, spiders, lobsters or octopi (e.g. H.G. Wells' War of the Worlds, Starship Troopers, Men in Black). They could have any shape and (nearly) any size.
  • Alien visitors are unlikely to be elusive. They are on a one-way trip. If we were the alien visitors to another planet, it is almost certain that we would need to use resources from the new planet in order to continue to survive.  If the planet already had other lifeforms on it (even microscopic), then there could be serious consequences for one or both civilizations.

node.title: Perspectives on Life in the Universe
node.body:
• An overview of the potential for life in the universe from our course
  • The Anthropic Principle: A modern philosophical view
  • Creationism and Intelligent Design
As part of the final Discussion Forum in the Canvas site, you have a chance to contribute your own reflections on the broader implications of what we have learned from this course on Life in the Universe.   How has the course has shaped your views about the the scientific process?  Are there topics that made a stronger impression than others?  Are there topics that were unconvincing?  What do you think about the course's perspective and general conclusions? What do you think about the Anthropic Principle?  What do you think about Creationism and Intelligent Design?

node.title: The view from our course
node.body:
• The Universe formed in a Big Bang 13.7 billion years ago with early conditions leading to protons, neutrons and electrons .... lots of Dark Matter, hydrogen and helium in an expanding space-time.
  • Gravity pulls the matter inwards locally, producing galaxies, stars over billions of years.  The stars fuse H and He to heavier elements like carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, silicon and iron.  The stars eject some of this processed material back into the galaxies, so that new generations of stars can form with chemically enriched protoplanetary disks. 
  • Astronomers see these protoplanetary disks around all stars forming in nearby molecular clouds today.  The disks have the basic molecules of planets and life: silicates and soot for the rocky bodies, CO2+H2O+NH3... for the atmospheres.
  • Astronomers have now detected the resulting planetary systems around thousands of stars using sensitive techniques such as Doppler radial velocities, planetary transits, and microlensing.  We infer that virtually all stars have planets, and that many are Earth-like planets in Habitable Zones where surface water can be liquid.
  • Robotic probes to Mars, asteroids and the outer Jovial systems reveal that liquids are (or were) present in various locations in our Solar System.  Mars once has flowing rivers and seas of water, Europa and other Jovian moons have liquid water oceans under the surface ice, and Titan has a unique ecology of methane+ethane streams and lakes.  No living organisms have been found outside Earth, but these environments conceivably could be inhabited by extremophile-like micro-organisms. 
  • The evolution of life on Earth is now well-understood: the processes studied by Charles Darwin have been spectacularly confirmed by studies of DNA genetic sequences.  All lifeforms share a common heritage with similar biochemistry, cell biology and genetics.  Archaea (often extremophile) bacteria are the most ancient organisms.  But the original formation of a self-reproducing cell from inorganic components on the early Earth is still not understood.  
  • With billions of habitable planets in the Galaxy now inferred from exoplanet studies, the possibilities of extraterrestrial life rests on a stronger scientific foundation than in the past.  However, there is no convincing evidence of extraterrestrial life from any type of study:  astronomical observations (SETI), robotic probes (Solar System), terrestrial studies (UFOs, etc).  
  • We do not know whether we are the only technologically developed life form in the Galaxy, or whether  there are many other advanced alien civilizations.  Either possibility is reasonable.  Interstellar communication between civilizations (ours or others) on proximate habitable planets is not difficult.  Interstellar travel between habitable planets is extremely difficult, but not physically impossible.

In conclusion, life exists in the Universe ... on Earth.  The conditions for life arising elsewhere are widespread: there are lots of similar planets with similar surface conditions and similar chemistry.  But we do not know if extraterrestrial life is indeed present, or whether it has evolved to be technologically advanced on any planet except Earth.

node.title: The Anthropic Principle: A Modern Philosophical View
node.body:
For several decades, some astrophysicists have discussed arguments that the observed conditions of the physical Universe are closely linked in some way to the existence of living organisms such as ourselves. The sizes, masses and ages of objects we see (atoms, living organisms, planets, stars, galaxies, Universe) can all be related to a few basic physical constants: the relative strengths of gravitational, electrical, atomic and nuclear forces; the relative masses of protons and electrons; and parameters of cosmology. The existence of these objects thus places constraints on these elementary physical constants.

"The possibility of life as we know it evolving in the Universe depends on the values of a few basic physical constants—and is in some respects remarkably sensitive to their numerical values.'' (Carr & Rees, 1979)

For example, the existence of life on silicate + water planets requires that:

  • the universal expansion following the Big Bang is tuned to produce long-lived gravitationally collapsed structures.
  • the ratio of light to particles in the Universe is sufficiently low to permit particles to form neutral atoms and permit gravitational collapse of stars.
  • the constants of nuclear physics are tuned to give long-lived main sequence phases of stars and red giants that synthesize heavy elements.

Together, such requirements place stringent constraints on the fundamental constants of nature, sometimes constraining them to with a few percent of their observed values. These arguments can be made in considerable detail. Here are some details:

  • If the expansion after the Big Bang was weaker than we observe (with other cosmological conditions left the same), then the Universe would expand only briefly before recollapsing. Long-lived stars and planets would not have time to exist. If the Big Bang were stronger than it was, particles would be dispersed before gravity could collect them into galaxies and stars. This requires a delicate balance of ordinary matter, Dark Matter and Dark Energy.
  • If the nuclear isotope of lithium 3Li were stable, then the fusion of 4 1H --> 4He would proceed directly and quickly in the cores of stars, and the main sequence phase would not last billions of years.  Since it is not stable, main sequence stars fuse hydrogen to helium via slower, circuitous pathways. 
  • If the carbon nucleus 12C had an energy state just below -- instead of just above -- the energy of a beryllium 8Be energy state, then red giant nucleosynthesis would end at beryllium and heavier elements such as carbon or oxygen would be rare.
  • If Newton's law of gravity were F = GMm/r2.1 rather than GMm/r2.0, then there would be no stable orbits of a planet around a star. 

These arguments are collectively known as the Anthropic Principle. Several variations are discussed (weak Anthropic Principle, strong Anthropic Principle, final Anthropic Principle, etc). Many scientists dislike these arguments intensely: they seem post hoc, where observed phenomena somehow act backward in time on past conditions. How could the existence of humans 13 billion years after the formation of the Universe affect its properties?

But the problems of reverse causation are partly resolved if one considers the possibility of many "Universes", each with different physical properties. Then, life would exist only in those with the necessary conditions; most universes would not have living organisms. The Many Universes Hypothesis (or multiverse) is now considered seriously by some scientists who like to venture into philosphy, e.g. in the context of some theories of quantum relativity and inflationary cosmology.

Please watch the 21-minute TED talk by Brian Greene on the Anthropic Principle and the multiverse hypothesis.  Prof. Greene is a young physicist renown for his clear communication of complex concepts to the public.  

Perhaps the transition from inflation to ordinary expansion results occurs separately in different regions, each of which produces a "Universe" with its own "Big Bang" and unique physical properties? Perhaps there `are' (in some sense of existence) many Universes within which only a very few have the carefully tuned conditions necessary for life. Of course, we must live in one of these rare Universes.  Unfortunately, most such ideas do not yield testable predictions.  Therefore, theories that are untestable are beyond the realm of science and venture into other fields such as philosophy or religion.

node.title: Creationism and Intelligent Design
node.body:
For 150 years, a debate has waged concerning the implications of Charles Darwin's Origin of Species(1859) for the Judeo-Christian belief that God created humankind as described in the Book of Genesis.  William Paley (Natural Theology, 1802) argued that order (e.g. complex organisms) cannot arise from disorder (e.g. simpler organisms) and that Creator is required.  But Darwin's mechanisms of natural selection, as elucidated and confirmed by modern biology (mutation, sexual recombination, genetic mixing, species radiation, etc.), contradicts this claim.  It describes in great detail the development of complex life from simpler life.  Biochemical DNA-based life provides a continuous disequilibrium which, when interacting with complex and changing ecosystems, leads to the emergence of more complex species and the elimination of unfitindividuals.  However, the biochemical evidence does not clearly explain the emergence of the first lifeform.

The debate wages on in the public arena: a recent poll in the U.S. indicates only 44% agree that humans descended from earlier lifeforms, and a law suit was recently argued in a Pennsylvania Federal court whether or not a statement regarding Intelligent Design should be included in a public school scence class.  (The judge ruled against Intelligent Design and in favor of modern biology.)  Many important church councils have formally stated that evolution is not a threat to belief in God (e.g.Humani Generis issued by Pope Pius XII 1950).  Some Christian scholars, often labeled Creation Scientists in the 1980s, argued for the Young Earth hypothesis -- that the world was formed in six days in 4004 BC as literally told in the Bible.  However, the vast majority of scientists believe the Young Earth hypothesis blatantly disagrees with a wealth of scientific results from biology, geology  and astronomy.

Here are some thoughts from creationists:

"We have the biblical concept of a six-day creation, we have the concept of evolution over thousands of millions of years, and we have a number of views intermediate between the two.  Which is true?  Science is the best system devised by man to give us information about nature.  However, the conclusions of science are not final.  Science repeatedly revises and even reverses its conclusions ... [especially when dealing with a past that] cannot be experimentally repeated.   When it comes to answering the great questions of origins, meaning, and destiny, science has lost its credentials.  This happened over a century ago when science decided to exclude God from its explanatory menu.  ... The Bible, on the other hand, takes a more open approach, inviting us to consider nature as well as God ... As such it has a broader base for addressing the questions or origins... Its internal consistency challenges any suggestion that it is a collection of invented stories.  This is not a book that we can easily dismiss. "  Ariel A. Roth in In Six Days: Why Fifty Scientists Choose to Believe in Creation2000

"Take the existence of the Universe.  To call it the result of an 'accident' raises many questions - and answers none.  The same is true of the 'Big Bang' theory.  Where, for instance, did the raw materials come from?  Not even a 'big bang' can make something out of nothing!  The evolutionary idea is widespread, but just as weak; how can 'nothing' evolve into 'something', let alone earth's amazingly complex life forms?"  John Blanchard Ultimate Questions 1987, pamphlet from Evangelical Press handed out on the Penn State campus.

Some Creationists point to complex biological structures like the human eye, arguing that such an amazing organ could never develop through random evolutionary processes, and requires instead divine creation.  But detailed study of the evolution of the eye, from bacteria to primates, shows a long sequence of evolutionary changes.  Indeed, the human eye is not the best for many purposes.  You can hear some of this argument on YouTube: a 5-minute excerpt from Neil Degrasse Tyson's Cosmos television series here, and a longer 45-minute presentation by several scientists here.   

During the 1990s, a more moderate viewpoint known as Intelligent Design was developed by scholars who are both well-schooled in science and in religion.  They generally accept major portions of Darwinian evolution and astronomy; e.g. that the Earth is billions of years old, that 99% of species are now extinct, that all species were not in the Garden of Eden, and that genetic variations (e.g. poodles vs. Labrador dogs) can arise from natural selection.  But they assert that whole species cannot be descended from one another, and that the origin of life cannot have arisen from inorganic chemicals.  They argue that life itself is `irreducibly complex' and requires an intelligent creator, and that nature is fundamentally subordinate to God.

"Can the first self-replicating cell have come into existence by many slight modifications, or was God's intervention necessary through concious design?"  Michael Bahe Darwin's Black Box: The Biochemical Challenge to Evolution 1996

"If nature is all there is, and matter has to do its own creating, then there is every reason to believe that the Darwinian model is the best model we will ever have of how the job might have been done"  Phillip Johnson, The Wedge of Truth: Splitting the Foundations of Naturalism 2000

Biologists argue that even the emergence of first life can plausibly be explained by natural causes and effects: while any one molecular structure is unlikely to transform itself into a specific other structure, real evolutionary change occurs in huge populations under diverse circumstances (Robert Pennock Tower of Babel: The Evidence Against the New Creationism 1999).  For example, the rapid emergence of bacteria resistent to antibiotics does not require Intelligent Design.    Some scientists argue strongly against the intellectual merits of Intelligent Design; here is one who avows a rational ecological ethic:

.".. the time has run out for telling ourselves that we are the darlings of a deity who placed nature here for our convenience.  We are the most resourceful, but also the most dangerous and disruptive, animals in this corner of the Universe.  A Darwinian understanding of how we got that way could be the first step toward a wider ethics commensurate with our real transgressions, not against God but against Earth itself and its myriad forms of life."  Frederick Crews in New York Review of BooksSept/Oct 2001.

Some leaders argue that science and religion can coexist by confining their scope and avoiding the claim that a single framework explains all aspects of human existence.  Stephen Jay Gould, one of the foremost Darwinian scholars, said that science and religion are non-overlapping magisteria equally valuable for investigations of nature and for the pursuit of spiritual values, respectively.

"Science studies how the heavens go, religion how to go to heaven."  Stephen Jay Gould Rocks of Ages: Science and Religion in the Fullness of Life  1999

Humans are "both the products of evolution and the apple of God's eye".  John Haught God After Darwin:A Theology of Evolution 2000

"Pius XII stressed this essential point: if the human body takes its origin from pre-existent living matter, the spiritual soul is immediately created by God"  Pope John Paul II in a letter to the Vatican Academy of Sciences 1997 (quoted by Crews above)

The professional scientific community is unanimous in its rejection of blurring the distinction between a scientific and religious approach to understanding evolution.  Here is the 2005 statement of the American Astronomical Society: 
 

The American Astronomical Society supports teaching evolution in our nation’s K-12 science classes. Evolution is a valid scientific theory for the origin of species that has been repeatedly tested and verified through observation, formulation of testable statements to explain those observations, and controlled experiments or additional observations to find out whether these ideas are right or wrong. A scientific theory is not speculation or a guess -- scientific theories are unifying concepts that explain the physical universe.  

"Astronomical observations show that the Universe is many billions of years old (see the AAS publication, An Ancient Universe), that nuclear reactions in stars have produced the chemical elements over time, and recent observations show that gravity has led to the formation of many planets in our Galaxy. The early history of the solar system is being explored by astronomical observation and by direct visits to solar system objects. Fossils, radiological measurements, and changes in DNA trace the growth of the tree of life on Earth. The theory of evolution, like the theories of gravity, plate tectonics, and Big Bang cosmology, explains, unifies, and predicts natural phenomena. Scientific theories provide a proven framework for improving our understanding of the world.

In recent years, advocates of “Intelligent Design,” have proposed teaching “Intelligent Design” as a valid alternative theory for the history of life. Although scientists have vigorous discussions on interpretations for some aspects of evolution, there is widespread agreement on the power of natural selection to shape the emergence of new species. Even if there were no such agreement, “Intelligent Design” fails to meet the basic definition of a scientific idea: its proponents do not present testablehypotheses and do not provide evidence for their views that can be verified or duplicated by subsequent researchers.

Since “Intelligent Design” is not science, it does not belong in the science curriculum of the nation’s primary and secondary schools.

The AAS supports the positions taken by the National Academy of Sciences, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the National Science Teachers’ Association, the American Geophysical Union, the American Chemical Society, and the American Association of Physics Teachers on the teaching of evolution. The AAS also supports the National Science Education Standards: they emphasize the importance of scientific methods as well as articulating well-established scientific theories.
