node.title: Tips for Succeeding in this Course
node.body:
We want you to enjoy Astro 140 and to do well in it. We do not subscribe to a "weed out" or "pass the best—flunk the rest" philosophy. By the nature of its content, however, Astro 140 is a course that requires your serious academic commitment. You will not succeed by quickly "skimming" the web pages and book chapters. Even "reading" web pages and textbook is not sufficient for most students. You will need to pause, think about what you read and self-assess how well you understand the content. It's a sign of maturity when you can recognize what aspects of the reading will require more study, such as rereading the material more slowly, seeking out an explanations from alternative sources, or asking questions. At Penn State, a credit represents about 40 hours of work, so our 3-credit course will require about 120 hours of your time or 8 hours-per-week during the 15-week semester.

Having no face-to-face classes in a World Campus class has some disadvantages:  the students never meet the instructor or each other.  But there are advantages.  Students need not reside or travel to the Penn State campus; they can live anywhere in the world.  Students do not have to attend class at specific times; all interactions are asynchronous.  This is very convenient for individuals with other important responsibilities.  But the independence provided by World Campus does mean that students must be disciplined in devoting time to the course continuously during the semester.  Duties include: studying course material (on-line lectures, linked on-line material, textbook reading), taking timed quizzes (which must be taken within specified Friday-to-Monday intervals), writing two research papers with specified deadlines, participating in interactive discussions and an on-line research activity.  

Based on our collective experience with past students we offer the following suggestions:

  • Complete all web and textbook reading assignments each week. You are encouraged also to click on other web links and readings; they have been selected to give a richer background on the issues while avoiding overwhelming detail. 
  • Professor Ford is available to answer questions, whether you are working ot better understand the material or eager to learn more about some aspect of the course.  Email him at eford@psu.edu with "ASTRO 140" in the subject line. 
  • We suggest you schedule your study time to allow a few large blocks of time for studying material of this course each week.  Practicing your ability to work intensively for an extended period of time is a skill that will help you in the midterm and final exams, and also more generally in other classes and your work beyond Penn State. 
  • The standards for the course quizzes, papers and project will be clear; in particular, written standards for the course papers will be high.  We will provide specific guidance on how to write a science essay.  It is important to realize that this is quite different from other forms of writing such as persuasive or creative writing. Even if you are already well-versed in some forms of writing, you should expect to work to deveop skill at writing a scientific essay. You are encouraged to interact with Dr. Ford as you research and draft your papers, to focus on clear factual communication and not get overly distracted in details.  Writing a strong essay requires time, often significantly more time than one initially thinks.  Therefore, please be sure to allow significantly more time than you think you will need to draft and revise your papers.
  • Don't fall behind. Procrastination can quickly lead to a situation from which it may be very difficult to recover. Please, do not wait until the last minute to prepare for exams or write papers.  Many students have to work hard to master the material.  That takes time.  If you do not allow sufficient time, then it may become impractical to do well in the course.

Three study habits that will maximize your chances for success in your online class:

1.  Devote sufficient time and effort every week. Time-on-task is a necessary condition for learning. Schedule  blocks of time during each week to study the text, to work on assignments, and to read and contribute to discussions / meetings.

2.  Approach learning reflectively. Be aware of your strengths and weakness as a learner, and spend time each week focusing on areas where you want ot improve. Students  who are able to relate what they learned to situations outside the classroom (real or virtual) are most likely to retain that knowledge. After each lesson ask yourself questions like, "what did I do well?", "what can I improve?", "how did my work/actions affect the people on my team?

3. Review and reinforce your learning each week, looking over the previous week's material, and earlier lessons if appropriate, and connecting it to what you are learning this week. The course outline should help you to place each week's readings in a larger context.

node.title: Introduction to the Solar System
node.body:
Major Bodies

Sun, Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Asteroid Belt, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, Kuiper Belt Objects (including Pluto and other dwarf planets). Below are real-color images of the Sun (left only) and all the planets including the Jovian (gas giant) planets and the terrestrial planets. Note how Earth and Venus are about the same size, while the other terrestrial planets Mars and Mercury are smaller. Note how the outer gas giants are far bigger than the inner terrestrial planets, with Jupiter and Saturn dominating.  The following composite image shows the Sun, planets and principal moons with correct scale in radius, although incorrect scale in orbital spacing.  

  

You can visualize planetary orbits with a digital orrery. Set `Draw orbits' and click `Forward' repeatedly. Note how the inner planets orbit faster ... this is Kepler's Third Law, P2 = a3 (the square of the orbital period is proportional to the cube of the orbit size). The configuration of the orbits right now can be found here.  While the terrestrial planets have few moons (Earth has one large moon, Mars has two small ones captured from the Asteroid Belt), the Jovian planets are orbited by an endless number of small bodies.  See here a table of 174 named moons with links to photos and more information. 

History 

Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn are easily seen with the naked eye and have been known since antiquity. In the late-1600s, Isaac Newton Laws of Motion and Gravity, combined with the methods of calculus he invented, gave a quantitative understanding of the elliptical orbits and masses of the planets and their moons. Uranus was discovered with a telescope by amateur German astronomer William Herschel in 1781, later appointed Royal Astronomer of England.  Neptune was discovered in 1846 in France based on predictions using Newton's celestial mechanics. Astronomers detected small deviations in the Uranus from an ellipse and correctly inferred that the non-elliptical motion was due to the pull of a then-unknown planet. The first asteroid in the Asteroid Belt between Mars and Jupiter, Ceres, was discovered by accident in 1801.  At the time they were considred new planets.  Subsequently, tens of thousands of asteroids have been discovered and have well characterized orbits.  Now, it's obvious that Ceres and other large asteroids fit are more naturally categorized as members of an asteroid belt than as planets.  Altogether, the discovery of the outer Solar System bodies caused tremendous excitement throughout Europe during the 18th and 19th centuries, giving confidence both in the improved technology of telescopes, in the theoretical predictions of Newton's `celestial mechanics', and in the rationality of the world around us.

Beyond Neptune are many minor bodies collectively known as Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs), most discovered since the 1990s. The most famous is Pluto, discovered in the U.S. in 1930 based on perturbations of Uranus' orbit after long searching. Michael Brown (at Caltech in California) and Devid Jewitt (at University of Hawaii) and others have found hundreds of KBOs, and new large surveys are planned to find many more.  A few years ago, the International Astronomical Union `demoted' Pluto from `planet' to `drawf planet' status because several KBOs comparable or larger in size have been found.

node.title: Life on Mars
node.body:
Our LUBS text gives an excellent and detailed treatment of the possibility of life on Mars in Chapter 8.  Please read sections 8.1-8.4.  

Historical Perspective

Enthusiasm for the possibility—even certitude—that life exists on Mars has persisted for centuries. Below left is a typical image of Mars obtainable from a ground-based telescope.  In the late-1800s, Giovanni Schiaperelli claimed he saw `canals', and in a series of popular books, Percival Lowell (1895-1908) proclaimed that they represented constructions of an advanced civilization dying of thirst.  In 1898, author and futurist H. G. Wells wrote a popular novel about an invasion of Earth by technologically advanced Martians.  This was recouped in 1938 in a radio drama by Orson Welles that caused widespread panic.  It was not until NASA's robotic flybys (1960s) and landers (Viking missions, 1970s) that is was completely established that no large forms of life is present on Mars;  thousands of pictures have been returned from the Martian surface, and no Martian animals, plants, footprints or other indications of large life forms is seen. The controversy today is whether there is microbial life, or fossils of past life from an era when the climate was warmer and liquid water was prevalent.

  

Evidence for Liquid Water in Mars' Past

In our class on The terrestrial planets in our Review of our Solar System, we described many surface features of Mars indicating liquid water was present in the past:  streambeds flowing from overfilled craters; craters surrounded by mud flows; dry meandering riverbeds; lake shorelines; gullies around the Valle Marineris canyon system; scarps (cliffs) around the base of Mons Olympus.  Recent rovers making close-up studies of the Martian landscape found ripple patterns in rock; sedimentary layers of rock; carbonates (like limestone) and ball-shaped hematite minerals that can only form under water.  

Read some of the incredible findings about water on Mars released during the last few months including seasonal changes in gullies, a layer of gypsum (calcium sulfate with water, CaSO4-2H2O), and radar indications of a former large ocean. One research group estimates that Mars has been dry for ~600 million years.  See also photos relating to water on Mars in our LUBS text, pp. 271-276.

If water once flowed on Mars, the temperature of its surface and atmosphere must have been considerably warmer than it is today.  This is likely due to an increased greenhouse effect from more carbon dioxide and other gases (water? methane? sulfur dioxide? nitrous oxide?) in the past.  Several causes for the gradual loss of warming atmosphere may be involved:  the ablation (stripping away) of Mars' atmosphere by the Sun's wind; the destruction of water (H2O) by the Sun's ultraviolet radiation and subsequent loss of hydrogen to space; ejection due to the explosions from large asteroid impacts; the end of active volcanism as the planet cooled and crust thickened; changes in the planet's obliquity (axis of rotation).  See LUBS sec 8.3 for discussion of these possibilities, but our understanding of Mars' ancient climate is still quite uncertain and is actively studied today.  

Professor James Kasting in Penn State's College of Earth and Mineral Sciences is one of the world's distinguished scholars studying the atmospheres and climates of the terrestrial planets. Review a talk Jim gave to astronomy undergraduates in 2008 on the early warming of Mars.  

Evidence for Life of Mars

We really have no evidence for life on Mars.  No Martian bunny has been photographed on the surface of the planet.  While sedimentary rocks have been seen, no fossils of ancient life have yet been photographed.  No messages or visits from Martian civilizations have been identified (outside of fictional stories).  But with the clear knowledge that liquid water once flowed profusely on Mars, and the presence of carbon dioxide gas in the atmosphere and carbonate minerals in the rock indicating that organic (carbon-based) molecules were present, and of course the presence of sunlight as an energy source, we satisfy the basic conditions for the emergence of living organisms discussed in our last lesson (General Considerations).  There is, thus, intense interest today in establishing whether life once was present on Mars.

In the late-1970s, NASA launched two excellent probes that landed softly on Mars (although, unlike more recent probes, they did not have wheels and the ability to move) and provided our first close-up view of the Martian surface.  These Viking landers had a robotic shovel that scooped up soil and placed in into three small laboratories specifically designed to search for active life forms (see LUBS p. 281-2).  The results were tantalizing!  When Martian soil is placed into water, it fizzes, absorbing carbon dioxide and releasing oxygen just like green plants on Earth.  However, a mass spectrometer experiment revealed no organic molecules at all.  These apparently contradictory results have been explained as the consequence of the Sun's ultraviolet light irradiating the soil giving rise to suboxide or peroxide minerals.  When placed in water, these materials can absorb carbon dioxide and emit oxygen ... but without any metabolism of living organisms (analogous to the fizzing of a common treatment for stomach distress).  See more details from the Encyclopedia of Science website.

  

There is one other curiosity.  Telescopes in Hawaii have taken infrared spectra of the Martian atmosphere for many years.  In 2003, methane was seen over localized regions of the northern hemisphere during its summer.  Methane on Mars should be rapidly (few years) destroyed by solar ultraviolet ... so where did it come from? Is it from the ancient atmosphere, trapped in the rock for billions of years and suddenly released?  Or, as on Earth, is the methane generated by microbial life?  This puzzle has not been solved.  A new probe by NASA, the Mars Science Lander (nicknamed Curiosity), is on its way to Mars and should land in August 2012.   It has a variety of advanced experiments specifically to look for microbial life.

node.title: Habitability of Icy Moons
node.body:
This commentary accompanies Chapters 4 and 5 of our text, An Introduction to Astrobiology

Section 4.1: Introduction

This is a long introduction to the outer icy moons of the Solar System that you do not have to read in great detail.  I covered this on a simpler level in the Review of the Solar System class.  The photos of the moons are excellent (Figures 4.4-7 and 4.10-12) as well as the models of their interiors (Figures 4.13-14).  The surfaces show enormous variation: from ancient cratered ice to young smooth icy, to stange patterns from (re)melting episodes and volcanoes on Io.  

I entirely agree with the first sentences of the chapter:  prior to the fly-by missions of the Voyager probes in the 1980s, there was little expectation of liquids needed for life anywhere in the Solar System beyond Mars. The reason is simply temperature: the Sun's light is so faint at these distances that no body's surface can reach the melting temperature of water.  Scientists expected that the moons would either be rocky like the asteroids, or icy with ancient frozen surfaces, showing only craters from many asteroid impacts.  Jupiter's biggest moon, Callisto (Fig 4.10), is a good example of this, as well as many smaller Jovian moons.  

It was thus a big surprise when Voyager found several moons with young, active surfaces, showing few impact craters. Understanding these moons was a major motivation for the complex and expensive missions of the 2000s: the NASA's Galileo probe, which orbited within Jupiter's system, and European Space Agency's (ESA's) Cassini mission that is still orbiting within Saturn's system.  Jupiter's innermost moon, Io, nearly entirely melted by tidal stresses, has many active volcanoes that perpetually cover the surface with new material.

Section 4.2: Europa 

But it was Jupiter's moon Europa (and similarly, Ganymede) that seemed most relevant to the search for life in the Solar System. It has a water ice surface like Callisto, but very few craters.  The reflective surface must have been melted and refrozen.  The strange grooves, rough patches, and multicolored ice suggest that this melting is a recurrent process, not from a single violent event. Dark ice fills some grooves and patches on the surface (photo below and the many figures in the text).  This suggests that the ice covering is not very thick, and liquid (or slushy) water lies below and wells up when the surface cracks.  The rough patches on the surface (chaotic terrain) may be the product of ice plates grinding against each other, similar to mountain-building on Earth due to plate tectonics. 

This requires that Europa have a liquid water layer beneath a relatively thin ice crust.  This is supported by the presence of a weak magnetic field around Europa.  What keeps it above freezing temperature?  Perhaps it is tidal forces (weaker than Io's) due to its slightly elliptical orbit and perturbations by other moons.  Perhaps large impacts episodically melt the interior.  The thickness of the ice crust and the water ocean is quite uncertain; below are two models for Europa's interior.  NASA engineers and scientists have conceptually designed a mission that would land on Europa with a probe that would melt its way through the ice and swim in the hidden ocean.  But this ice-penetrating robot mission has not been approved by NASA or Congress.

Section 4.2 on Europa is 24 pages long, and you do not have to know it all.  However, in Quiz #3 I will ask for a 1 paragraph essay about Europa's surface which you should prepare in advance from this section.  Detailed information and explanation will be expected.

Section 4.5: Other icy moons

Jupiter's moon Europa is not the only one that appears to have melted interior.  Neptune's moon Triton is bizarre, half covered with an ancient cratered surface and have with a smooth uncratered surface.  Perhaps it collided with another moon and partially melted.  Saturn's moon Enceladus shows some craters, but also has discolorations and grooves.  Here the Cassini probe has photographed geysers (essentially water volcanoes) along a long ridge.  As with Europa, this can be explained only if the surface ice is relatively thin and a (partially) melted layer lies below.  Here are some photos of Enceladus.

  

Chapter 5: Titan 

         

We finally come to Saturn's moon Titan, the largest in the Solar System.  It was already known from ground-based studies that it is the only moon with its own atmosphere, mostly nitrogen (N2) with some methane (CH4) and other hydrocarbons.  Take a look at its spectrum in the infrared band shown in Figure 5.8, and recall our discussion early in the semester how different molecules have rotational and vibrational states defined by quantum mechanics.  The complicated jagged spectral features are from transitions between these quantized states, and from the spectrum astrochemists can determine the composition of Titan's atmosphere.  The answer is given in Table 5.3.  

Section 5.3 then describes how many of these molecules can be formed from a simpler original composition of (say) methane.  Some of the chemical reactions would commonly occur on Earth, such as the conbining of two methanes to form ethane (equation 5.5).  But other reactions require more unusual molecules such as CH (equation 5.6).  These arise when chemical bonds are broken by ultraviiolet light from the (rather faint and distant) Sun.  Reactions involving CH lead to other rarer species such as ethene and ethyne (equation 5.6), and then long chain hydrocarbons (eequations 5.9-5.10).  

Chemists know a lot about such molecules, including the pressures and temperatures where they are in gaseous, liquid or frozen states (see Box 3.3 on p. 92). The pressure and temperature structure of titan's atmosphere was directly measured by the Huyghens probe launched onto the surface by the Cassini satellite in 2005 (Figure 5.13).  Combining laboratory  measurements of these chemicals with the Titan atmosphere measurements, we find that methane (CH4) and ethane (C2H6), which are in high abundance in the atmosphere, should be liquid at Titan's surface temperature and pressure.  This explains why the Cassini mission found liquid streams and lakes on Titan: methane-ethane lakes evaporate, producing methane-ethane clouds that rain, forming streams that flow back into the lakes ... just like water on Earth has lakes and oceans that evaporate, produce rain that forms rivers that flow back into the oceans (section 5.4.1).  

                 

Thus, chemistry and astronomy together explain the remarkable liquids on Titan's surface.  The surface cannot be seen in visible light due to the thick clouds, but the Huyghens probe took a few photos as it pararchuted onto the surface (section 5.4.3) and the orbiting Cassini satellite obtains detailed maps of the surface in infrared light and radar reflectance (section 5.4.4).  I find these images to be totally amazing!  On Earth, liquid methane is called LNG, liquified natural gas, and is used as a fuel.  Titan seems to have a full climate with polar methane ice caps, methane clouds and rainstorms, rivers and lakes, and dunes.  Cassini has traced a seasonal cycle involving warming with lake evaporation, and cooling with expanding ice caps.  

Finally, our text explains that methane cannot survive long on Titan due to photodissociation (breaking apart) by solar ultraviolet (section 5.4.1).  So there should be some source of methane to continuously replenish the atmosphere and lakes (section 5.4.5).  One possibility, still not confirmed, is volcanoes releasing methane from the moon's interior.  While we are not sure this is occurring, we do see cryovolcanoes (ice-volcanoes) on Neptune's moon Triton, and of course on Jupiter's Io. 

Life on Titan?

One can only speculate whether life can arise on Titan's surface where the temperature is around 90o K (ninety degrees above absolute zero).  Recent laboratory experiments (similar to the Miller-Urey experiments for early Earth) indicate that amino acids and nucleic acids, critical components of proteins and DNA, could form if the temperature were hotter.  Astronomers note that, in a few billion years, the Sun will become a red giant star, boiling water on Earth but warming Titan to more habitable temperatures.  Altogether, after Earth, Titan seems to have the best chance for life in the Solar System with a solid surface, carbon-rich chemistry, a liquid solvent, and ecological variety.  NASA recently approved funds for preliminary study of a Titan Mare Explorer that would splash-land in one of its methane lakes and study its chemistry.      

We thus find that, contrary to any reasonable expectation before detailed study with robotic probes, that some Jovian moons have liquid on (or close to) their surfaces.  Europa and similar moons have water oceans below their ice coverings, and Titan has incredible liquid hydrocarbon lakes on its surface.

It is likely that, in coming decades, humans will send more probes to the icy moons of the outer Solar System to study them further ... and look for primitive live forms.

node.title: The Anthropic Principle
node.body:
For several decades, some astrophysicists have discussed arguments that the observed conditions of the physical Universe are closely linked in some way to the existence of living organisms such as ourselves. The sizes, masses and ages of objects we see (atoms, living organisms, planets, stars, galaxies, Universe) can all be related to a few basic physical constants: the relative strengths of gravitational, electrical, atomic and nuclear forces; the relative masses of protons and electrons; and parameters of cosmology. The existence of these objects thus places constraints on these elementary physical constants.

"The possibility of life as we know it evolving in the Universe depends on the values of a few basic physical constants—and is in some respects remarkably sensitive to their numerical values.'' (Carr & Rees, 1979)

For example, the existence of life on silicate + water planets requires that:

  • the universal expansion following the Big Bang is tuned to produce long-lived gravitationally collapsed structures.
  • the ratio of light to particles in the Universe is sufficiently low to permit particles to form neutral atoms and permit gravitational collapse of stars.
  • the constants of nuclear physics are tuned to give long-lived main sequence phases of stars and red giants that synthesize heavy elements.

Together, such requirements place stringent constraints on the fundamental constants of nature, sometimes constraining them to with a few percent of their observed values. These arguments can be made in considerable detail. Here are some details:

  • If the expansion after the Big Bang was weaker than we observe (with other cosmological conditions left the same), then the Universe would expand only briefly before recollapsing. Long-lived stars and planets would not have time to exist. If the Big Bang were stronger than it was, particles would be dispersed before gravity could collect them into galaxies and stars. This requires a delicate balance of Dark Matter and Dark Energy.
  • If the nuclear isotope of lithium 3Li were stable, then the fusion of 4 1H --> 4He would proceed directly and quickly in the cores of stars, and the main sequence phase would not last billions of years.
  • If the carbon nucleus 12C had an energy state just below -- instead of just above -- the energy of a beryllium 8Be energy state, then red giant nucleosynthesis would end at beryllium and heavier elements such as carbon or oxygen would be rare.
  • If Newton's law of gravity were F = GMm/r2.1 rather than GMm/r2.0, then there would be no stable orbits of a planet around a star. 

These arguments are known as the Anthropic Principle. Several variations are discussed (weak Anthropic Principle, strong Anthropic Principle, final Anthropic Principle, etc). Many scientists dislike these arguments intensely: they seem post hoc, where observed phenomena somehow act backward in time on past conditions. How could the existence of humans 13 billion years after the formation of the Universe affect its properties?

But the problems of reverse causation are partly resolved if one considers the possibility of many Universes, each with different physical properties. Then, life would exist only in those with the necessary conditions; most universes would not have living organisms. The Many Universes Hypothesis (or multiverse) is now considered seriously by astrophysicists in the context of the latest theories of quantum relativity and inflationary cosmology. Perhaps Universes emerge from some quantum foam of virtual Universes? Perhaps the transition from inflation to ordinary expansion results occurs separately in different regions, each of which produces a Big Bang with different properties? Perhaps there `are' (in some sense of existence) many Universes within which only a very few have the carefully tuned conditions necessary for life. Of course, we must live in one of these rare Universes. 

The anthropic principle is briefly discussed by LUBS pp. 69-70.

node.title: Galaxies: The Home of Stars and Planets
Interlude: Understanding Molecules
node.body:
To pursue our study of live in the universe, we first need to introduce some concepts and information about atoms, molecules and light. `Atoms' are tiny entities with a dense nucleus of protons and neutrons surrounded by a cloud of electrons. The number of protons defines the element: 1 = hydrogen, 2 = helium, …, 6 = carbon, 7 = nitrogen, 8 = oxygen, …, 26 = iron, and so on. A collection of atoms can be called a gas cloud.

When the cloud is hot, two atoms that collide will bounce off each other because the electron clouds (both negatively charges) repel each other. But when a cloud is cold and the collisions are slow and the two atoms can form a weak, but stable, bond. This occurs when the attraction of the protons is slightly stronger than the repulsion of the electrons. These entity of two or more atoms bonded together is called a `molecule'. `Chemistry' is the science devoted to the behavior and reactions between molecules.

                

The bonds between atoms in a molecule are not entirely fixed. They can stretch and bend in various ways (see fun moving diagrams). Even at very cold temperatures, the molecules can rotate. But the behavior of atoms and molecules is not like the behavior of large objects we experience in our daily lives. Large objects can move in a smooth fashion where any energy is possible. But tiny objects follow the rules of `quantum mechanics' and can be in only a fixed number of distinct energy states. A rotating or vibrating molecule can change its energy state by emitting or absorbing a particular wavelength of light. These wavelengths are generally not in the visible band, but have longer wavelengths in the infrared and microwave bands.

Thus, astronomers can observe the sky using specialized telescopes and look for emission or absorption lines at particular wavelengths associated with the quantum transitions of specific molecules. Even for simple molecules, these patterns of spectral lines can be very complicated, often blurring together to form messy bands. But they are unique for each molecule: just as a crime investigator can identify a person from a unique fingerprint, an astronomer can identify a molecule from its unique pattern of microwave and infrared emission lines. The study of the spectral lines and patterns produced by different molecules is called "molecular spectroscopy."

Here are infrared spectra for three common molecules: water, carbon dioxide, and ethanol (the alcohol in wine and beer). To show why this is relevant to our search for live in the universe, we show the infrared spectra of three familiar planets in our Solar System. We see that Venus, Earth and Mars all have carbon dioxide in their atmospheres, but only Earth has abundant water and oxygen (inferred from it chemical byproduct, O3 or ozone).

 

To discover the molecular material from which planets (and eventually living organisms) form, we have to study the sky with infrared and microwave telescopes. Below are photos of important telescopes at the three bands: the Gemini telescope on a Hawaiian mountaintop for visible wavelengths, the Spitzer Space Telescope orbiting the Earth at infrared wavelengths (two photos), and the ALMA (Atacama Large Millimeter Array) now being built on a mountaintop in Chile.

node.title: Cosmology: The Story of the Universe
node.body:
Cosmology: The story of the Universe

We first lay the foundations of Life in the Universe by discussing the Universe as a whole, its origins in a Big Bang ~13 billion years ago and its history until the present day. Big Bang cosmology began in the early-20th century, was largely confirmed by the late-20th century, and is now in an era of detailed investigation, establishing the parameters of the model to ~1% precision.

Modern cosmology is full of unexpected and unintuitive features: a universal expansion (similar to blowing up a balloon); its contents dominated by mysterious Dark Matter and Dark Energy; a clear explanation for the formation of the simplest elements (hydrogen and helium), and the formation of stars and galaxies.

All societies have a cosmology … an explanation for the origin and development of the world around us. In many traditional cultures, the world is created by deities, gods and goddesses. The previous lecture outlined the rise of modern science, starting with Isaac Newton's mathematical relationships defining the motions and gravitational interactions of physical objects.

A brilliant young scientist named Albert Einstein made profound changes to Newtonian physics. First, in 1905, he showed that Newton's laws of motion do not hold when speeds approach the speed of light. He then struggled for a decade to understand gravity in his new context, emerging with the theory of General Relativity in 1915. Based on the view that massive bodies alter the geometry of 4-dimensional space-time, Einstein's General Relativity gives a full and accurate explanation of the gravitational attraction between bodies. The mathematics was quickly applied to the universe as a whole by the Russian physicist Alexander Friedmann and Belgian astronomer Georges Lemaitre. He found that the theory predicts that the Universe should not be static: it should either expand or contract following specific mathematical formulae. Remember that this is not a vague idea, but a rigorous mathematical derivation based on Einstein's General Relativity.

 

In the early 20th century, astronomers knew only about stars relatively near the Sun in the Milky Way. But there were some blurry objects in the sky known as `nebulae'. Around 1920, a talented American astronomer names Edwin Hubble used a giant new telescope in California to obtain improved photographs of the nebulae. Some appeared to be huge, but very distant, structures similar to the Milky Way. With repeated observations of the nebula Messier 31 in the Andromeda constellation, Hubble demonstrated it was a distinct `island universe', or galaxy. He and others photographed many other galaxies.

Astronomers obtained spectra of these galaxies to measure their motions towards or away from us based on the Doppler shift. To everyone's amazement, nearly all galaxies showed a redshift indicating they are all moving away from us. Furthermore, the redshift is greater for more distant galaxies, following a linear relationship v = Ho d (Hubble's law). The only reasonable interpretation for all galaxies moving away from us in a linear fashion is that space itself is expanding, much like the rubber surface on a balloon expands as it is inflated. The diagrams below show the original data available to Hubble, a modern dataset combining data from several methods for estimating galaxy distances, and the `raisin bread' analogy to explain the redshift law. By the middle of the 20th century, nearly all astronomers acknowledged that we reside in an expanding universe that follows the predictions of Einstein's General Relativity.

If the universe is really expanding, then the galaxies were closer together and the average density of matter was higher in the past. Extrapolating to earlier times, there must be some instant when the expansion began, after which the density of the universe was extremely high. High densities imply high temperatures for normal matter. When dense matter is hot it radiates light with a `blackbody' spectrum. So the expanding universe model predicts:

  • the universe was formed in a Big Bang at a single instant. With the latest measurement of Hubble's contestant, H0=73 km/s/Mpc and other parameters, the Big Bang occurred about 13.7 billion years ago.

  • the early universe just after the Big Bang was filled with light and particles at extremely high temperatures

  • the Universe should be suffused with light from the Big Bang following a black body spectrum

In the 1950s, physicist George Gamow calculated that the light from the Big Bang should cool as the universe expands, and should be a few degrees above absolute zero today. In the mid-1960s, this cosmic light was discovered, by accident, by Arno Pensias and Robert Wilson. They were working for Bell Laboratories (the U.S. telephone company) to investigate why static was present on long-distance telephone calls that used microwave signals. They found that the entire sky was the source of the radiation. This `cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation was immediately associated with Gamow's predicted light from the Big Bang.

The discovery of the CMB was a powerful confirmation of the Big Bang model for the expanding universe. It was found to have exactly a blackbody spectrum with T=2.735 K, about 3 degrees above absolute zero. Other predictions of the model were also validated during the 1960s-70s. Exactly 24% of the hydrogen was converted to helium, with trace amounts of deuterium, lithium and beryllium isotopes. The age of the oldest stars is close to the 13.7 billion years since the Big Bang.

Today, detailed studies of the CMB, galaxies, galaxy clusters, and other extragalactic phenomena (such as quasars and gravitational lensing) all support a particular version of the Big Bang model. Here only 4% of the `stuff' in the universe is regular matter: molecules made up of atoms, themselves made up of protons, neutrons and electrons. 72% is composed of a mysterious `Dark Energy' that is accelerating the universe's expansion, and 23% is comprised of a different mysterious Dark Matter that slows the expansion. However, many of these fascinating findings of modern cosmology do not directly affect our understanding of Life in the Universe. We will concern ourselves here only with regular matter from which stars, planets and biospheres are made.

node.title: The Milky Way Galaxy
node.body:
Galaxies: The home of stars and planets

Even though the Universe has been expanding since the Big Bang, dispersing the atoms and cooling the light, gravity is still present. On local scales, atoms attracted each other, forming early stars and then galaxies. We have little observational knowledge about this phase of the Universe's history, hence its nickname `the Dark Ages'. It lasted roughly from 1 million to 1 billion years after the Big Bang, or the first few percent of the Universe's current age. Astrophysicists argue that an early generation of stars formed during this time, quickly going supernova and polluting the gas with small amounts of elements heavier than helium. Detailed models show that gravitational attraction (involving both Dark Matter and regular matter) produced dense sheets and filaments that then collapsed to form galaxies and galaxy clusters. Big galaxies cannibalize smaller ones, and mergers of big galaxies are common. Massive black holes formed at the center of most galaxies at the same time.

Take a look at recent computer simulations of gravitational collapse in the expanding Universe. These are very complicated calculations based on the latest cosmological model (with Dark Matter and Dark Energy) requiring the world's most powerful computers.  The first movie (1 min) shows a calculation the formation of large-scale structure from the University of Chicago. The second movie (2 min) is a similar calculation from University of California showing good agreement with the latest observations from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey.

While galaxy collisions still occur occasionally today, ~12 billion years after the violent Dark Ages, most galaxies are quiet and stable, serenely spinning through space. Most large galaxies have a flattened disk with a pinwheel pattern of `spiral arms' where stars and planets form. See the photos above of nearby spiral galaxies, including own Milky Way Galaxy. Because the Sun lies in the disk of our Galaxy, we cannot see its structure as we can with distant face-on galaxies. We study the detailed formation of stars and planets in the nearby spiral arms of our Galaxy.

A composite photo of our Galaxy as seen from Earth is shown above.  Note the similarity to NGC 891, another spiral galaxy seen edge-on. Below is an artist drawing, consistent with modern observations, showing our Galaxy  as it would appear if seen face-on.  Note the Sun is about 25,000 light-years (8000 parsecs) from the center, and lies between two spiral arms. The central region of the Galaxy has a large bar, and a modest 3x106 Mo massive black hole lies at the very core.

The Interstellar Medium

The images of the Milky Way (above) and other galaxies (previous page) were made in visible light, the waveband where the surfaces of stars shine. Their temperatures are thousands of degrees Kelvin (above absolute zero). But the dark clouds where stars and planets form are much colder, only tens or hundreds of degrees Kelvin. These `shine' in the microwave and infrared bands of light, and in particular exhibit the emission lines and bands produced by particular molecules. Read the `Sidebar: Understanding molecules' (next page) for background.

Interstellar clouds nearby in the Milky Way can be oddly beautiful in photographs. The first two images below show the Eagle Nebula and the Orion Nebula in visible light, as seen with the Hubble Space Telescope. The Eagle shows dark pillars of cold gas and dust illuminated by a nearby hot star. A few stars (probably with planets) are forming now in these pillars. Orion recently (about 1-2 million years ago) formed a rich cluster of stars (probably with planets). The dark cloud is behind the cluster, and the edge is brightly shining due to heating by the hottest Orion stars. The third image a much larger cloud as viewed in the infrared with the Spitzer Space Telescope. The light here is from vibrations of soot-like hydrocarbon molecules. The final image below shows recent research maps of two emission lines of the ammonia molecule (NH3) in a small dark cloud that is likely to form stars soon.

 

 

 

The result of several decades of molecular spectroscopy of interstellar clouds has shown an amazing variety of molecules in a gas that is mostly hydrogen (H2) and helium. Most of these molecules are organic; that is, they containing carbon. Some are quite simple molecules: carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), hydrogen cyanide (HCN). But others are more complex: ethane (C2H6), ether (CH3OCH3), ethanol (CH3CH2OH), acetone (CH3CH3CO), acetic acid (CH3COOH), a simple sugar (CH2OHCHO), antifreeze (HOCH2CH2OH), and controversially, possibly an amino acid (NH2CH2COOH). Some interstellar molecules are not organic (that is, without carbon): water (H2O), nitrogen (N2), ammonia (NH3), hydrochloric acid (HCl), salt (NaCl), sulfur dioxide (SO2), and so forth. Some molecules happen to have emission lines at wavelengths that are technically difficult to detect. This is the reason that the oxygen molecule (O2) was not discovered until 2011 using the new Herschel Space Telescope.

See an up-to-date list of interstellar molecules at The Astrochymist Web site. Browse this fun site, such as the `Astromolecule of the Month'.

node.title: Sidebar: Understanding Molecules
node.body:
To pursue our study of live in the universe, we first need to introduce some concepts and information about atoms, molecules and light. `Atoms' are tiny entities with a dense nucleus of protons and neutrons surrounded by a cloud of electrons. The number of protons defines the element: 1 = hydrogen, 2 = helium, …, 6 = carbon, 7 = nitrogen, 8 = oxygen, …, 26 = iron, and so on. A collection of atoms can be called a gas cloud.

When the cloud is hot, two atoms that collide will bounce off each other because the electron clouds (both negatively charges) repel each other. But when a cloud is cold and the collisions are slow and the two atoms can form a weak, but stable, bond. This occurs when the attraction of the protons is slightly stronger than the repulsion of the electrons. These entity of two or more atoms bonded together is called a `molecule'. `Chemistry' is the science devoted to the behavior and reactions between molecules.

                

The bonds between atoms in a molecule are not entirely fixed. They can stretch and bend in various ways (see fun moving diagrams). Even at very cold temperatures, the molecules can rotate. But the behavior of atoms and molecules is not like the behavior of large objects we experience in our daily lives. Large objects can move in a smooth fashion where any energy is possible. But tiny objects follow the rules of `quantum mechanics' and can be in only a fixed number of distinct energy states. A rotating or vibrating molecule can change its energy state by emitting or absorbing a particular wavelength of light. These wavelengths are generally not in the visible band, but have longer wavelengths in the infrared and microwave bands.

Thus, astronomers can observe the sky using specialized telescopes and look for emission or absorption lines at particular wavelengths associated with the quantum transitions of specific molecules. Even for simple molecules, these patterns of spectral lines can be very complicated, often blurring together to form messy bands. But they are unique for each molecule: just as a crime investigator can identify a person from a unique fingerprint, an astronomer can identify a molecule from its unique pattern of microwave and infrared emission lines. The study of the spectral lines and patterns produced by different molecules is called `molecular spectroscopy'.

Here are infrared spectra for three common molecules: water, carbon dioxide, and ethanol (the alcohol in wine and beer). To show why this is relevant to our search for live in the universe, we show the infrared spectra of three familiar planets in our Solar System. We see that Venus, Earth and Mars all have carbon dioxide in their atmospheres, but only Earth has abundant water and oxygen (inferred from it chemical byproduct, O3 or ozone).

 

To discover the molecular material from which planets (and eventually living organisms) form, we have to study the sky with infrared and microwave telescopes. Below are photos of important telescopes at the three bands: the Gemini telescope on a Hawaiian mountaintop for visible wavelengths, the Spitzer Space Telescope orbiting the Earth at infrared wavelengths (two photos), and the ALMA (Atacama Large Millimeter Array) now being built on a mountaintop in Chile.

node.title: Stars: Energy for Life
node.body:
On Earth, scientists study the complicated interactions in the world around us, often tracing `cycles' that show how some feature begins, develops, and ends. Some involve physical components (such as the `water cycle': evaporation of water from the oceans, with rain and rivers bringing water back, while some is captured in glaciers and ice caps) while others involve living organisms (such as the life cycle of a human from birth through childhood, adulthood, aging, and death). Similarly, astronomers can trace the physical cycles and interactions in a Galaxy, and of its components (such as the interstellar medium, stars and planets). Here we discuss the life cycle of individual stars. Stars are crucial for life in the universe, as without their heat, planets would be much too cold to sustain life.

Star Formation

We have seen that, in a spiral galaxy like the Milky Way, a complicated `interstellar medium' resides in the space between stars. It consists of gases (mostly hydrogen and helium from the Big Bang, with a soup of interesting molecules) and tiny solid `dust grains' (some made of rock like tiny sand grains, others made of carbon like soot). As a spiral arm passes through a region in the Galaxy, the interstellar material is compressed and dark cold clouds form. When a cloud of interstellar medium is dense enough, gravity locally dominates other forces and a star forms by `gravitational collapse'. Material with too much spin forms a flattened disk orbiting the protostar; this is the `protoplanetary disk' where planets form. The star and disk formation process is complicated, and astrophysical modeling is underway. Thus stars, planets, and any life on these planets inherit their molecules from the interstellar medium.

Look at the recent computer simulations of the star formation process in a small interstellar cloud by Matthew Bate. The gas in the cloud starts off with random swirling motions known as `turbulence'. Then some clumps undergo gravitational collapse forming stars (white dots), but gas continues to collect. Some stars form in isolation with their disks, but many interact with other young stars and disks in complex ways. A large fraction of stars remain in binary systems. Many stars form in large molecular clouds where hundreds or thousands of stars form together as a star cluster. Here too individual stars often have protoplanetary disks. We will study protoplanetary disks later in the course to understand how diverse types of planetary systems form; this is needed to evaluate how many planets could harbor life similar to Earth's.

Stages of Stellar Evolution

Once formed in a molecular cloud, the individual star goes through four major phases of evolution: - `pre-main sequence' powered by release of energy from the gravitational collapse;

  • `main sequence' powered by fusion of hydrogen to helium in the core;
  • `red giant' powered by fusion of helium to elements up to iron;
  • `death processes'. The outer layers of the red giant stars are ejected, slowly or violently, and the inner core becomes one of three types of compact star (`white dwarf', `neutron star', or `black hole').

The observational evidence for the evolution of a star is often shown on the Hertzsprung-Russell (H-R) diagram. Here we plot the luminosity of the star on the vertical axis (actually, the log of the luminosity since the range of luminosities is so huge), and the surface temperature on the horizontal axis. Recall that `luminosity' has units of energy per second, and measures the intrinsic light output or `power' of a star. A common unit of luminosity is the `watt'; we might have a 60 watt lightbulb in our room, while the Sun today emits 4x1027 watts. A protostar in a molecular cloud has a relatively cool surface but is quite luminous, and thus appears in the upper-right part of the H-R diagram. It quickly (not too quickly …. for a 1 Mo star like the Sun, in ~10 million years) loses power but heats its surface, moving downward and to the left on the diagram below (left).

 

When the star reaches the main sequence where the core temperature exceeds ~13 million degrees Kelvin, nuclear reactions begin in the core that fuse hydrogen to helium. In most stars, this is through the `proton-proton chain' with intermediary steps involving rare isotopes of hydrogen and helium. As over 70% of the star is hydrogen, there is a vast supply of fuel for this reaction, keeping stars on the main sequence for (in most cases) billions of years. This is the most stable and long-lived phase of stellar evolution. Our Sun today has been on the main sequence for 4.5 billion years, and will continue hydrogen-to-helium burning steadily for ~6 billion years more. Below is an artist's conception of the interior of the Sun and many other similar main sequence stars.

Learn more about stellar evolution on the interactive H-R diagram here.  

Red giant stars: `We are starstuff!' (Carl Sagan)

The red giant phase is particularly important for understanding the origin of elements needed for planets and living organisms. When hydrogen is depleted in the core of the main sequence star (that is, when the core is entirely helium), nuclear burning continues in a shell around the core. When the core reaches ~120 million degrees Kelvin, then helium is not longer stable and can react with itself to form heavier elements.

First, the helium flash initiates the reaction

3 4He ---> 12C + 2 gamma-rays

Stars like the Sun will then burn hydrogen to helium in a shell around the core where helium is burning to carbon.  The star becomes very luminous but the outer layers swell to huge radii and cool.  The star thus moves upward and to the right in the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.

   

Cores of more massive stars (5-100 Mo) will be hot enough to burn carbon and other elements up to iron:

12C + 4He ---> 16O
16O + 4He ---> 20Ne
and similar reactions give 24Mg, 28Si, 32 S, ..., 56Fe (iron).

These rare high-mass stars become supergiants, the most luminous stars in the Galaxy, during their brief red giant phases. Several nuclear reactions can occur simultaneously in the core and shells around the core (like layers of an onion; see diagram below). Each nuclear reaction releases more energy, so the stars becomes more and more luminous. These are the massive supergiants with luminosities L ~ 105-106 Lo.

Iron is the last element that can be made in this fashion because it is the most stable nucleus.  That is, any nuclear reaction involving iron requires more enegy than it emits.  Iron is thus the end-product of normal stellar nucleosynthesis.

The synthesis of nuclei in red giants/supergiants explains the relative abundances of different elements in the Universe.  The plot below shows that, after hydrogen & helium, the most abundant elements in the Sun are the even-numbered elements between 6 and 26 protons: C, O, Ne, Mg, ... Fe.  Note also the rarity of elements heavier than iron. Similar abundances of the elements are seen in other stars, the Galaxy's interstellar medium, Jupiter and elsewhere. This universal pattern is powerful evidence for the theory of red giant stars, and implies that red giants are the main source of elements with 6-26 protons in the Universe.

How do these atoms formed inside red giant stars get out into the Galaxy? Convection (like boiling) in red giants brings these heavier elements produced in the interior to the surface. There they condense into tiny solid particles of rock (typically Mg-Si-O mixtures) and carbon which are pushed outward into space by the starlight. These explain the interstellar dust particles, which scatter and redden light in the Milky Way.  Later, the gas and dust ejected by red giant stars enter cold molecular clouds, where it undergoes gravitational collapse and forms new stars and planets.

Thus, the Earth, you and I are composed of C/N/O/Si/Fe/... atoms that were created in red giant stars before our solar system was born. The atoms were formed by nuclear reactions in the giant/supergiant phase, ejected into the interstellar medium in both gaseous and solid form, and later incorporated into the solar system, the biosphere and ourselves.

"We are made of starstuff'' (Carl Sagan)

Summary: The astronomical context for life

In this introductory portion of the course, we have found that normal galaxies, forming in complicated ways billions of years ago after the Big Bang, form stars and planets continuously from their interstellar medium. The stars produce elements heavier than helium by nuclear fusion, and these atoms are ejected into the galaxy's interstellar medium. More stars and planets form in the cold interstellar clouds, now enriched with atoms from the furnaces in stars. These atoms combined to form a wide variety of molecules, many containing carbon. Interstellar clouds can be viewed as a laboratory of organic molecules diluted in the dominant hydrogen (H2) and helium from the Big Bang. These chemicals are familiar to us -- water, molecules in Earth's atmosphere (O2, N2, CO2), methane and other hydrocarbons, alcohols and sugars. These are the molecules we see in our daily lives on the surface of Earth, the same molecules necessary for living organisms on Earth. We thus have traced profound links between the Universe, the galaxies, the stars, the interstellar medium, star and planet formation, and life on Earth. While some of this story was known ~50 years ago and Carl Sagan outlined it for the public ~30 years ago, many of the findings are very recent. Understanding the molecular universe, in particular, is a strong motivation for the most modern (and expensive) telescopes of the past ~10 years such as the Spitzer and Herschel Space Telescopes and the ALMA in Chile.

node.title: The Nature of Time
node.body:
In a fundamental way, life in the Universe would not be possible if our universe had not begun in a very peculiar state. 

This point is important, and relates to one of the three perspectives on the nature of life that we have been discussing - specifically, the Schroedinger picture of life as a system that resists the decay to thermal equilibrium (for a while). In order to understand the importance of the universe's special initial state, and how it made life in this universe possible, we will have to go back to a very basic question:  What is Time? 

What is Time?

There are actually two very different ideas of time that we will need to clarify before we can discuss their relationship to life. Let's review these two ideas and see if we can't find a way to reconcile them into a single picture. 

1. Time is a Dimension

In the first vision, time is a physical dimension of our universe - the dimension we measure with clocks. Just as we can measure the distances between two any two events using a ruler, we can measure the time between any two events using a clock. A "clock", for a scientist, is just any predictably periodic process, for example:  

  • Motions of the Sun, Moon, and planets

  • The human heartbeat, or pulse

  • The motion of a pendulum, as first pointed out by Galileo

  • The regular motions of an analog wrist watch's springs and ratchets

  • The regular vibrations of a digital wrist watch's quartz crystal

  • The rates of atomic or nuclear transitions, as in "atomic clocks"

  • Pulsars observed by radio and X-ray astronomers

Scientists have learned some basic facts about time as a dimension:

  • Some clocks are better than others

  • All clocks can be synchronized, to the limits of their accuracy

  • Psychological or subjective time, as we experience it, has some odd effects – stress, age (but these are not our focus here)

  • Various effects are observed thanks to Einstein’s relativity theories, and the finite speed of light

Once we have accounted for all the objective effects, we find we can correct our measurements from one frame of reference to another, or from one observer to another, without any contradictions. So the picture holds. 

However, this vision of time does not capture every important aspect of our idea of time. We also need a completely different, second vision: 

2. Time is Change

In the second vision, time is the relentless process of change in our cosmos that transforms the unknown future into the unchanging past. There are many differences between the past and the future - not just subjectively! Even with respect to strictly physical measurements, time has a "direction" to it that space (out in outer space, that is) does not. For example:

  • We remember the past and don’t know the future

  • Complex systems evolve toward states of greater disorder, as codified in the famous Second Law of Thermodynamics: Entropy of closed systems (including the universe as a whole) is always increasing

  • Life's metabolic processes are thermodynamic processes: As pointed out by Schroedinger in our reading last week, life persists by eating "negative entropy" or order - in the form of food - from its surroundings, using it to increase and maintain internal order, and releasing entropy or disorder - in the form of heat and waste products - back to the outside world.  

  • All of our civilization's industrial processes also operate on this basis, taking in low-entropy fuel, "burning" or consuming it to carry out useful work, and releasing heat and high-entropy waste as a result. 

  • Similarly, any process of recording data or making memories - creating a little bit of order in the universe - requires the disposal of "waste entropy" somewhere else. 

The directionality of time is often pictured as an “Arrow of Time” pointing away from the past, toward the future. (Sometimes, different arrows of time are discussed, but in the end, these all amount to different versions of the Second Law of Thermodynamics.) From an ordinary, everyday point of view, there is nothing strange about this. 

However, from the point of view of time as a dimension (Vision #1), the difference between past and future is a very odd one indeed. The "directionality" of time is simply not something that physical dimensions intrinsically possess. Out in space there is no difference between left and right, forward and backward, or up and down. Similarly, elementary particle interactions do not recognize any distinction between the two directions of time; the underlying physical laws that govern their motions do not care whether we run our clocks forward or in reverse. So where does the arrow of time come from? 

The answer, it turns out, comes down to an aphorism of the Nobel laureate Philip Anderson, "More is Different." 

Reconciling the Two Visions of Time

The conflict between the two visions of time, one imagining a clockwork (backwards and forwards!) universe, and the other grappling with the messy developing reality of steam engines, friction, and metabolic processes, came to a head in the latter half of the 19th century. Happily for a civilization that was beginning to feel a bit embarrassed about the conflict between its physical theories and its increasingly important industrial processes, these two competing visions were eventually reconciled. The work began with a group of theorists who developed statistical models for the behavior of systems with large numbers of particles, a mole (6.2 x 1023) or more, and reached its conclusion in the work of Austrian theorist Ludwig Boltzmann (1844-1906), who successfully connected this new science of statistical mechanics to the laws of thermodynamics that were already known, including the second law.  

What Boltzmann found was that the complexity of the system under study - the number of interacting particles - makes all the difference between a clockwork, reversible system and the messy world of ever-increasing entropy that we live in. Specifically, the seemingly irreversible nature of complex systems results from nothing more or less than the very large number of interacting particles that they contain, and the extreme improbability of them "accidentally" organizing themselves in any particular way without the action of outside forces. Consider: a single hydrogen atom (proton + electron) will easily ionize (break apart) or recombine (come back together); it may even switch back and forth between these two states a million times a second. A single egg, however (~1023 particles), while it will readily break apart, will not so readily be put back together again. As Boltzmann showed, the contrast in behavior between the two systems - the contrast between our two visions of time - springs solely from the large number of particles involved in the egg, by comparison to the atom. His conclusions: 

  • No "Arrow of Time" exists for simple systems, nor for complex systems once they reach equilibrium. 

  • The Second Law of Thermodynamics is a probabilistic law: Entropy can decrease (eggs unscramble!) even for complex systems, just with extreme, extreme rarity (in the case of the egg, only after many lifetimes of the universe). 

  • Complex systems put in a low-entropy initial state exhibit an "Arrow of Time" as they evolve, in highly predictable fashion, to higher entropy states and eventually equilibrium (maximum entropy).

  • Since the universe around us exhibits an "Arrow of Time", we observe it in exactly this phase of its evolution. 

  • This rather unusual state of the universe can be understood if its entropy was very low in the distant past. 

The last conjecture, known as Boltzmann’s “Past Hypothesis,” has been validated with superb precision by astronomers' studies of the cosmic microwave background radiation. This radiation provides us with a picture of the infant universe as it existed at 380,000 years of age, 99.997% of the way back to the Big Bang, and it shows a universe of extreme smoothness, and incredibly small entropy - much smaller than its entropy today, and even smaller than its maximum equilibrium entropy will be in the distant future. 

Time, Entropy, and Life in the Universe

Since life can only persist in regions of space, and during times, where it is able to extract order from its surroundings (Schroedinger's definition, from last week), all life owes its existence to the extremely low-entropy state that our universe exhibited at its creation. 

Recalling that low-entropy states are low-probability states, this means that our universe was for some reason created in an extremely, extremely improbable state. To theorists today, this is one of the great outstanding puzzles about the origins of the universe. In the next set of notes we will discuss the only approach that has been able to make progress on this fundamental question....

node.title: A Modern View
node.body:
The Anthropic Principle

For decades now, astrophysicists and physicists have been developing arguments about how the observed conditions of the physical Universe seem to be closely linked, in some particular ways, to the existence of living organisms such as ourselves. As we saw in the last page of notes on the nature of time, one of these arguments points out the extreme improbability of our universe's origin in its observed very low-entropy state. Separately, physicists have pointed out that the sizes, masses, and ages of objects we see (atoms, living organisms, planets, stars, galaxies, Universe) can all be derived, in an approximate fashion, by knowing the values of a few physical constants: the relative strengths of the gravitational, electrical, atomic, and nuclear forces; the relative masses of protons and electrons; and the key cosmological parameters of our universe. The existence of these objects thus places constraints on these elementary physical constants.

"The possibility of life as we know it evolving in the Universe depends on the values of a few basic physical constants -- and is in some respects remarkably sensitive to their numerical values."

(Carr & Rees, 1979)

For example, the existence of life on rocky (silicate) water-bearing planets like Earth requires that:

  • The universal expansion following the Big Bang is tuned to produce long-lived, gravitationally-collapsed structures.
  • The ratio of light to particles in the Universe is sufficiently low to permit particles to form neutral atoms and permit gravitational collapse of stars.
  • The constants of nuclear physics are tuned to give long-lived main sequence phases of stars and red giants that synthesize heavy elements.

Together, such requirements place stringent constraints on the fundamental constants of nature, sometimes constraining them to with a few percent of their observed values. These arguments can be made in considerable detail. Here are some details:

  • If the expansion after the Big Bang was weaker than we observe (with other cosmological conditions left the same), then the Universe would have expanded only briefly before recollapsing, and long-lived stars and the planets orbiting them would not have had time to exist. On the other hand, if the Big Bang had been significantly stronger than it was, particles would have dispersed too far from one another too quickly for  gravity to collect them into galaxies and stars. The "just right" early expansion that we observe requires a delicate balance between the effects of Dark Matter and Dark Energy.
  • If the nuclear isotope of lithium 3Li were stable, then the fusion of 4 1H --> 4He would proceed directly and quickly in the cores of stars, and the main sequence phase would not last billions of years.
  • If the carbon nucleus 12C had an energy state just below -- instead of just above -- the energy of a beryllium 8Be energy state, then red giant nucleosynthesis would end at beryllium and heavier elements such as carbon or oxygen - necessary for life as we know it - would be extremely rare.
  • If Newton's law of gravity were F = GMm/r2.1 rather than GMm/r2.0 (or any exponent other than exactly 2!), then there would be no stable orbits for planets around a star.

These arguments are known collectively as the Anthropic Principle. Several variations are discussed (weak Anthropic Principle, strong Anthropic Principle, final Anthropic Principle, etc). Many scientists dislike these arguments intensely: they seem post hoc, that is, positing that the observed phenomena of the universe somehow "act backward in time" on its past conditions. How could the existence of humans 13 billion years after the formation of the Universe possibly affect the properties it had when it was formed?

But this is not actually what adherents of the Anthropic Principle propose. Rather, they suggest that we admit the possibility of there being many universes, each with different physical properties. Then, among the many universes of this "multiverse", life would exist only in those with the appropriate conditions; most probably, the vast majority of universes would not have any living inhabitants. This Multiverse or "Many Universes" Hypothesis is now considered seriously by theoretical physicists engaged in developing the latest theories of quantum relativity and inflationary cosmology. Perhaps universes emerge from some quantum foam? Perhaps the transition from inflation to ordinary expansion occurs differently in each region where it occurs, producing distinct Big Bangs (one per universe) with different properties? Perhaps there `are' (in some sense of existence) many Universes within which only a very few have the carefully tuned conditions necessary for life. Of course, if this is the case, it would not be surprising for us to find ourselves living in one of these rare Universes - just as it is not surprising that we find ourselves inhabiting a warm, stable world orbiting a single, steadily-burning star. In both cases, the "special" properties of our surroundings are in fact those that make our very existence possible.
