node.title: Searching for Extraterrestrial Life
node.body:
If other intelligences exist in the Galaxy, how do we best communicate with them?

  • Hard X-rays/gamma-rays: Hard to produce, impossible to focus
  • Ultraviolet/soft X-rays: Absorbed by atoms in interstellar gas (and Earth's atmosphere)
  • Optical: Signals overwhelmed by starlight
  • Infrared/millimeter: Overwhelmed by interstellar & interplanetary dust emission (and Earth's atmosphere)
  • Centimeter-wavelength (1-30 GHz) radio: YES!
  • Longer than meter wavelength: Overwhelmed by interstellar electron synchrotron emission
  • Non-electromagnetic radiation: neutrino beams? neutron beams? other subatomic particles? Technologies ineffective or not available.

Large radio telescopes sensitive to centimeter wavelength light are easily constructed (e.g. Arecibo Telescope in Puerto Rico, Very Large Array in New Mexico - photos below), radio waves are easily focused (paraboloid shaped dishes), radio receivers are extremely sensitive for reception, and radio broadcasting is easy (e.g. TV stations, radar at airports). Existing radio telescopes could easily detect a typical terrestrial radio/TV broadcast across the Galaxy -- if it were beamed directly towards us.

   

What Frequency to Use?

Examples: AM band from 0.5-1.6 MHz; FM from 88-108 MHz; TV scattered from 50-1000 MHz, plus police/taxi radios, airport/military radar, long-distance telephone, satellite communications, cellphones (rapidly growing), etc. Only a few narrow bands are kept quiet for radio astronomy.  Arguments have been made that the best frequency to use is around 1420 MHz (21.1 cm), the emission line of cold hydrogen.

Solution: build receivers that analyze signals from many (million, billion!) channels simultaneously within radio astronomical bands.

How Do We Recognize an Alien Signal?

Criteria might include: narrow band signal at wavelength not produced by atoms & molecules; rapid variations in signal intensity (a message!) but not a radio pulsar; signal seen from star with good lifezone for habitable planets: signal seen in different telescopes (not local interference); periodic intensity or Doppler shifts from from their planet's rotation/orbit; signal contains complex information.

Could Earth be Detected by Other Civilizations?

Major emission in centimeter band are military radar (esp. over Alaska and Siberia) and TV stations (esp. over US and Europe). Arecibo Telescope could detect these signals out to a few parsecs (tens of stars). TV broadcasts from 1978 had ~10 million watts power, and are now 20 lightyears (6 pc) away with ~20 A-G-K main sequence stars. So not much chance we have been detected yet.

node.title: SETI Radio Searches
node.body:
Project Phoenix

About 1000 solar-like stars within 50 pc have been targeted with Parkes (Australia) 210-foot, Green Bank (West Virginia) 140-foot, and Arecibo (Puerto Rico) 1000-meter telescopes during the 1990s. ~50 million channels at 1-2 Hz resolution between 1-3 GHz (30-10 cm wavelength) are examined for continuous and pulsed signals, including frequency drifts.  Stars with newly discovered planets are included in search. Private funding because Federal funding turned off in 1993 by Congress.  Confirmation by an independent observatory required for identifying a candidate extreterrestrial signal.  Main technical challenge: elimination of human radio interference.  The image below shows frequency (horizontal axis) vs. time (vertical axis) brightness plot with an example of interference.

Excerpt from the Project Phoenix diaries, March 21 2002 at Arecibo (by Seth Shostak, SETI Institute):

Jane Jordan and I tried not to get too excited. A signal picked up while observing target 4505, a star very slightly dimmer than the Sun that's 117 light-years away, was persistent and passing all the usual tests. We moved the telescope off the star system, and the signal went away. We ran it back on the target, and the signal reappeared. It was looking good. We continued to examine 4505 until the Earth's rotation took it beyond Arecibo's field of view, and it looked good all the while.

Nonetheless, we've developed a certain  resistance to easy adrenaline rushes. The microwave band is increasingly jammed by interference from orbiting satellites, so false alarms are common.  As target 4505 drifted out of sight to the west, I wrote in the log book "should be  re-observed." The next night, we did exactly that. This time the signal was seen not only in the direction of the star, but in other directions as well. Sadly, it was just more earthly interference, and definitely not extraterrestrial.

One of these days, this small scenario may end differently. And occasionally we think about that.  It's after midnight. Jill Tarter has taken over the observing, so I walk outside the control room to the patio that overlooks the telescope. Overhead, the familiar  winter constellations prick the humid air. Is there more out there than simply the  frigid blackness of space and the silent boiling of the stars? Are there hidden places where the sounds of life are being made and heard? Do beings exist that  can see the universe and understand what they see? It seems impossible to imagine otherwise.

Allen Telescope Array

Initially funded by Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft Corp, the Allen Telescope Array of small antennas is being constructed in northern California for full-time SETI search.  This will increase SETI studies by a factor of ~100 over current levels, observing 105-106 stars and survey 4x1010 stars in the inner Milky Way at 1420 MHz.  

The ATA is a centimeter-wave array that pioneers the Large-Number Small-Diameter (LNSD) concept of building radio telescopes. By taking advantage of Moore’s Law, the designers are replacing steel with silicon, resulting in a large cost saving over telescopes of more conventional design.  If completed, the ATA will ultimately comprise 350 6-meter dishes.

The ATA has four primary advantages for scientific studies over all major radio telescopes built to date: a very wide field-of-view (2.45° at λ = 21cm), complete instantaneous frequency coverage from 0.5 to 11.2 GHz, multiple simultaneous backends, and active interference mitigation. The instantaneous area of sky imaged is 17 times that of the VLA. The instantaneous frequency coverage of more than 4 octaves is unprecedented in radio astronomy.  Unfortunately, the ATA has run out of money and is not continuously observing.

    

Result from SETI observations

NO EXTRATERRESTRIAL SIGNALS DETECTED

Not a single convincing alien signal has emerged from ANY SETI observation to date.

The SETI Institute in California is run by Dr. Jill Tarter (who was the model for the heroine of the 1997 movie Contact.  Browse their Web site for interesting material regarding SETI.

node.title: Interstellar Travel & UFOs
node.body:
Why Interstellar Space Travel is Hard

I have chosen here to concentrate on a single spacecraft propulsion method here (matter-antimatter annihilation engines) and to think about the issue using elementary formulae from physics:  t=d/v (time to travel = distance divided by velocity); a=v/t (acceleration is change in velocity over time); KE = 1/2 mv2 (kinetic energy of a moving body is one-half the product of its mass and velocity squared);  E=mc2 (Albert Einstein's conversion between mass and energy, only achievable at extremely high temperatures or involving subatomic particles), and the `rocket equation' (not given here becuase it's a bit more complicated, but shows that it becomes exponentially more difficult to propel a spaceship when its mass is dominated by fuel).  Please look at a more thorough discussion of interstellar travel from this perspective by the Australian astrophysicist I.A. Crawford (Quar. J. Royal Astro. Soc. 31, 377-400, 1990), but you are not responsible for understanding this entire article.

Recall from the Drake equation discussion that the distance to the nearest civilization or habitable planet is

d = (2x1013/N)1/3 parsecs,

where N is the number of civilizations or habitable planets in the Galaxy.  Let's assume N~106, which gives d = 300 parsecs ~ 1000 lightyears ~ 1x1019 meters. [Exoplanetary research indicates that the number of Earth-like Habitable Planets is higher than this, but the Drake equation suggests number of current Intelligent Civilizations is lower than this; so N~106 seems like a reasonable middle ground.]  

Our current spacecraft (e.g. Space Shuttle, probes to Jupiter and Saturn) travel at a speed around v = 104 m/s, so the travel time would be

t = d/v = 1x1019 m / 104 m/s = 1x1015 sec ~ 30 million years.

This is far too long to be convenient for human beings! The obvious solution is to develop rocket propulsions that give faster speeds, say 10% of the speed of light:  v = 0.1 c = 3x107 m/s.   Now the travel time would be

t = 1x1019 m / 3x107 m/s = 3x1011 s = 10 thousand years,

which is still very long but not inconceivable.

Let's check whether the human body can tolerate the acceleration and deceleration up to these speeds.  A spacecraft acceleration equivalent to the gravitational acceleration we feel on Earth's surface would be a ~ v/t ~ 10 m/s2.  To reach a speed of v=0.1c would take

t ~ v / a = 3x107 m/s / 10 m/s2 = 1 month,

which is no problem.

Now let's check the power requirements.  Assume the spacecraft has a mass of 100 tons, equivalent to a dozen trucks.  Its kinetic energy is

E = 1/2 m v2 = 1/2 (1x105 kg) (3x107 m/s)2 = 5x1019 watt-sec.

The engine power must thus be at least

E / t = 5x1019 watt-s / 3x1010 s ~ 2000 megawatts,

comparable to big modern power stations. (Here I've assumed acceleration for 1/10th of the 104 year trip.) This doesn't seem too difficult.

But how do we produce so much power for 104 years from such a small mass? The most efficient source of energy is to tap Einstein's equivalence of mass and energy, E=mc2.  We need

m = E / c2 ~ 5x1019 watt-s / (3x108 m/s)2 = 500 kg,

which is within our mass limit. 

But the only efficient way we know to derive this energy is from the annihilation of matter and anti-matter, and we have not been able to make and transport more than infinitisimal (<<<1 gm) quantities of anti-matter. Fermilab's Main Injector can accumulate ~10-8 g of antiprotons/year. If Fermilab uses ~10-4 of modern society's energy resources for 109 years to fuel our spaceship. This is reduced to ~105 years if one could tap all of the solar energy incident on the Earth's surface, and less if one could build a Ringworld or a Dyson sphere to trap a greater fraction of their Sun's energy output. The antiprotons produced must then be cooled with electrons in magnetic traps and (perhaps) stored as solid antihydrogen until needed for flight propulsion. See the analysis Production and trapping of antimatter for space propulsion applications by (former-PSU Physics professor) G. A. Smith & colleagues.

Crawford makes a similar (but better!) calculation of a spaceship using antimatter drives in his section 4.  Note that I ignored the question of how to actually produce thrust from matter-antimatter annihilation; Crawford argues that the annihilating particles should be surrounded by ordinary matter (say, water that Crawford calls the `reaction fluid') that absorbs the products (pions, muons and positrons) of the annihilations, heats and evaporates (makes steam)  giving a jet of ordinary atoms to thrust the spaceship forward.  Now the spaceship weighs more (carrying tons of reaction fluid), so more than a few hundred kilograms of antimatter is needed to power the trip.  Crawford solves the rocket equation (eq. 1-9).  Crawford and others don't think the antimatter drive is feasible because we can't make enough antimatter, and they prefer light sail technologies.

Conclusion: The distances between existing intelligent civilizations is likely to be >1000 light years, although the distance to the nearest Earth-like Habitable Planet might be as little as ~10-100 lightyears.  It is physically possible for a civilization  to travel such distances if the travel time is long (say 104 yrs).  But it is very difficult (orders of magnitude byond our current societal capability) to produce the necessary antimatter fuel, or the necessary laser power for light sails. As such, designing a space ship that can reach other stars in a human lifetime is not possible for our society at present, but it is also not ruled out by any laws of physics.

node.title: Drake Equation
node.body:
How Many Intelligent Civilizations are in the Galaxy Today?

In 1961, astronomer Frank Drake developed a formula to estimate the number of intelligent species or communicable civilizations in our galaxy that we could communicate with at this instant of time. The Drake Equation is still used to estimate the number of cummunicable civilizations in the Galaxy. Reasonable estimates range from 1 (only us) to 108.

Ni  = N* x fp x Np x fe x fl x fi x Li/LMW

Values need to be determined for each factor. Some can be calculated fairly easily, other are extremely uncertain estimates. A wide range of information is needed to determine Ni.  Note that this is not a real equatlion of physics, like Newton's equations of motion and gravity.  Rather, it is a way to organize ones thinking about life in the Universe.  Different calculations can have slightly different factors.  Let us now go through these factors individually, and then multiply them to ogether to estimate the number of intelligent civilizations in the Galaxy today. 

  • N* = Number of stars in the galaxy. Current measurement of the size, rotation and luminosity of our Milky Way Galaxy gives a mass in stars (excluding the Galaxy's Dark Matter) around 300 billion Mo (3 x 1011 solar masses). Since the most common star has M~0.3 Mo, we estimate there are a trillion (1 x 1012) stars in the Milky Way.
  • fp = Fraction of these stars that can host habitable planets. High mass stars (OBAF) may evolve so fast that intelligent life does not have the time to develop; but these stars are rare.  Binary systems with 0.1-100AU separations will not permit stable orbits; this eliminates some stars.  But the very recent census of exoplanets, discussed two weeks ago, directly demonstrates that the majority of stars -- not only can -- but actually do contain planets that orbit inside, within, and outside the habitable zone.  So, I think that a reasonable estimate today is fp~0.7 -- very high compared to earlier discussions of the Drake Equation.  (The current authors of Wikipedia, for example, are more cautious but still put this at fraction at 0.2-0.5.)  Until recently, many astronomers considered this fraction to be lower (maybe 0.05), but it has recently be recognized that the very common low-mass M stars have good Habitable Zones close to the star.   
  • Np = number of planets per star . Our own solar system has ~8 planets.  Using radial velocity techniques, Penn State Professor Jason Wright has estimated that at least 28% of stars that have one planet also have additional planets.  See his 2009 paper.   Using planetary transit techniques, the Kepler mission has found roughly 10% of stars with one planet also have additional planets.  But in both cases other planets could be present and still be undetected today.  Planet formation calculations (e.g. oligarchic growth of planetary embryos) suggest that a number of widely-spaced planets is a common and stable configuration.  My estimate, based on the data and planet formation theory is again optimistic:  Np~5.
  • fe = Fraction of these planets with Earth-like conditions suitable for life. This restricts planets of interest to those with nearly-circular orbits in the habitable zone where water is liquid.  Planetary mass and atmospheric composition play an important role in habitability, e.g. through the carbonate-silicate cycle (Scharf's text, sec 9.3).  In our own system, 1-2 out of 8 planets are suitable for life for extended periods (say, >1 Gyr, Gyr = giga year = billion years).  this includes Earth and Mars, because Mars was habitable 1-2 GYy ago when water flowed in rivers and oceans.  A few of the extrasolar planets fall within the Habitable Zone, though often with eccentric orbits.  The recent estimates based on Kepler mission data by Catanzarite & Shao and by Traub suggest fe~0.03-0.3.  Again this is a very high fraction.  
  • fl = Fraction of suitable planets where life actually develops Miller-Urey experiments show  that biotic material (e.g.. amino acids, lipids) can arise in an environment like the early Earth.  Simple biotic material may also be brought in by infalling interstellar particles or comets. Life may take a wide variety of forms from sulfur metabolizing, deep-sea vent bacteria to oxygen-breathing animals.  Nonetheless, there has been no success in producing self-reproducing macromolecular systems in the laboratory. So the mechanism of life formation is still unknown and the probability of it happening in a limited time or location is very small.  The integrated probability over a Gyr and over an entire planet is unknown.  Let's say the chance is at least one-in-a-thousand habitable planets give rise to life, fl~10-3-100.
  • fi = Our definition of an intelligent civilization is one that is able to communicate using radio telescopes. It took ~4 Gyr for simple cyanobacteria to evolve into radio astronomers.  Asteroidal impacts (such as the one that killed the dinosaurs) or climatic changes (like the changes that dried up Mars) are two possibilities. It is also possible that an intelligent species might emerge but be unable or unwilling to communicate, e.g.  life on water or gas worlds.  This quantity is entirely unknown.  Let's say again at least on-in-a-thousand but no more than 10% of lifeforms develop radio telescopes:  fi=10-3-10-1.
  • L/LMW = Lifetime of communicating civilization / Lifetime of Milky Way. The lifetime of the Milky Way is ~11 Gyr (1x1011 yr). Our radio telescopes have been in existence only tens-of-years (101 yr) and all human culture with written languages are 104 yr old.  What does the future hold?  Civilizations can be destroyed by nuclear or biological war, environmental or technological disaster,  asteroidal impact or some other catastrophe. It is also possible that civilizations have the ability to build radio telescope, but choose not to.  Let's guess L/LMW~10-7-10-3.

Ni  = (1x1012)* x 0.7p x 5p x (0.03-0.3)e x (10-3-100)l x (10-3-10-1) i x (10-7-10-3)

Multiplying these factors give a range of to 1x10-2 to 1x108 intelligent civilizations in the Galaxy today. The minimum of 3x10-3 intelligent civilizations in the Galaxy today seems too low.  Since we have radio telescopes, the number is at least 1 = 100.  

So it is reasonable to consider that there are between one (we are alone in the Galaxy) to a hundred million (108) intelligent civilizations in the Galaxy today.  For convenience, let us choose Ni~103, understanding that it could be a thousand times higher or lower. Most of the uncertainty involves the biological and sociological aspects of the Drake Equation (last three factors), not the astronomical aspects (first four aspects).  

Please examine similar discussions of the Drake Equation online at Wikipedia and the SETI Institute website.  This last link, to the SETI Institute in California, has a great 7-minute TED talk by Jill Tarter, Director of the Institute who was the model for the heroine of the 1997 movie Contact (written by Carl Sagan).  She emphasizes the importance of the L/LMW factor in the Drake Equation.  

How Far Away is the Nearest Intelligent Civilization?

We can use our answer to estimate if communication with other intelligent civilizations is practical by asking: What is the average distance between civilizations for a given Ni?  Consider that most stars lie in the Galactic disk (the Galactic halo has fewer stars and these have lower metallicities, so plausibly fewer planets). The Milky Way disk is roughly a cylinder with volume:

2 pi R2 x h ~ 2 pi (100,000 ly)2 1,500 ly ~  1 x 1014 ly3 (cubic light years) 

The density of civilizations is the number per unit volume, or Ni / (1 X 1014) civilizations per cubic light year.  Since volumes have units of (distance)3, and the density has units of (distance)-3,  the typical distance between civilizations (if they are randomly distributed in the Galactic disk) is d = 1/ (Density)1/3.  So, if Ni=103 and Volume=1014 lightyears, the density is 10-11 ly-3 and the average distance between civilizations is d ~ 5,000 ly.  This is about 2 kpc (kiloparsecs) using the units familiar to astronomers.   For a more optimistic estimate of Ni=1,000,000, d ~ 500 ly = 200 pc.

The distance in light years is the time it takes to send a message in years. Twice this number is the time to send a message and get a reply (plus a bit for the message recipient to think of a response and prepare the radio telescope).  So, for middle values of Ni in the Drake Equation, a typical conversation takes thousands of years to occur.  That's very long on himan timescales!  If the first pharaohs of ancient Egypt had our advanced telescope technology and sent a message to the nearest civilization (assuming they knew which star had the right inhabited planet with radio telescopes), we would only now be receiving the first response. Thus, except for very optimistic values of Ni, optimistic values, meaningful conversations between civilizations are not really viable because the time to send/receive a message is longer than the duration of a civilization.

node.title: Science Writing Papers
node.body:
Start Here

Start with this 10-min video about science writing. (This video was made a previous semester, so the due dates are wrong. The correct deadlines are given below.)

Goals

The goals of the paper assignments are as follows:  

  • Provide students with the opportunity to investigate a narrow scientific issue in some detail;
  • Challenge the student to assimilate diverse information into a coherent narrative;
  • Provide training in the art of scientific writing.

Format

The paper should be prepared with a word processing program like Microsoft Word or Google Docs, in the following format: 12pt Arial or Times Roman font; single-spaced, 1 inch margins; 8.5x11 inch or A4 paper. Papers may be submitted in either .docx or .pdf fomat with file names like "Lastname_Paper1.pdf".  For each paper, the text length is between 2 and 3 pages (roughly 7-11 paragraphs) and 1-2 additional pages with references (minimum three non-encyclopedia references) and useful figures or tables (e.g., jpg images imported from Web resources).  A cover sheet should be added with the paper title, student name and email, and date of submission.   The draft for paper #1 should be double-spaced (and hence will be 4-6 pages of text, plus references), so as to leave space for writing comments.  

Grading

Paper 1 will count 12% of the course grade, and Paper 2 will count 15%.  For Paper 1, students will submit a draft (a detailed outline with references would also be acceptable) to the instructor for improvement of writing and organization, but the grade will be based on the final version.  Half of the grade will be based on content: motivation, scientific details, and synthesis.  Half of the grade will be based on writing:  overall organization, well-designed paragraphs, sentences and grammar.

Deadlines

Paper 1 draft is due Friday, September 32.  The final version of Paper 1 is due Friday, October 14.  Paper 2 is due by Tuesday, December 13 (near the beginning of Exam Week).  Papers are to be submitted via Canvas.  [UPDATE WITH MORE DETAILED INSTRUCTIONS.]  Students are strongly encouraged to informally consult with the instructor as they progress with the papers.  

Paper Topic

For paper #1, paper topic should be chosen from the list below, or selected by mutual agreement with the instructor.  Generally speaking, your textbook and Wikipedia provide useful starting points for your research; however, they may not be your primary sources.   Consultation of a minimum of three additional high-quality resources is required. If you have difficulty identifying resources, please contact the instructor.  If you have trouble obtaining full text versions of important documents for the course, then please ask Penn State libraries for assistance.

Writing Style

Quality science writing is a skill well worth developing and exercising. The paper's overall organization looks like a U: it begins with a short statement of motivation or scientific issue; most of the text presents the evidence or argument (usually a combination of empirical findings and scientific model formulation); and the paper ends with a discussion of how the results relate to the original motivation. Within the text, the paragraphs should follow a logical trail. Within a paragraph, sentences should be well-constructed with informative nouns and verbs; use of the passive voice should be avoided as much as practical. No first person language (use of "i" or "We") is permitted.  For useful advice, please see:

  • Eric Feigelson's general advice for astronomy writing
  • Caty Pilachowski's tips for astronomy writing
  • William Safire's rules for writers
  • Writing in the sciences
  • Astro writing problems (Feigelson)

Regarding references, the common procedure in the physical sciences literature is to say in the text " ... blah blah (Smith 2010).  ... blah blah (Smith & Ford 2011) " and then in the references

Smith, A. B. 2010, A big result on extremophiles, http://www.blah.org   [or]

Smith, A. B. & Ford, E. B. 2011, A big result on extremophiles, Astrophysical Journal, 409, 525-530

Plagiarism is strictly prohibited. For example, you are not permitted to cut and paste text from the Web, rather than understanding and restating the issues in your own voice (with appropriate reference). Extensive quotations and quotations from any source are also inappropriate. Note that it will be much easier to phase an argument or conclusion in your own words if you have reviewed multiple references on the subject before writing your own text. The presence of plagiarized text may be checked using specialized software.  Plagiarism can have severe consequences.  If you have any doubts about whether something might be considered plagiarism, ASK BEFORE, not after you submit the assignment.

++++++++++++++++++++
